sections.heading: 1.1. Introduction and Scope
sections.text:
The metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), also called porous coordination polymers (PCPs), are two- or three-dimensional porous crystalline materials with infinite lattices synthesized from secondary building units (SBU), metal cations salts or clusters, and polydentate organic ligands with coordinationtype connections.1−5 Their structure is flexible and can be tuned by variation of the nature of the metal cation and linkers and by postsynthesis modification (PSM).6 MOFs bridge micro- and mesoporous materials and possess ultrahigh surface areas measured by Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) up to 10000 m2 g−1, which is much higher than zeolites and active carbons.7 MOF constructions and applications have been pioneered and emphasized in the 1990s by the groups of Robson,8 Moore,9 Yaghi,10 Kitagawa,11 and Feŕey.12 More than 20 000 MOF structures have so far been reported, and some MOFs have been produced in ton scales by BASF and are available at Sigma-Aldrich, Strem Chemical, and MOF technologies. The most currently utilized MOFs are MIL-53, HKUST-1, Fe-BTC, and ZIF-8. Their properties include inter alia gas storage, energy conversion, chemical sensing, drug delivery, proton conductivity, and catalysis, and their applications are in oleo-chemical and textile industries, transportation, all-electric automobile prototypes, food packaging, and respiratory systems.1−5,13
In the present review, we will first delineate the essential features and basic concepts involving catalysis by MOF nanoparticles (NPs) including synergistic interactions between the NPs and various catalytic components using seminal and major examples. Then we will comprehensively review research works published since the beginning of 2017 and until the first term of 2019, classified by reaction types. Indeed given the exponential growth of the field, the numbers of publications before 2017 and since then are of the same order. These reactions will be divided into three categories: “chemical”, electrocatalytic, and photocatalytic. Finally, we will suggest future prospects with remaining challenges. Seminal catalytic use of a MOF clathrate was reported in 1994 by Fujita et al.14 These authors constructed a two-
dimensional 2D network of Cd(4,4′-bpy)2(NO3)2 by reaction between Cd(NO3)2 and (4,4′-bpy), and they used this MOF clathrate as a heterogeneous catalyst for the cyanosilylation of aldehydes. Excellent general reviews on MOFs in catalysis covering up to 2016 are available.15−33

sections.heading: 1.2. Background
sections.text:
1.2.1. MOF for Catalysis and NP@MOF. The MOFs are superb catalyst templates due to their metal centers, highly ordered porous structure, uniform pore sizes and environments, very high surface areas, and functional organic linkers. The metal located at the nodes of the MOF structure such as Cr,34 Mn,35 or Cu36,37 possesses free coordination sites following thermal removal of water ligands without great structural change. These coordinatively unsaturated metal sites act as excellent Lewis acid catalysts by themselves or in synergy with encapsulated NPs. Another very efficient method of introduction of catalytically active metal sites in MOF consists in the metalation of ligands located on the MOF linkers either during the MOF synthesis or by postsynthesis modification (PSM, Scheme 1).
With their very large variety of topologies, MOFs are highly adaptable to catalytic design and can contain various guests including metal- and semiconductor oxide NPs. The leaching of small cluster atoms may eventually be prevented by MOF functional groups. The pore confinement limits the growth of metal and metal oxide NPs and favors the construction of ultrafine nano-objects. The insoluble character of MOFs insures heterogeneous catalysis for easy recycling, and their open channels favor the transport and diffusion of substrates and products with minimized mass-transfer limit. The MOF pore shapes and sizes are uniform and tunable upon design, affording size-selective catalysis. The MOFs can be combined with other nanostructures such as graphene and nanotubes in order to improve conductivity, and they can be calcinated to provide hybrid catalytically efficient metal−carbon and -heteroatom nanocomposites (Scheme 2).26
The metal centers and organic linkers are parts of the MOFs that act in synergy with a guest nanocatalyst located inside the MOF cavity. In MOF structures, the metal can be replaced by a variety of Earth-abundant transition metals, and heterometallic MOFs are also accessible. All these multiple advantages of MOFs have already been highlighted.1−7,13−31 The thermal stability and stability in water are essential factors for uses of MOFs in catalysis. In the early stages of MOF catalysis research, MOF structures such as MOF-538 and MOF-17739 that have impressive surface areas and gas storage performances were also used in catalysis but suffered from limited thermal resistance or sensitivity to moisture. More robust MOFs have recently been selected, however. The very
Scheme 1. Picture Representing the Principle of Postsynthetic Modification of Porous MOFsa
aReproduced with permission from ref 6. Copyright 2009 The Royal Society of Chemistry.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
B
thermally robust, water-resistant, and therefore most extensively studied MOF structures in catalysis during the past decade are MOF-74,40 ZIF-8,42,43 CPO-27,41,44 UiO-66,45 CuBDC (HKUST-1),46 MIL-53,47 and MIL-101.48 These MOFs withstand prolonged heating in boiling water,43,49−51 as verified by the identity of their X-ray data before and after such water treatments. Postsynthetic metal-cation exchange and ligand functionalization are factors that can improve water resistance whenever needed.51 The introduction of NPs in MOFs is most often conducted in MOFs by impregnation, but in order to ensure complete NP encapsulation, more sophisticated methods are also used21 and briefly discussed in the following sections. 1.2.2. Characterization of MOF-Nanoparticle Catalysts. MOFs are characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, including a check of the thermal stability after the reaction), and BET surface area.52 After introduction of the metal NPs by the deposition-precipitation method consisting in mixing the metal salt(s) with an aqueous MOF suspension followed by reduction with NaBH4 or another adequate reducing agent, the MOF-NP catalyst is characterized by TEM and high-angle annular dark-field imaging (HAADF), a STEM technique (HADDF-STEM) producing an annular dark-field image formed by very high angle, incoherently scattered electrons. Series of 2D data at various tilting angles using this technique allow a tomographic 3D reconstruction of the metal NP/MOF composite, which shows whether the NPs are located only inside the MOF framework. Measurement of the NP size by TEM only poses a problem because of the small NP size and lack of contrast with the MOF framework, and the charges that accumulate under the electron beam cause distortion of the images. Therefore, the MOF framework may be digested and the metal NPs stabilized using a polymer. For instance ZIF-8 is digested using ethylenediamine tetracetic acid (EDTA) in the presence of poly(vinylpyrolidone) (PVP, Mw = 10 000). 53 Otherwise, nitrogen sorption of the MOF-NP catalyst also shows much size decrease compared to the free MOF. New characterization techniques such as spherical aberrationcorrected high-resolution electron microscopy and cryoelectron microscopy may also be applied.54 The amount of metal contained in the MOFs is inferior to the one of the
precursor because some metal components remain in solution or in suspension outside the MOF frameworks. The metal content in MOFs can be determined by inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS).55 These data together with the NP metal surface determined by TEM allow one to calculate TOF values per NP surface atom. Spatial location of the metal NP in the MOFs, a question rarely addressed that involves the MOF-NP interactions, may be investigated using X-ray synchrotron radiation experiments.56 The crystallinity of the nanomaterial may be tested by the observation of lattice fringes by HRTEM. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), eventually called energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDXA) or also energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDXMA), is used for elemental analysis; this technique is based on the interaction of an X-ray source with the sample and allows one to determine if bimetallic NPs have an alloy or core−shell structure.57 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) allows one to determine the oxidation states of the metal(s) in the NPs. These techniques may be complemented by Fourier-transformed infrared (FTIR), NMR, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopies whenever their use is appropriate.
1.2.3. Introduction of NPs in MOFs. The NPs are most often synthesized by solution impregnation, whereby the MOF is impregnated by contact with the solution of the metal salts followed by reduction by NaBH4 or other reducing agents. During these syntheses, in many cases there is also formation of NPs on the external MOF surface in addition to incorporation into the MOF. The bimetallic NP@MOF synthesized in this way have been essentially used for hydrogen production from ammonia borane,58−60 hydrazine,61−64 or formic acid.65−68 Another efficient method is the “bottle around the ship” synthesis whereby the MOF is assembled around the NP seed with subsequent growth of the NP@MOF assembly. These nanomaterials obtainable only with a few MOFs (essentially ZIF-8 and UiO) were used for ethylene photodegradation to CO2 and H2O,
69 secondary alcohol oxidation,70 nitrobenzene hydrogenation,71 generation of H2 from formic acid,72 and tandem reductive imination of nitroarenes with carbonyl compounds.73 A few NP@MOF (MIL-101) catalysts were also synthesized by MOCVD for the reduction of phenols and ketones by Ni−Pd74 and by the sol− gel method for the hydrogenation of benzene to cyclohexane by Ru−Pt.75 With MOFs possessing hydrophilic environment and large cavities such as MIL-101, a double-solvent approach (DSA) is sometimes utilized in order to avoid or minimize metal NP formation outside the MOF cavity, an inconvenience encountered with the impregnation method. The quantitative volume of aqueous solution of the metal precursor is selectively introduced into the MOF pores following dispersion in a large volume of organic solvent with a low boiling point. This astute process pioneered by Xu’s group is driven by hydrophilic interactions and capillary forces and is effective for both monoand bimetallic NPs.76 It was applied by Jiang’s group to the synthesis of encapsulated core−shell NPs. Pd(NO3)2·2H2O and CoCl2·6H2O were introduced into MIL-101 using DSA followed by sequential reduction using NH3BH3 of Pd(II) (E°Pd2+/Pd = 0.915 eV vs SHE), then Co(II) (E°Co2+/Co = 0.28 eV vs SHE, SHE = standard hydrogen electrode) according to the order of these standard redox potentials. The mild reductant NH3BH3 is selective, whereas the strong reductant NaBH4 is not, leading to the formation of alloyed PdCo NP in MIL-101.77 Core−shell bimetallic NP catalysts are of interest
Scheme 2. Fabrication of Numerous Porous Materials from MOFs and MOF-Based Composites through Pyrolysisa
aReproduced with permission from ref 26. Copyright 2018 Elsevier.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
C
because the electronic structure and activation property of the shell is modified by the presence of the core. Their synthesis has mostly concerned noble metals and has been influenced by galvanic effects. In various MOFs they have been utilized to catalyze formation of H2 from ammonia borane,
77 4-nitrophenol reduction,78 CO oxidation to CO2,
79 and phenylacetylene hydrogenation to styrene.80 Grinding solid NP precursors with MOFs, applicable only with volatile precursors, avoids the use of solvents but ensures complete precursor encapsulation in the MOF. This technique has been pioneered by Haruta with various MOFs including Al-MIL-53, MOF-5, CPL-1, HKUST-1 and ZIF-8 for the synthesis of encapsulated Au NPs of small size using the volatile gold complex [AuMe2(acac)]. 81,82
Metal NPs have also been generated in MOFs from their precursors simply thermally without the addition of any reducing agent. In many cases, such a method leads to MOF destruction or partial decomposition, depending on the MOF stability and the heating mode. This technique is used in various ways to form new catalysts with different degrees of nanomaterial decomposition, and specific examples will be further discussed.27,83 Variation of NP/MOF composites with NPs inside or outside the MOF are known involving stepwise or one-step synthesis of the NPs and MOF depending on the MOF type and procedure.27 All these methods are attempting to obtain clean, well-defined NPs inside MOFs, but engineering and readily verifying such syntheses remain a difficult challenge. 1.2.4. Monometallic NP@MOF Catalysts. A specific feature of NP@MOFs is their ability to activate substrates with synergy of interactions with both some part of the MOF framework (Lewis acidic metal, etc.) and the encapsulated nanoparticles, allowing tandem reactions. For instance, it was shown in early examples that phenol coordination to Cr(III) allowed PdNP@MIL-101-catalyzed hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone at atmospheric pressure and room temperature (rt), coordination inhibiting further hydrogenation to cyclohexanol.84 MIL-101, a well-known mesoporous material with large pores of 2.9 and 3.4 nm and a high BET surface area of ca. 4000 m2 g−1, has a high density of Cr Lewis acid centers. MOF pores also provide size selectivity. In a seminal example, n-hexene was selectively hydrogenated in the presence of ciscyclooctene by PtNP@ZIF-8 based on size selectivity of the MOF cavity.85 PdNP@MIL-101 catalyzed the cyclization of citronellol diastereoselectively forming rac-isopulegol that was further hydrogenated over the PdNPs to (−) menthol.86 MNP@MIL-101 (M = Pd, Pt) also catalyzed the tandem nitroarene reduction to aromatic amine followed by reaction with an aldehyde or ketone yielding the imine and imine hydrogenation to the secondary arylamine.87 The presence of an amino group in amino-functionalized MOFs is useful for organic catalysis and tandem reactions. For instance PdNP@ NH2-MIL-125 efficiently catalyzed formic acid dehydrogenation producing H2.
88 AuNP@NH2-MIL-53 catalyzed benzyl alcohol oxidation and Knoevenagel condensation.89 Yaghi et al. attached sulfonic acid and ammonium groups to UiO-66-type MOFs called UiO-66-S and UiO-66-N, respectively. In methylcyclopentane transformation, the former catalyst selectively promoted the formation of cyclic C6 products, whereas the latter one promoted that of acyclic C6 products.90 The same MOFs to which NH2 or OMe groups were attached also yielded group-dependent selectivities in benzaldehyde areobic reactions in the presence of ethylene glycol.91
Finally asymmetric catalysis has also been conducted on MNP@MOF. For instance the presence of cinchonidine, a chiral alcaloid̈e, in PdNP@MIL-101 resulted in enantioselectivity23 in the asymmetric hydrogenation of prochiral olefins such as ethyl pyruvate and ethyl-2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate.92
1.2.5. Bimetallic NP@MOF Catalysis. The use of bimetallic NPs encapsulated in the MOF structure in catalysis allows not only synergistic activation between the NP and the MOF but also synergy between the two metals enhancing catalytic activity compared to those of both individual metal NPs. The bimetallic NPs can be alloys or core−shell NPs. In the PdNP@MIL-101-catalyzed cyclization of citronellol diastereoselectively forming rac-isopulegol that was further hydrogenated over the PdNPs to (−) menthol cited above in 1.2.4,86 the presence of Ag in the PdAg alloy slowed down the reaction, rendering it more selective (Scheme 3).93 AuPd@
MIL-101 selectively catalyzed oxidation of toluene to benzyl benzoate in air. With another MOF, Pd@UiO-66-NH2 benzyl alcohol reacted to selectively yield 2-phenyl-1,3-dioxolane via formation of benzaldehyde and further acetalization using ethylene glycol.94 The bifunctional MOF PdPt@MM-MIL-53 containing both acidic and basic sites catalyzed oxidant-free secondary alcohol dehydrogenation to ketones and H2. 95
There are also NPs that are combined with other species, and in most cases, a metal NP was combined with a metal oxide in the MOF structure. For instance AuMOx@MOF-5 (M = Zn, Ti, x = 1, 2) in which both metal oxides strongly interacted with the AuNPs catalyzed benzyl alcohol oxidation in the liquid phase with higher selectivities and activities than Au@MOF-5.96 Metal oxide NPs and their molecular cousins, the polyoxometallates (POMs), play important roles in MOF nanomaterial catalysis, because their hydrophilic oxygen atom activates the hydrogen atoms of water and OH-containing molecules. Metal NPs can also act in synergy with a variety of other nanoparticles and other molecular ensembles and such applications have been reviewed.97
MOFs act in synergy in catalytic reactions in various ways using their SBUs, linkers, or PSM with functional groups such as amines.90,91 Yaghi and Somorjai’s group showed that variation of the acidic properties of linking ligands in UiO-66
Scheme 3. Bimetallic PdAg@MIL-101 with Multiple Active Sites for One-Pot Cascade Reactiona
aReproduced from ref 93. Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
D
led to different product selectivities and activities of embedded PtNPs in the gas-phase conversion of methylcyclopentane to acyclic isomer, olefins, cyclohexane, and benzene.90 MOFs not only provide size selectivity but also were shown to boost the concentrations and reactivities of gases such as H2 or CO in MOF cavities as shown for instance in PdNP-catalyzed hydrogenation of CC bonds with H298,99 and aminocarboxylation100 or aminocarbonylation101 of aryl iodides with CO, respectively. 1.2.6. Tandem Reactions. A good proportion of examples of tandem reactions with NPs@MOF catalysts involved the Knoevenagel reaction (see section 2.2.4 for recent reports on this reaction), and typical early tandem examples briefly follow. For instance, Tang reported the Knoevenagel reaction of 4- n i t robenza ldehyde wi th malononi t r i l e to 2-(4 - nitrobenzylidene)malononitrile catalyzed by Pd@IRMOF-3 in which the MOF was amino-functionalized, and this reaction was followed by hydrogenation of the nitro group to the amino group.102 In another example, Raja’s group reported the onepot and heterogeneous selective oxidation of primary alcohols in tandem with the Knoevenagel condensation reaction catalyzed by AuNP@UiO-66-NH2. 103
1.2.7. MOF-Derived Catalysts. Whereas MOF-based catalysts described above involve metal-MOF as catalysts or parts of catalysts in which the MOF itself is present in its integrity during the whole reaction time, MOFs have also been pyrolized at various temperatures (most often between 700 and 1000 °C) for a usage as self-sacrificing templates toward the fabrication of highly porous carbon-based materials (Figure 1). These MOF-derived nanomaterials benefit from precise
morphologies, hierarchical porosities, and doping with heteroatoms, metal NPs, and metal oxide NPs. With high BET surfaces, they present a large density of active sites and therefore serve as excellent and durable heterogeneous catalysts, cocatalysts, or catalyst supports for a variety of reactions. This area has been developed relatively recently, and a large number of rationally designed examples are found herein, in particular, in the electrocatalysis and photocatalysis
sections. Initiation of this area during the period before 2017 has been systematically reviewed by the groups of Song and Zhang24 and Li.32

sections.heading: 2.1. Hydrogen Evolution from Inorganic Hydrides
sections.text:
Hydrogen generation from suitable hydrogen storage inorganic solid materials, in particular sodium borohydride (NaBH4), ammonia-borane (NH3·BH3, AB), hydrous hydrazine (H2NNH2·H2O), and formic acid (HCOOH, FA) is an important component of advances in hydrogen technology.104 Rossin et al. reviewed catalyzed H2 evolution from borohydrides, AB, sodium alanate and hydrazine in MOFs either thermally or upon hydrolysis.105 Most studies are now focusing on hydrolysis reactions yielding a higher H2 content than thermolysis that also gives various polymers from boron hydrides. Sodium borohydride has been a very popular potential hydrogen storage material that has still been extensively investigated over the past decade.106 NaBH4 is a well-known reducing agent, and its gravimetric hydrogen storage capacity is as high as 10.8 wt %. In 1953, Schlesinger et al.107 reported the reaction of NaBH4 with water generating 4 mol of hydrogen per mol NaBH4 and sodium metaborate (NaBO2) under ambient conditions.
NaBH 2H O NaBO 4H4 2 2 2+ → + (1)
This self-hydrolysis is slow, but the reaction between NaBH4 and water becomes fast when the temperature rises 100 °C, and acids and certain catalysts help to speed up the reaction, even at rt. Therefore, appropriate catalysts are required in order to accelerate the hydrolysis of NaBH4 at rt. Among various catalysts toward this reaction, cobalt NPs are recognized as one of the most efficient first-raw transition metal NP catalysts for H2 production from NaBH4 hydrolysis, and they are also widely used owing to their low cost.108 Luo et al. synthesized a series of Earth-abundant first-raw transition metal NPs embedded in ZIF-8 and showed that the best activity for NaBH4 hydrolysis was that of CoNPs@ZIF-8 with a rate of 14 000 mLH2 min −1 gCo −1 and 19 400 mLH2 min −1 gCo −1 at 30 °C (Figure 2).109
There is now increasing interest for the controlled pyrolysis of MNP@MOF structures to fabricate efficient nanocomposite catalysts for H2 evolution from NaBH4. A porous magnetic cobalt/carbon composite (MCCC) was prepared using the cobalt-based ZIF-67 as a precursor (carbonized at 600 °C) by Lin et al.110 A cobalt content of 33 wt % made MCCC an efficient catalyst to hydrolyze NaBH4 with an Ea value of 64.3 kJ mol−1. In the presence of 1 M NaOH, MCCC showed superior catalytic capability with an activation energy value Ea decreasing to 25.8 kJ mol−1. A Co−Co3O4@carbon composite possessing a core−shell Co−Co3O4@C structure was synthesized from a Co-MOFs@glucose polymer by Du and Li et al. by controlled thermolysis followed by partial oxidation.111 Synergistic interactions between Co and Co3O4 NPs was found in Co−Co3O4@C and afforded a H2 generation rate of 5360 mL min−1 gCo
−1 for NaBH4 hydrolysis. Co@C composites were prepared by carbonization of Co@MOF precursors at various temperatures, and Co@C-700 in which Co NPs were highly dispersed in nanoporous C was found to be the best of these catalysts for NaBH4 hydrolysis; upon recycling five times, 93% of the activity was retained.112
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
E
Lithium borohydride has been studied much more rarely than NaBH4 as hydrogen storage material, in spite of its high hydrogen volumetric and gravimetric contents. Recently, studies of hydrogen production from both LiBH4 and NH3BH3 have been reviewed. 113
Ammonia-borane has received much attention because of its high hydrogen content (19.6% wt), low molecular weight (30.87 g mol−1), high solubility in common solvents, and high stability under ambient conditions.114,115 These properties make AB a convenient source of H2 upon hydrolytic dehydrogenation that can be achieved under ambient conditions only in the presence of suitable catalysts. Various late transition metal NP catalysts were generated in MOFs for hydrolysis of AB.117−128 Some reports also involve H2 release from methylamine borane (CH3NH2BH3) hydrolysis (for instance catalyzed by CuNP@MIL-101).129 These catalysts provoke the evolution of 3 mol H2 upon AB hydrolysis, the reaction being zero-order in AB and first-order in catalyst. The stoichiometry of AB hydrolysis catalyzed by NPs was shown by Duan and Chen,116 as follows:
H N BH 4H O NH B(OH) 3H3 3 2 4 4 2· + → + + −
(2)
Noble metal nanoparticles (NPs) have catalyzed the reaction with high hydrogen evolution rates. The practical use of noblemetal NPs is limited, however, owing to their high cost and global reserve scarcities. Thus, the improvement of non-noble metal catalysts possessing similar catalytic performance is important. Recently, Co-SiO2-N-doped porous C was prepared by heating at 800 °C under N2 Co@ZIF-67@SiO2 microtubes, and this nanocomposite catalyzed H2 production from AB at a rate of 8.4 mol min−1 mol(Co)−1 with an activation energy of 36.1 kJ mol−1 and at least 10-time reusability.117 The maximum turnover frequency (TOF) of 90.1 min−1 was achieved with CoNCs@PCC-2a by Zhou,118 which was an excellent result for non-noble metal catalysts. Co−Zn@ZIF-67 was heated at 800 °C yielding a Co−N-doped microporous C that catalyzed ammonia borane hydrolysis with a turnover
frequency of 7.6 mol H2 mol Co min −1 and Ea = 44.9 kJ mol−1.120
Several bimetallic catalysts on MOFs have been synthesized to minimize and optimize the use of noble metals.121−128
Enhanced catalytic activities compared to those of monometallic counterparts were found in these bimetallic catalysts, mainly thanks to the strong bimetallic synergistic effects between the two metals and with the MOF host. Ni0.66Co0.19P0.15/OPC-300 synthesized by Xu’s group by calcination of ZIF-67 at 300 °C exhibited good catalytic activity for AB hydrolysis. This catalyst benefited from the synergy between two metals, P and oxygen-doped porous carbon.121 In the presence of 0.4 M NaOH, the TOF value increased to 95.24 molH2 molcat
−1 min−1 at 298 K. Ni2Pt@ZiF8 was shown to achieve a TOF of 600 mol H2·molcatal −1 min−1 under ambient conditions, which was around 87 times higher than the TOF of the noble metal-only catalyst Pt@ZIF-8, and gave much better results than other transition metal bimetallic catalysts.122 ZIF-8 in this catalyst appears extremely selective for AB hydrolysis compared to other supports (Figure 3). Recent results showed that cleavage of the O−H bond in
H2O was found to be the rate-determining step in this reaction, as revealed by kinetic isotope effects using D2O. NaOH had a negative influence on the PtNP catalyst, probably due to the occupation of the surface coordination site by OH− inhibiting the surface activity of PtNPs. This was in contrast with the positive influence on other late transition-metal catalysts.53,120−122
Hydrous hydrazine (H2NNH2·H2O), with an hydrogen content of 8.0 wt %, has been shown to be a promising hydrogen carrier. Care must be exercised, however, because explosion is a dangerous hazard of hydrazine, in particular in the presence of a metal catalyst. Hydrazine selectively decomposes to hydrogen and nitrogen at rt in the presence of catalysts in two ways according to complete decomposition (eq 3) or incomplete decomposition (eq 4):130,131
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
F
H NNH 2H (g) N (g) H 95.4 kJ mol2 2 2 2 1→ + Δ = − − (3)
H3H NNH 4NH (g) N (g) 157 kJ mol2 2 3 2 1→ + Δ = − −
(4)
These two decomposition reactions depend on the nature of the catalysts and reaction conditions. It is very important to explore highly efficient catalysts over the complete decomposition of hydrous hydrazine in order to obtain a high efficiency of hydrogen generation. Recently, various bimetallic NPs immobilized by functionalized MOFs have been synthesized for selective decomposition of H2NNH2·H2O to generate H2. Ni0.8Pt0.2/MIL-101-NH2 synthesized by Su and Gu et al. exhibited 100% of H2 selectivity for the dehydrogenation of hydrous hydrazine.132 A high TOF value of 137 h−1 at 298 K was achieved, which was assigned to the electronic state of active NiPt NPs, the interaction strength between hydrous hydrazine molecule and the electron-donating NH2 group in the MOF supports. The switch to Earth-abundant catalysts is more and more desired. Hydrazine borane, N2H4BH3, also is a new sophisticated precursor of choice for catalytic deshydrogenation. The bimetallic Ni and Pt NPs in Ni0.9Pt0.1/MIL101_A synthesized by Lu et al. exhibited outstanding activity for complete H2 evolution from dehydrogenation of both N2H4·H2O (TOF value of 140 molH2·mol(Ni+Pt)
−1 h−1 at 303 K) and N2H4BH3 (TOF value of 400 molH2·mol(Ni+Pt)
−1 h−1 at 303 K), and the catalyst displayed excellent reusability for 20 cycles of reactions.133 The catalytic activity of Ni0.9Pt0.1/MIL101_A for H2 evolution from N2H4BH3 is a little higher than from N2H4·H2O, probably due to the quick hydrolysis of the BH3 group of N2H4BH3. Soon afterward, the same group synthesized another bimetallic catalyst, Rh0.8Ni0.2/MIL-101, that showed excellent catalytic performance for the dehydrogenation of N2H4BH3 and N2H4·H2O with 100% conversion and hydrogen selectivity and high total turnover frequencies (TOF) up to 1200 and 428.6 molH2·mol(Rh+Ni)
−1 h−1, respectively, higher than other Rh-based catalysts.134 The noble-metal-free catalyst Ni0.5Fe0.5−CeOx/MIL-101, prepared by liquid impregnation of MIL-101, showed full selective conversion with excellent hydrogen generation activity (351.3 h−1).135
Formic acid (FA, HCOOH, pKa = 3.75) is a safe colorless liquid with a high hydrogen content (4.4 wt %) that is industrially obtained by methyl formate hydrolysis. It has been regarded as a potential carrier for the production and storage of hydrogen for already half a century.136−138 Hydrogen can be liberated from FA through a dehydrogenation reaction (eq 5):
HCOOH CO H2 2→ + (5)
However, FA can be decomposed in another way, which produces CO (eq 6).
HCOOH CO H O2→ + (6)
In order to selectively obtain H2, avoid the unwelcoming side reaction, metal NPs supported on various MOFs (such as NH2-MIL-125, MIL-100(Fe), ZIF-8, and UiO-66) for the dehydrogenation of FA have been widely investigated.137 AuPd@MIL-101-NH2 synthesized by Gu and Su et al., catalyzed dehydrogenation of FA with 100% of H2 selectivity and high activity, and an initial TOF value of 526 h−1 was obtained at 298 K.139 The electron-donating NH2 groups in MIL-101 frameworks enhanced the catalytic activity. Another bimetallic catalyst, PdAg@ZrO2/C/rGO (Figure 4), from the calcination of UiO-66-GO, was reported by Xu et al. and exhibited excellent activity for the dehydrogenation of FA with a TOF value of 4500 h−1 at 333 K.140 In such a strategy, homogeneous coverage of the GO surface with MOFs ensures uniform dispersion of the metal oxide/porous carbon on reduced GO, and the NP electronic structure is favorably modified by the metal oxide toward catalysis. The released gas mixture was only a mixture of CO2 and H2. The introduction of ZrO2 benefited the formation of the electron-rich PdAg surface via electron transfer and thereby improved the catalytic performance for FA dehydrogenation. The catalyst Cr0.4Pd0.6/ MIL-101-NH2 reported by Wang and Zhao and synthesized by impregnation followed by reduction of the metal cationic precursor showed an excellent ZrO2@C activity with an initial TOF value of 2009 molH2 molPd −1 h−1 at 323 K.141
There is an increasing number of reports concerning catalysis of hydrogen generation catalyzed by nanomaterials resulting from thermolysis of NP@MOF nanomaterials. For instance, Xue and Wang’s group reported the formation of ZrO2@C upon pyrolysis of a UiO-66 precursor. Decom-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
G
position of FA using this heterogeneous catalyst Pd/ZrO2@C was achieved at 60 °C at a TOF of 8588 h−1, with 100% selectivity in H2.
142 In another example, a nanosuper tetragonal ZrO2-embedded carbon synthesized by calcinating a Zr-MOF served as an excellent support for PdAg NPs in the catalyst PdAg@ZrO2/C; the latter exhibited an excellent activity (TOF: 9206 h−1) for the decomposition of FA at 50 °C.143

sections.heading: 2.2. Reduction
sections.text:
Numerous catalysts based on MOFs have been employed for reduction reactions, such as the hydrogenation of compounds with unsaturated carbon bonds and the hydrogenation of nitro compounds, aldehydes, CO2, CO, and Cr(VI). 144,145
2.2.1. Hydrogenation of Unsaturated Hydrocarbons. The hydrogenation of alkenes and alkynes is one of the main reactions in chemical industry and organic synthesis.146 Pd catalysts are largely used and are among the most effective catalysts for hydrogenation of multiple carbon−carbon bonds.147 Heterogeneous catalysts involving MOFs are either of the type MNP@MOF in which the MNP is embedded inside the MOF structure or inorganic composite materials resulting from the calcination of the MNP@MOF compounds taken as precatalysts. Pd/F-ZnO@ZIF-8 was synthesized by Zhang et al. using flowerlike ZnO as both support of PdNPs and Zn2+ source of ZIF-8.148 Using this catalyst a conversion of 99.80% for hydrogenation of 1-hexene to 1-hexane was obtained after 10 h. A sub-2 nm bimetallic Pd-containing catalyst, PdZn@ZIF8C, synthesized by Chen and Zhou et al., displayed 80% selectivity in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene.149 The conversion of acetylene was nearly total, but some nanoparticle aggregation appeared, and the catalytic performance of PdZn@ZIF-8C then decreased. Cai et al. designed bimetallic Pd−Ni@MIL-100(Fe) that catalyzed reversible dehydrogenation and hydrogenation of quinolone derivatives.150 Excellent cyclic performance was demonstrated, and there was no significant decrease in catalytic performance after reusing 6 times (Figure 5). The authors believed that the
Lewis acid sites on the MIL-100(Fe) were favorable due to weak electron-donating Pd particles enhancing the catalytic properties of Pd−Ni@MIL-100(Fe). Catalysts resulting from the calcination of MNP@MOF benefit from the synergies between the metal(s), C, and N in microporous C materials. For instance, Pd@CN prepared upon calcination of ZIF-67 by Chen et al., possesses good
catalytic performance (conversion: 95.6%, selectivity: 94.9% after 95 min) and excellent stability (no significant decrease after fourth cycle) for the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone.151 Soon afterward, the same group further synthesized Pd@CND from the calcination of ZIF-67 and DICY.152 Pd@CND exhibited a better conversion (96.1%) and selectivity (94.1%) toward the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone. Indeed it benefited from the introduction of DICY as an additional source of nitrogen. Luo’s group has applied the so-called MOF+ technique for the synthesis of the catalyst Zn-MOF-74@(Pd@Fe2O3) and its use in efficient alkene hydrogenation and selective phenylacetylene semihydrogenation.153 This MOF+ technique consists in the reaction of a Fe(II) or Fe(III) salt with a phenol-containing MOF at high temperature, which leads to the formation of Fe2O3 on the MOF surface. Besides Pd, catalysts with some other metal NPs in MOFs also work well. Lin et al. reported that the Ti8(μ2-O)8(μ2-OH)4 node of the catalyst support TiBDC MIL-125 offers a single-site model of TiO2.
154 CoIIhydride supported by TiIII in Ti-BDC MIL-125 appeared as the catalytically active species for benzene hydrogenation with a TOF value of 7017 h−1 with 0.005 mol % Ti8-BDC-CoCl for the hydrogenation of benzene (Figure 6). Ti8-BDC-CoCl also showed good catalytic performances for the hydrogenation of substituted benzenes and was promising for the size-selective hydrogenation of arenes because of the size exclusion effect of MOF catalysts. Yamashita et al. reported pyrolysis of Ni-MOF-74 at 300 °C and obtained a NiNP-carbon/Ni-MOF-74 core−shell nanomaterial.155 The resulting Ni-MOF-74−300 exhibited high catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of 1-octene (conversion: 97% after 0.5 h), due to the highly dispersed and small NiNP core. This catalyst also showed size selectivity that benefited from the carbonaceous shell. The catalysts RhCoNi@ZIF-67(Co) and RhCoNi@MOF-74(Ni) were synthesized by Kuang et al. using RhCoNi alloys as selfsacrificing templates and HnIM and DOT as etchant and coordination reagent, respectively (Figure 7).156 These two RhCoNi@MOF catalysts displayed various size selectivities for the hydrogenation of alkene because of the difference of the aperture sizes in the two MOF shells. For example, the conversion of hexene was close to 100%, but the conversion of cyclohexene was only 10% with RhCoNi@ZIF-67(Co) as hydrogenation catalyst, because the shortest size of 1-hexane (3.0 Å) is smaller, whereas the shortest size of cyclohexene (4.8 Å) is much larger than the aperture size of ZIF-67 (3.4 Å). However, lack of recycle performance was a major weakness of these two catalysts.
2.2.2. Reduction of Nitroarenes. Catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes to the corresponding aniline products is of great importance in particular for detoxification, organic synthesis, access to pharmaceuticals, and production of dyes with recent emphasis on the Earth-abundant first-raw transition-metal-containing nanocatalysts.157−162,45−48 Since the middle of the 19th century, the reduction of nitrobenzene to the aniline dye has been very popular, and in the 20th century, it has been extended to a large number of derivatives that are industrially produced by high-temperature heterogeneously catalyzed hydrogenation.163 Selectivity of the nitro reduction in halogeno-substituted nitroarene is especially crucial because of the easy hydrogenolysis of the iodo substituent in the iodo derivatives that are useful in further coupling reactions. This selectivity problem has been solved in
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
H
the mid-2000s by Corma’s and Qiu’s groups using oxidesupported nanogold and nanosilver catalysts, respectively.164,165
The MOF-based catalysts have recently been shown to bring about competitive selectivity and efficiency, even with earthabundant metal-based catalysts. Zhang’s group reported the MOF catalyst Cu-BTC@Fe3O4 (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) for nitroarene reduction by NaBH4 to anilines in aqueous medium under mild conditions and catalyst separation with an external permanent magnet allowing six-time recycling.166 Gascon et al. synthesized Co@mesoNC with dispersed Co-Nx sites by carbonization of a bimetallic Zn/Co ZIF precursor.167,168 Co@mesoNC shows good catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene and excellent chemoselectivity in hydrogenation of substituted nitroarenes; it selectively reduced the nitro group without affecting double bonds and other substituents such as halogen, −OCH3, and −COCH3. Upon recycling, the nitrobenzene hydrogenation catalyst Co@mesoNC, the conversion of nitrobenzene decreased to 51% after the fourth run, which was mainly ascribed to fouling by deposits in the catalyst pores. Another Co-based catalyst, Co2P/CNx nanocubes, synthesized from red-phosphorus and ZIF-67 by Queen et al., displayed excellent catalytic properties for the selective hydrogenation of nitroarenes.169 Loss of catalytic activity was observed after 3 runs in the recycling experiment, owing to cobalt leaching from
Co2P/CNx. The same group also reported Co3S4/CN hollow nanoboxes prepared from ZIF-67 and possessing good activity and selectivity for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes.170
Noble metal-based catalysts are still used for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. Bimetallic Co:Ag(1:1)@NC, reported by Ma et al., selectively catalyzed the hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes without dehalogenation, and good catalytic activity remained after five reaction cycles.171 Pd/NH2-UiO-66 synthesized by Ahn et al. was effective in nitrobenzene hydrogenation (conversion, 98%; selectivity, 99%), and the catalyst was used up to 4 cycles.172
The reduction of nitrophenols in aqueous solution, in particular 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), is a standard in nanoparticle catalysis that has encountered considerable success.173−189 This is due to the toxicities of nitrophenols and to the kinetics that are easily followed by the decrease of the 4-NP band at 400 nm.173 The NP-catalyzed reaction proceeds best with Au and Pd NPs, and its kinetics has been shown by Ballauff’s group to proceed according to a Langmuir−Hinshelwood model according to which the rearrangement of the substrate (nitrophenol and reductant) is the rate-determining step that proceeds more slowly than reversible migration of substrates to the nanoparticle surface.174,175 The reductant is most of the time NaBH4, but other reductants such as hydrogen, hydrazine hydrate, and formic acid have also been used.176,177 Cu2O@ ZIF-8 synthesized by Ma and Cheng et al. exhibited excellent activity (rate constant: 0.28 min−1) and good recycle performance (rate constant: 0.22 min−1 for the fifth cycle) for the hydrogenation of 4-nitrophenol,178 indicating that the Cu2O core was well protected by the ZIF-8 shell. Karahan et al. reported the synthesis of Cu-3(btc)2 and CuIm2 MOFs and their annealing yielding the nanoporous nanomaterials Cu/ Cu2O@C and Cu@N−C that catalyzed the reduction of various aromatic nitro derivatives to aromatic amines.179 The reactions were followed by UV−vis spectroscopy, and the catalyst Cu/Cu2O@C performed better than Cu@N−C. Cu@ C and Zn@C synthesized by Qiu and Zhang et al. derived from Cu-MOF and Zn-MOF upon pyrolysis displayed good catalytic activity for 4-NP reduction (rate constant: 19.5 × 10−3 s−1 for Cu@C, 9.86 × 10−3 s−1 for Zn@C), without significant activity decrease after 8 reaction cycles.180 MDNM(75Zn25Ni), prepared from MOF-74 by Jhung et al., achieved a TOF value of 2239 min−1 for 4-NP reduction (based on Ni).181
Guo and Zhang et al. synthesized the film Pd/UiO-66-NH2 in order to catalyze 4-NP reduction, and a conversion of nearly 100% was achieved in a short time. Almost no activity decrease
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
I
was observed during the 100 h of continuous reaction.182 Bian et al. reported the core−shell-structured catalyst Fe3O4@PDAPd@[Cu3(btc)2] that contained a core of Fe3O4 NPs@PDA, a layer of Pd NPs, and a shell of Cu-MOF (Figure 8).183 This catalyst provided a rate constant of 0.72 min−1 for 4-NP reduction and was reused 8 times.
Pt/NPC-900 and Ni/NPC-900 synthesized from HKUST-1 (Cu-MOF) by Li and Zhang et al. were reported to catalyze the hydrogenation of nitrophenols.186 Similar reaction rates for 2/3/4-NP hydrogenations were observed with Ni/NPC-900, whereas Pt/NPC-900 displayed different selectivities toward these reactions. The difference was suggested to originate from the different distributions of Ni and Pt species in the NPC support. Good performances were obtained with 2D MOFs. Upon using ZIF-67 as precursor, 2-D porous Ni3N-Co3N was prepared by Fu et al. upon pyrolysis, and the conversion of 4-NP with Ni3N-Co3N remained at 80% after 10 runs. 187 Another 2D catalyst, Au-1@NMOF-Ni, synthesized by Wen and Lu et al., is an ultrasmall Au NP (∼1 nm) incorporated into a 2D NMOF-Ni nanosheet (Figure 9), and a rate constant
of 0.404 min−1 was determined.188 Au-1@NMOF-Ni was used more than 10 cycles without significant activity reduction because the confined cavities of MOF inhibited aggregation and migration of Au NPs. The catalysts Au25(SG)18@ZIF-8 and Au25(SG)18/ZIF-8, reported by Shi et al., were synthesized by encapsulating Au25(SG)18 into ZIF-8 and upon impregnating Au25(SG)18 onto the surface of ZIF-8, respectively (Figure 10).189 The reduction of 4-NP was achieved within 12 min with the catalyst Au25(SG)18/ZIF-8, while it needed more than 15 h with the catalyst Au25(SG)18@ZIF-8. This remarkable contrast demonstrated the different distribution of Au clusters in ZIF-8 and showed that the Au clusters on the surface of ZIF-8 are more accessible for 4-NP than the encapsulated Au clusters, which made Au25(SG)18/ZIF-8 more favorable than Au25(SG)18@ZIF-8 to complete the substrate reduction. In sum, a significant pace has recently been accomplished by
the crucial selective reduction of nitro derivatives using NaBH4 as a convenient reductant to amines, in particular with Earthabundant MNP-MOF- or MNP-MOF-derived catalysts. It would be useful to develop the use of other simpler and cheaper reductants that could be extended to industrial production such as H2 itself, other hydrogen sources such as formic acid, hydrazine hydrate, and transfer hydrogenation systems, but all of them also present some specific drawbacks.
2.2.3. Hydrogenation of Aldehydes. Due to a huge market of pharmaceutics, flavoring, and perfumes, there is a large demand of unsaturated alcohols that is not fulfilled by natural resource.190 Therefore, selectivity is a key issue in the hydrogenation of aldehydes. Various metal NP catalysts have been reported for hydrogenation of aldehydes, and among them, selective hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated aldehydes to unsaturated alcohols has attracted much attention.191−193 This process is challenging because the hydrogenation of the CC group to form saturated aldehydes is thermodynamically favorable. With oxide-supported NP catalysts, the NP edges in contact with the oxide surface provide such a selectivity but not the NP surfaces themselves.192 With their layer and channel specificities, MOF templates are ideally suited to enable the desired selectivity.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
J
Zhang and Hu et al. used a new approach in assembling MIL-101, Pt NPs, and FeP-CMPs (conjugated micro- and mesoporous polymers with iron(III) porphyrin) to form MIL101@Pt@FeP-CMP (Figure 11) and used this catalyst for the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde.194 With an outstanding TOF value of 1516.1 h−1, conversion of 97.6% and 97.3% selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol were obtained. The excellent catalytic performance benefits from the Fe sites that activate the CO bonds then improve the selectivity to cinnamyl alcohol during the hydrogenation reaction. Kuang et al. synthesized two Pt-based catalysts, Pt@ZIF-8
with a flexible structure and Pt@ZIF-71 with a rigid structure, for the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde.195 Compared to Pt@ZIF-8, Pt@ZIF-71 shows a higher selectivity for cinnamyl alcohol but a lower conversion for cinnamaldehyde. The results show that both the confinement effect and the flexible structure of MOFs have impact on the catalyst. PtNi2.20NWs@ Ni/Fe4-MOF designed by Huang et al., through combination of porous nanowires (NWs) and MOFs, was used to the catalyze hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde. 99.5% of Cinnamaldehyde conversion, 83.3% of cinnamyl alcohol selectivity,
77.6 h−1 of TOF value, and good recycle performance (no significant change after 5 runs) were achieved.196
In the presence of the catalysts above the main product is cinnamyl alcohol in the selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde, although some results were obtained with different selectivities.197,198 With Pd@MIL-101(Fe) assembled by Bakuru and Kalidindi, the main product is phenylpropyl aldehyde (HCAL in Figure 12, selectivity: 86.4%).198 For the hydrogenation of two other α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds, crotonaldehyde and β-ionone, Pd@MIL-101(Fe) showed preference for hydrogenation of CC over CO. Besides cinnamaldehyde, there are other important hydro-
genation reactions of aldehydes. For example, 2-methoxy-4methyl phenol, the hydrodeoxygenation product of vanillin, is a valuable phenol compound in pharmaceutical industries.199−201 El-Shall’s group reported Pd/PRGO/Ce-MOF that catalyzed the complete hydrogenation of vanillin (conversion: 100%) to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (selectivity: 100%).201 The reaction benefitted from the well-dispersed Pd NPs and the acidic active sites in PRGO (partially reduced graphene oxide). However, after 4 cycles of reuse, the
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
K
selectivity of 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol decreased to 50% because residual reactants accumulated on the catalyst surface. Pd@NH2-UiO-66, synthesized by Zhang and Chen et al., displayed a high activity, selectivity, and stability (reused for 8 times) for hydrogenation of 2,3,5-trimethylbenzoquinone to 2,3,5-trimethylhydroquinone (an important vitamin E intermediate).202 Theoretical calculations suggested that the good catalytic properties of Pd@NH2-UiO-66 were due to the amine groups in MOFs facilitating the adsorption of 2,3,5- trimethylbenzoquinone and cooperating with the Pd NPs. 2.2.4. Hydrogenation of CO2. The increased amount of CO2 in the atmosphere that mainly came from the combustion of fossil fuel is well-known to have a significant impact on climate changes. Consequently chemical processes involving catalyzed CO2 conversion to commodity products are essential in green chemistry.203 MOFs are able to encapsulate and store large amounts of CO2, but catalyzed CO2 transformation has long been a difficult challenge. Numerous results have recently been obtained to undermine the negative influence of CO2 through fixation and conversion of CO2. 204−207 These
reactions should be made more selective using MOF-based and MOF-derived catalysts, and ongoing efforts are encouraging. This section focuses on recent progress in the chemical reduction of CO2 using MOF nanocatalysts. Other approaches to CO2 conversion will be discussed later in this review. Hydrogenation of CO2 to CO, known as the reverse water− gas shift (RWGS) reaction, is a key chemical process reducing CO2 to generate CO for further conversions. Ni/ZIF-8-C, synthesized by the group of Li and Wang, shows high activity for selective hydrogenation of CO2 to CO (conversion: 43.81%, selectivity: 97.37%) in RWGS.208 Density functional theory (DFT) results indicated that the CO product resulted from the direct cleavage of a C−O bond of CO2 and the high selectivity was due to the weak adsorption of CO on the Ni/ ZIF-8-C surface. A bimetallic catalyst for RWGS, Cu/Zn@Csubmm, synthesized by Wang et al. using the catalyst Cu-BTC MOF (HKUST-1) led to a CO2 conversion of 5.0% and CO selectivity of 100%.209 Synergistic effects between Cu and Zn were shown by comparison with the monometallic Cu catalyst. Xu et al. assembled the noble-metal-based nanomaterial Pt/ Au@Pd@UIO-66 and used this catalyst for the hydrogenation of CO2 through RWGS.
210 In this nanocomposite, bimetallic Au@Pd core−shell in the center was encapsulated by UiO-66, and Pt NPs was loaded onto the surface (Figure 13). As the temperature increased, Pt/Au@Pd@UIO-66 was more effective for CO2 hydrogenation (conversion: 35.3% at 400 °C); however, the CO selectivity decreased with increasing temperature due to the increased amount of CH4. For selective hydrogenation of CO2 to methane, Xu et al. developed the catalyst Ni@UiO-66 that provided both excellent activity (conversion: 57.6%) and methane selectivity (100%) at a low reaction temperature (300 °C).211 Moreover, Ni@UiO-66 also displayed outstanding stability during 100 h. Another Ni-based catalyst, 20Ni@MIL-101(DSM), synthesized by Lu et al., exhibited high activity (TOF: 1.6 × 10−3 s−1) at 300 °C for CO2 methanation. 212 The good catalytic
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
L
performance was due to the exposed Ni(111) facet of MIL-101 whose potential energy barrier is lower than that of Ni(200) facet for CO2 dissociation, which was confirmed by DFT. CO2 hydrogenation to methanol provides another valuable approach for CO2 fixation. In this reaction, the optimization of the Pd−ZnO interface appears crucial. MOFs, and in particular ZIF-8 based catalysts, were successful to increase selectivity as indicated by several reports. PZ8−400, a bimetallic alloyed Pd−Zn catalyst derived from Pd@ZIF-8 for selective CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, was synthesized by Hong et al.213
Active sites from PdZn alloy NPs formed after H2 reduction along with abundant oxygen defects on ZnO formed after the ZIF-8 decomposition contributed to the high methanol production of 0.65 g cat−1 h−1 (TOF: 972 h−1) at 270 °C. Hong’s group also reported highly selective hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol using the catalyst ZnO@ZIF-8-core−shell-
Pd/ZnO. In this catalyst, the pores allowed optimized contact between Pd and ZnO and a selectivity superior to 67% was obtained at 290 °C.214
Lin and Wang’s group reported selective methanol synthesis upon CO2 hydrogenation using a MOF-derived catalyst of UiO-bpy type. The catalyst was synthesized via a solvothermal reaction between ZrCl4 and 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate (BPYDC) in the presence of HCO2H forming BPYDC-briged Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4 SBUs.
215 The interfaces between Cu/ ZnO and Cu/ZrO2 formed at 250 °C played a decisive role. FeZnK-NC derived from ZIF-8 was synthesized by the
group of Guo and Song for CO2 hydrogenation to hydrocarbons.216 Good activity (CO2 conversion: 34.6%), selectivity (54.1 C-mol %) for value-added hydrocarbons (C2−C42−, C5+), and remarkable stability (126 h) were achieved.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
M
2.2.5. Fischer−Tropsch Synthesis. The conversion of syngas (CO + H2) into hydrocarbons, known as Fischer− Tropsch synthesis (FTS), has received much attention toward the generation of synthetic fuel. This gas-phase reaction proceeds at high temperatures, and MOF-derived heterogeneous catalysts synthesized by pyrolysis of MOFs offer an expected selectivity. The core−shell catalyst Co@C-500, derived from Co-MOF by Zhang et al., demonstrated a high catalytic activity in FTS and achieved a CO conversion of 13.7% and C5+ selectivity of 75% (a benefit from the porous carbon shell structure) at 260 °C.217 Gascon et al. synthesized Co@SiO2 that catalyzed FTS by hydrolysis of ZIF-67, furthering pyrolysis and calcination (Figure 14).218 High activity (CO conversion: 15.8%) and C5+ selectivity (90.5%) were achieved because of the high loading, optimal size, and high reducibility of Co in Co@SiO2. Ni/ZrO2, derived from Ni/UiO-66, synthesized by Dong et al., was used for the hydrogenation of CO to methane.219 The CO concentration was reduced to 1 ppm, and the CH4 concentration was around 1% (selectivity: ∼100%) at 240 °C for 120 h, showing the good catalytic performance and stability of Ni/ZrO2. 2.2.6. Transfer Hydrogenation. Transfer hydrogenation
is an important procedure allowing the replacement of H2 by a hydrogen-rich compound for hydrogenation. Yamashita et al. developed a sulfonic acid-functionalized UiO-66 catalyst (Figure 15), UiO-66-S60, for catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of levulinic acid and its esters to γ-valerolactone (GVL).220 Outstanding activity was observed (conversion: 98%, GVL yield: 80%) after 9 h at 140 °C, and the catalyst was successfully recycled 4 times, thanks to the Lewis-basic Zr clusters that catalyzed the CTH and the Brönsted-acidic −SO3H group that promoted the dealcoholization step.
Using a similar strategy, Zhang et al. synthesized MIL101(Cr)-SO3H, by employing MIL-101 (Lewis acid sites) and −SO3H (Brønsted acid sites).221 This catalyst was applied for transfer hydrogenation of a range of imines to amines, and good yields were achieved after 12 h at 60 °C. This catalyst MIL-101(Cr)-SO3H maintained its activity after five-time recycling with little loss. For reductive amination of aldehydes and ketones, Jagadeesh and Beller’s group synthesized Co-DABCO-TPA@C-800 (Figure 16) by reaction in DMF at 150 °C between cobalt nitrate and the linkers 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) and terephthalic acid (TPA) followed by immobilization on commercial Vulcan XC 72R carbon powder and pyrolysis at 800 °C.222 This nanomaterial catalyzed the synthesis of more than 140 amines by reductive amination of aldehydes and ketones, N-alkylation to obtain secondary and tertiary amines, and synthesis of N-methylamines. The catalyst was reused 6 times without significant activity reduction.
2.2.7. Reduction of Other Inorganic and Organic Compounds. A catalyst based on MIL-101, Pd@MIL-101, was synthesized by the group of Shi and Cui and further modified by ethanol and 1-dodecanethiol (C12T) to form PdEtOH@MIL-101 and Pd-C12T@MIL-101.223 Concerning catalytic nitrite reduction, Pd-EtOH@MIL-101 showed much lower selectivity (0.31%) for the undesired ammonia byproduct than Pd-C12T@MIL-101 (10.18%). The difference was assigned to the interfacial electronic effects. The electron density of Pd increased upon EtOH modification that favored the reduction of nitrite activation energy, whereas the electron density of Pd decreased upon C12T modification. Ru/Zn-MOF with subnanometer Ru NPs (0.8 nm) was prepared by Han et al. and applied to the selective hydrogenation of diphenyl sulfoxide.224 Ru/Zn-MOF achieved a conversion higher than 99%, 98% yield for diphenyl sulfide
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
N
with a TOF value of 207.6 h−1 at 95 °C. This catalyst was more effective than other Ru-based catalysts with larger Ru NPs. The reusability was checked, and no change in activity was observed after 5 runs. Cu@C-550, derived from HKUST-1 (Co-MOF), was synthesized by Song et al. and used for the reduction of Cr(VI) and pendimethalin.225 The reaction was complete within 15 and 4 min, respectively. In a previous work by the group of Liu and Yu, Pd@ZIF-67 showed a superior performance in the catalytic reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) that was complete within 5 min, and Pd@ZIF-67 was recycled 10 times (Figure 17).226
Phan’s group synthesized Co-ZIF-67, and this heterogeneous catalyst was utilized for the cascade redox condensation of 2-nitroaniline with benzylamine producing 2-phenylbenzimidazole in 97% yield after 1 d in DMSO at 140 °C without added oxidant or reducing agent.227 Benzimidazoles are largely utilized bioactive derivatives in medicinal and agrochemical areas, and therefore this simple heterogeneous process that does not require additives is of great value.228
Pd/MIL-53(Al)-P, synthesized by Fang’s group, catalyzed the hydrodeoxygenation of fructose using polymethylhydrosiloxane (PMHS) to DMF with 99% conversion and 95% yield after 75 min at 110 °C in n-butanol, and the catalyst was recycled 5 times.229
2.2.8. MOF-Derived Single-Atom Metal Catalysts for Reduction Reactions. Very few reports have concerned the synthesis of MOF-derived single-metal-atom catalysts.230−233 Li’s group reported selective hydrogenation of the nitrogencontaining ring of quinoline using UiO-66-NH2-derived single Ru sites as chemoselective catalysts.233 This amino group of the terephthalic acid MOF linkers acted as the Lewis base stabilizing RuCl3, which allowed confining the single Ru atom into the MOF pores. The MOF precursor nanomaterial was pyrolyzed at 700 °C, and the UiO-66 skeleton transferred in situ into ZrO2- and Ru-decorated porous carbon (Figure 18). Related strategies were used by Li’s group to synthesize at high temperatures, via nitrogen ligand−metal stabilization, other single-atom porous catalysts from nanoparticles or bulk metal for reduction reactions.234,235

sections.heading: 2.3. Oxidation
sections.text:
Selective oxidation of organic compounds is critical in chemistry and industry, especially because mechanisms are
most often difficult to elucidate and therefore processes difficult to optimize. The development of catalysts for oxidation reactions has been pursued for a long time, and given the selectivity offered by MOF supports, huge efforts are now dedicated to develop selective and efficient MOF-based catalysts for oxidation reactions. Recent work has mostly focused on low-cost, highly efficient and environmentally friendly catalysts toward selective oxidation of unsaturated hydrocarbons, alcohols, and CO.236−239 The oxidation of hydrocarbons and olefin is usually catalyzed in the liquid phase by MOF-based catalysts, although a few MOF-derived catalysts have started to appear. On the other hand, more and more efficient MOF-derived catalysts resulting from calcination have recently appeared for gas-phase CO oxidation.
2.3.1. Oxidation of Olefins. Oxidation of olefins plays a key role to introduce and modify functional groups in organic synthesis, and therefore reports on olefin oxidation using MOF-based catalysts have involved various reaction types using t-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), H2O2, and O2 as oxidants.240 Early studies around 2010 examined inter alia polyoxometallate@MIL-101 for aerobic allylic oxidation and hydrogen peroxide for epoxidation.241 Recently, more sophisticated MOF catalysts have been designed. Using TBHP as oxidant, Fan et al. fabricated a multicomponent MOF nanomaterial Zn1Co1-ZIF for the oxidation of styrene.242 Good conversion (99%) and high selectivity for styrene oxide (70%) were achieved with a Zn1Co1-ZIF catalyst. Han et al. synthesized Au/Zn-MOF possessing subnanometer (0.8 nm) Au NPs.224 In the presence of O2, Au/Zn-MOF showed a high activity (conversion: 82%) and selectivity of 2-cyclohexene-1-one (98%) toward the oxidation of cyclohexene at 100 °C after 8h. It was demonstrated that the very small NP size was crucial to improve the performance of similar catalysts with larger AuNPs. CuLuMOF was synthesized by Spodine’s group and tested as olefin oxidation catalyst.243 A conversion of 88% was obtained for styrene oxidation using TBHP, and the main product was phenylacetaldehyde (selectivity: 43%). The main oxidation product for cyclohexane oxidation was cyclohexanone, and a higher activity (conversion: 95%, selectivity: 60%) was achieved upon changing the oxidant to O2. Tsung and Nguyen’s group astutely designed a bifunctional catalyst Pd@UiO-66-(sal)Mo, and Pd NPs were encapsulated therein.244 MoVI(sal) (sal = salicylaldimine) moieties were
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
O
modified on the surface of UiO-66-NH2 MOF. In this way, the encapsulated Pd NPs were in contact with H2 and O2 to generate H2O2, while the large alkene substrates were prevented by the MOF to contact the encapsulated Pd NPs. The alkene was then oxidized by the (sal)Mo moieties using the freshly generated H2O2 (Figure 19). In sum, Pd@UiO-66(sal)Mo has been successfully used to catalyze the tandem reaction for H2O2 generation and alkene selective oxidation by generated H2O2.
Gao and Wang’s group synthesized Cu-CuFe2O4@HKUST1 that provided high activity (conversion: 99%) and selectivity of fluorenone formation (99%) from fluorene oxidation under O2 at 60 °C.
245 The good catalytic performance comes from the active sites on CuFe2O4 and the absorption of O2 by the MOF. Furthermore, the magnetic catalyst was easily separated and reused 10 times upon recycling. These examples show that suitable catalyst engineering provide excellent results in terms of selectivity and performance, in particular, when the multiple oxidation states of the metal catalyst of the MOF provides the possibility of oxo transfer from the substrate to the olefin product via readily generated metal-oxo intermediates. This area is thus promising. 2.3.2. Oxidation of Alcohols. The selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehyde, for example, oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde is a well-known organic reaction that is useful, in particular, for pharmaceutical industry.246,247 Numerous catalysts have been searched, and the trend consists in finding environmentally friendly ways, such as processing at rt in H2O, ideally using O2 from air as the oxidant. 248
MDNM(75Zn25Mn) synthesized from MOF-74 by Jhung et al. achieved a TOF value of 1570 min−1 (based on Mn) for oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde.181 A good recyclability was observed after 4 runs of reaction. Another Mn-catalyst, Mn3O4/MIL-101(15), synthesized by Zhan and Lu et al., led to a conversion of 38.7% and a selectivity for benzaldehyde of 99% after 4 h in oxidation of benzyl alcohol with O2.
249 The reaction was performed at 100 °C in toluene, without base. The catalyst was repeatedly recycled 10 times with an unchanged catalytic activity. CuPd-HKUST-1 synthesized by Muhler et al. showed a conversion of 71% and selectivity of benzaldehyde of 92% for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol with O2 at 423 K after 7 h in toluene.250 Liu’s group synthesized PdNP@MIL-101 in which
the Pd NPs were encapsulated in the MOF by capillary impregnation. The catalyst PdNP@MIL-101 showed a high catalytic activity for oxidation of alcohol by O2 and aldimine condensation in one-pot reactions at 353 K in toluene with K2CO3.
251 High yield of benzaldehyde (99.9%) and good stability (reuse over five cycles) was achieved after 4 h at 353 K upon using toluene as solvent and K2CO3 as base for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Then in the same pot after the oxidation of 4-methoxybenzylaldehyde, the condensation reaction between 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol and aniline further proceeded to give N-(4-methoxybenzylidene)aniline with 99.0% conversion and 99.9% selectivity. Pt@NH2-MONFs synthesized by Huang et al., showed an excellent activity (conversion: near 100%) for oxidation of benzyl alcohol with K2CO3 after 1.5 h. This was one of the best results of Pt catalysts in the green oxidation of alcohol (solvent: H2O, oxidant: air, at rt), and the catalyst was reused over 10 times without significant catalytic activity loss.252 The good catalytic performance was related to the hierarchically porous structure and the interactions between the −NH2 groups and PtNPs. The Tai group showed that the activities of core−shell ZIF8-encapsulated Au0−Ag0 NP and AuAg cluster catalysts toward benzylic alcohol oxidation (TOFs, 130 °C, 1 h, THF, 8 bar O2) were in the order of Ag@Au/ZIF-8 (28 h
−1) > AuAg cluster/ZIF-8 (25 h−1) > Au@Ag/ZIF-8 (20 h−1) with aldehyde selectivities higher for both core−shell structures (53%) than for the cluster structure (35%).253
Zhan et al. used sacrificial Cu2O nanocrystals as a copper source for the fabrication of HKUST-1, Cu2O@HKUST-1, and Cu2O@HKUST-1@Au.
254 Galvanic reaction between encapsulated CuI from Cu2O@HKUST-1 and Au
III from HAuCl4 located outside the MOF to form Cu2O@HKUST1@Au resulted from the diffusion of Cu2O through the MOF micropores to the MOF surface. The nanomaterial Cu2O@ HKUST-1@Au successfully catalyzed the fully selective oxidation of aromatic and aliphatic alcohols to aldehydes. Although most of the above-mentioned catalysts are until now based on functional MOFs, a few MOF-derived catalysts obtained after calcination have appeared. Pd/ZDC@mesoSiO2, derived from ZIF-8 developed by Wang et al. exhibited high catalytic activity (conversion: 99%, selectivity: 99%) for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. The reaction was conducted at 100 °C for 6 h under base-free conditions (oxidant, air; solvent, toluene). An excellent recyclability was also obtained (reused 8 times), benefiting from the SiO2 shell that prevented Pd leaching.255 Another green catalyst, based on non-noble metal, yolk−shell Co@C−N, was assembled by Shen and Li’s group for the oxidation of alcohols.256 CoNPs were localized in the core of Co@C−N, covered by ZIF-67derived nanosheets, and then enfolded by a ZIF-8-derived C− N shell (Figure 20). Synergistic effects between the CoNPs and the covering nanosheets were demonstrated. The outer layer C−N shell prevents CoNP leaching and provides a space for alcohol oxidation. These properties endow Co@C−N an excellent catalytic activity and stability in oxidation of alcohols. More than 99% conversion was achieved in mild and environmentally friendly conditions (no base, water, or air as oxidant). An elegant strategy was recently reported by Li’s group for selective functional alcohol oxidation to aldehyde using a nanomaterial catalysts resulting from the pyrolysis of ZIF-8encapsulated [Ru3(CO)12] cluster.
257 The carbonyl-free Ru3 cluster was preserved and stabilized by the CN atoms resulting
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
P
from pyrolysis, and full conversion and selectivity were obtained for 2-aminobenzaldehyde from 2-aminobenzyl alcohol. The catalyst TOF (4320 h−1) was 23 times higher than that of small Ru NPs (2.5 nm; TOF = 184 h−1). For the oxidation of other alcohols, Liu et al. synthesized NENU-9HP-1/120 through a gel-like/freeze-drying strategy and used it for the oxidation of alcohols using THBP as oxidant.258 High activity (conversion: 97%) and good stability (after reuse 5 times, conversion: 90%) were achieved for the oxidation of 1-phenylethanol to acetophenone after 7 h in toluene at 100 °C, due to the accessible catalytic sites and the accelerated mass transfer favored by this hierarchically porous material. Zhu et al. synthesized Pd−Ce/Fe−MIL-101-NCH through a neocuproine functional Fe-MIL-101-NH2.
259 With the use of O2 as oxidant, a yield of 55% was obtained in the oxidation of glycerol to 1,3-dihydroxyacetone (DHA) after 6 h in acetonitrile/water at 60 °C.
2.3.3. Oxidation of CO. Carbon monoxide (CO) is a wellknown gas product of vehicle exhaust that is extremely toxic for human and animals and thus causes a serious environmental problem. Its solubility in water is very low, so its oxidation is highly needed for elimination.260 Pt nanomaterials are used in exhaust pipes for CO elimination at high temperatures, which does not solve CO elimination upon starting engines near ambient temperature nor full CO elimination at higher temperatures. Therefore, Haruta’s discovery in 1987 of oxide-supported Au NP catalyzed CO oxidation at temperatures far below 0 °C has been very promising.261,262 Cerium oxide (ceria) supports have shown considerable efficiency inter alia in CO oxidation.263 Another catalyst using noble metal and Ce, UiO-66@Au/CeO2, was synthesized by Puntes et al., through dispersion of core−shell Au/CeO2 to UIO-66.264 Full CO oxidation was achieved at 100 °C, and during the recycling test no loss of activity was observed for 37 h (a slight decrease was observed afterward). Noble metals different from gold such as palladium and
ruthenium have recently been used in MOF-derived catalysts for CO oxidation. El-Shall et al. synthesized a Pd/Ce-MOF catalyst from Ce-BTC-MOF.265 Pd/Ce-MOF stores oxygen both on Ce(III)/Ce(IV) centers and by Pd in the form of palladium oxide, and these oxygen atoms are released during the CO oxidation. Full conversion of CO was achieved by 5 wt % Pd/Ce-MOF at 92 °C, and this catalyst was stable during 8 h of reaction. Other MOFs used for CO oxidation follow. The catalysts
ZIFs(Co/Zn)@M (M = Pd, Pt, or Au) were synthesized by Liu and Li’s group for CO oxidation.266 Catalytic results show that the nanomaterials ZIF-67(Co)@M are better catalysts than ZIF-8(Zn)@M, and ZIFs@Pd is better than ZIFs@Pt/ Au. The best catalyst, ZIF-67(Co)@Pd, achieved full CO conversion at 120 °C because of the electron transfer from ZIF to Pd NPs. A 3D catalyst, Ru/GA-HK, developed by Chen and Lu’s group from HKUST-1 (Figure 21), achieved a simultaneous adsorption and oxidation of CO with a conversion of 19.8%.267
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
Q
Beside active oxide-supported noble-metal CO oxidation catalysts, ceria-supported Earth-abundant metals of the first raw of the transition metals have recently been successfully utilized as components of efficient MOF-derived CO oxidation catalysts. In particular Cu-containing MOF-derived catalysts have attracted much attention. Zhang first applied this type of material to MOFs upon introducing CeIII into the channels of Cu3(BCT)2 followed by pyrolysis.
268 Li’s group recently used CuII@Ce-UiO-66 to synthesize a CuO/CeO2 catalyst that was very efficient and selective (>95% selectivity) for CO oxidation of CO in a H2-rich stream. 269
Several catalysts combining a metal and Ce-MOF were developed by Jia and Zhang et al., who synthesized a series of CuxCe1−xO2 catalysts through CuxCe1−x-BTC MOFs for catalytic oxidation of CO.270 The highest activity (conversion, 85%; selectivity, 94% at 80 °C) was achieved by Cu0.3Ce0.7O2650 with a calcination temperature of 650 °C. This demonstrated that a suitable calcination temperature led to the production of additional CuO clusters and oxygen vacancies, due to enhancement of the interaction between CuO and CeO2. Other Earth-abundant metal-based MOF-derived catalysts
are also efficient, especially with manganese and cobalt. For instance, Wang et al. synthesized, under Ar by pyrolysis of ZIF67 at 600 °C, a CO oxidation catalyst Co/C-600 that was active even at −30 °C, and the conversion of CO did not decrease after 1 day on stream under ambient conditions.271
Zhang et al. reported a Mn2O3 catalyst produced through calcination of Mn-MIL-100 for CO oxidation.272 The calcination temperature had an important effect on the catalyst activity, and the best activity was obtained for Mn2O3-700 (calcined at 700 °C) with a T98 (temperature for 98% conversion of CO) at 240 °C. Later, the same group synthesized a-Mn-250 by calcination of Mn-MIL-100 at 250 °C.273 a-Mn-250 showed a high catalytic activity toward CO oxidation (T98 at 300 °C). Interestingly, a-Mn-250 was transformed into Mn3O4 during the recycling test at low temperature, and the catalytic performance improved (T98 at 200 °C after 4 runs). When it was treated with CO at high temperature, the catalyst a-Mn-250 was transformed into Mn2O3, and the catalytic performance still improved (T98 at 120 °C). Finally MOF-derived materials only recently appeared most
suitable for the use of Earth-abundant metal instead of expensive noble metals such as gold and platinum for the crucial selective oxidation of CO to CO2.
2.3.4. Oxidation of Sulfur Derivatives. H2S is another highly toxic gas that is produced in industry by natural gas processing and use, coal chemistry, and crude oil desulfurization. The Claus process is used in industry to remove H2S from natural gas, but 3 to 5% H2S is left thereafter. Therefore, removal of sulfur from fossil fuels by developing efficient catalysts for selective, irreversible oxidation of H2S to S [H2S + 1/2O2 → (1/n)Sn + H2O] has long become a priority. Over oxidation to SO2 must be avoided. NH2-MIL-53(Fe) synthesized by Jiang et al. (Figure 22) displayed a high activity for selective oxidation of H2S to S (H2S conversion, selectivity, and yield of S were all around 100%) in the temperature range of 130∼160 °C.274 In the durability test, H2S conversion was kept as 100% for 17 h and then began to decrease. Oxidative desulfurization has long drawn attention from researchers in heterogeneous catalysis because it is of great industrial and environmental importance. MDC-C synthesized from ZIF-8@H2N-MIL-125 by Jhung et al. exhibited a high catalytic activity toward the oxidative desulfurization of dibenzothiophene with H2O2.
275 A high conversion of 99.5%, reaction rate constant of 0.12 min−1, and a low activation energy of 19 KJ mol−1 were obtained after 2 h reaction at 80 °C. Furthermore, the catalyst was reused for 5 cycles.
2.3.5. Oxidative Functionalization. Zhang’s group synthesized Co-ZrO2/N−C from UiO-66-NH2, the metal precursor Co(NO3)2, six H2O, and DABCO using the in situ impregnation method followed by pyrolysis at 800 °C for 3 h under an argon flow. Co-ZrO2/N−C catalyzed the oxidative functionalization with O2 of cyclic amines using 2-aminoarylmethanols to ring-fused quinazolinones. Typically a yield of 80% was obtained for the cross-coupling of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline and 2-aminobenzyl alcohol at 120 °C.276
Zhao et al. synthesized the bimetallic catalysts Au−Pd/ MOF from MOF-253(Al)277 for the oxidative carbonylation of cyclohexanamine with CO.278 Under O2, high catalytic activity (TOF: 2573 h−1) and selectivity (over 98%) were achieved after 20 h at 90 °C in THF (with the optimized Au:Pd molar ratio = 26:74), thanks to the synergy between Au and Pd (Figure 23). However, the stability of Au−Pd NPs became lower after five cycles of reaction.
2.3.6. Toluene Combustion. Jia et al. and Chen’s group reported the synthesis of Pt@M-Cr2O3 by pyrolysis of MIL101-Cr with impregnated Pt NPs for toluene combustion.279 The optimized catalyst was 0.82Pt@M-Cr2O3 exhibiting the T10%, T50%, and T90% of toluene conversion at 120, 140, and 145 °C, respectively. On-stream test displayed that the
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
R
catalytic activity did not remarkably decrease in the water vapor (concentrations: 10 and 20 vol %). Intermediates along the toluene oxidation pathway were suggested to be benzoate and maleic anhydride before decay to CO2 and H2O. 2.4. C−C Bond-Forming Reaction MOF-based catalysts are becoming among the most used catalysts for bond formation reactions including C−C and C− N coupling, cyanosilylation, Diels−Alder reaction, etc.280 BisN-heterocyclic carbenes (NHC) being excellent chelating ligands in homogeneous catalysis, Pd-bis-NHC complexes have been introduced into MOFs for heterogeneous catalysis of various Mizoroki-Heck, Suzuki-Miyaura, and Sonogashira reactions, and this specific field has been reviewed by Han’s group.281 Carbon−hydrogen bond activation for the formation of carbon−carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds has been a popular area in homogeneous catalysis, and extension to MOFbased heterogeneous catalyst has now been reviewed by the Garcia group.282 The reactions involved and analyzed are mostly the Mizoroki-Heck and Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reactions, C−H arylation of benzoxazole, indole, N-methylindole and naphthalene, coupling of coumarin with N,Ndimethylaniline, of N-benzoyl-8-amino-quinoline and morpholine, of quinoxalin-2(1H)-one or ethyl phenyl ketone with morpholine, C−H amination of tetrahydrofuran or cyclohenene, borylation of arenes, and halogenation of cyclohexane and heterocycles. Improved performances of MOF-based catalysts logically result from their porosity, large surface area, site isolation, and immobilization.282
2.4.1. Mizoroki-Heck Reaction. The Mizoroki-Heck reaction, developed by Mizoroki283 and Heck,284 couples a vinyl, aryl, or benzyl halide with an olefin over catalysis by Pd0 (eq 7). It is the best-known C−C coupling reaction because of
its simplicity since it does not necessitate the preliminary synthesis of an intermediate organoelement compound. In addition it tolerates a large number of functional groups and is thus of considerable interest in organic synthesis.285 Molecular Pd catalysts in which the ligands are strongly coordinated such as Pd(acac) with or without PPh3 are most used, but Pd NPs [formed from Pd(acac)] are not very efficient due to aggregation unless they are strongly stabilized against agglomeration.286−288 Therefore, MOF-templated and MOF-
derived catalysts are of great interest in the stabilization of Pd NPs or nanomaterials under reaction conditions requiring heating around 100 °C. The Shaikh group reported the conversion of hexagonal ZIF8 microcrystals to rod- and flower-shaped PdNPs@ZIF-8 with the controlled addition of formic acid. This ZIF-8-supported PdNPs catalyzed Heck coupling of aryl halides with substituted styrenes in excellent yields with high selectivities.289 A Pdbased microporous organic nanotube framework-supported catalyst, Pd@NH2-MONFs, synthesized by Huang’s group, provided yields between 94% and 99% for the Heck reactions of various aryl iodides and methyl acrylate at 90 °C, and the catalyst was recycled over 6 times without significant catalytic activity decrease.252 Dou and Li’s group synthesized several Pd-based MOF-derived catalysts (Pd@Co3O4, Pd@Co3O4/C and Pd@Co/CNT) through pyrolysis of Pd@ZIF-67 to catalyze the Heck reaction (Figure 24). These catalysts all
