achieved high yields (94 to 99%) for the Heck reaction between styrene and iodobenzene at 120 °C for 6 h benefiting from the many active Pd sites in hierarchical pores after pyrolysis. Pd@Co/CNT was reused 5 times without activity loss.290
Dong’s group reported a UiO-67-type MOF that contained a palladium N-heterocyclic bis-carbene dicarboxylate ligand under solvothermal conditions, and this catalyst was active for Heck coupling and intermolecular benzyne−benzynealkene coupling insertion reactions.291 Operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), X-ray powder diffraction, TEM, and 1H NMR have been combined by the Zou and Martin-Matute group to search the mechanism of the Heck reaction with Pd@MOF catalysts. Interestingly, the results show that PdII complexes dominate at the reaction beginning and then progressively form Pd0 nanoclusters containing on average 13 to 20 Pd atoms in later turnovers. The anions Cl− that are produced during the reaction coordinate to the cluster surface causing poisoning. Such understanding allowed increasing the catalyst lifetime.292
2.4.2. Suzuki-Miyaura Reaction. The Suzuki-Miyaura reaction is the most popular cross C−C coupling reaction between a halide compound and an organo-element (here organoboron) derivative because it proceeds under very mild
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
S
conditions.293,294 It couples a vinyl or aryl borane, via boronate, with a vinyl or aryl halide. As in most coupling reactions, a Pd catalyst and base are used, and Pd NP catalysts in quantities as small as ppm or subppm Pd have been shown to be sufficient for quantitative homogeneous reactions.295−297 A general pathway for the Suzuki reaction is shown below (eq 8):
R X R BY NR R R NR H X
(X halogen)
1 2 2 3 catalyst 1 2 3+ + ⎯ →⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯ +
=
+ −   
(8)
The interest of MOFs in these catalysts is that they afford well-defined recyclable heterogeneous catalysts, although they are required in considerably larger amounts than in homogeneous catalysis. In addition, the robustness of MOFbased or MOF-derived catalysts allows addressing the challenging use of Ni-based catalysts instead of Pd-based catalysts. Madrahimov developed Ni-immobilized catalysts by combining a modified MOF (UiO-66(L3)), Ni(COD)2, and PPh3 (Figure 25).298 A yield of 96% and good cyclic performance
(reusable over 7 times) were achieved by this Ni-immobilized MOF for a Suzuki-Miyaura reaction between bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid, by using K2CO3 as the base and CH3CN as the solvent at 65 °C for 12 h with 3 mol % Ni. This catalyst is in fact a classic [Ni0(bpy)(L)(PPh3)] that is heterogenized by linking the MOF to the bipy ligand thanks to a “click” reaction. For the same reaction between bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid, Bian et al. reported a core−shell structured magnetic catalyst Fe3O4@PDA-Pd@[Cu3(btc)2]. The best yield of 97% was obtained at 75 °C after 30 min, by using K2CO3 as the base and EtOH/H2O (v/v = 1:1) as the solvent. The catalyst was reused over 8 times without decrease upon magnetic recovery. The excellent performance was attributed to the strong synergistic effect between Fe3O4@PDA-Pd and [Cu3(btc)2].
183 A magnetic Fe3O4−Pd catalyst, Fe3O4@LaMOF-Schiff base-Pd, synthesized by Sun and Dragutan et al.,
has been used to catalyze the Suzuki-Miyaura reactions of various aryl halides with arylboronic acids.299 Yields of above 99% have been attained for various aryl iodides and bromides at 80 °C after 30 min, by using K2CO3 as the base and ethanol as the solvent. The catalyst was recycled over 12 times without significant yield decrease. The high activity and stability of the catalyst were assigned to the synergistic effect between Pd and the La nodes, and the stability of the Pd moieties was enhanced by the La ions. The Stanley and Huang group synthesized a series of isoreticular mixed-linker MOFs to examine the stereoelectronic substituent effects on the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction.300 The effect of linker substitution of MOF templates on the catalytic activity of encapsulated Pd NPs has been shown to be crucial, and remarkably MOF-Pd NPs and MOF-PdII catalysts generated similar active centers.
2.4.3. A3-Coupling. A3 coupling is a three-component coupling reaction that involves an alkyne, an aldehyde, and an amine, and the reaction will produce propargylamine derivatives in the presence of a catalyst (eq 9).301
Ag-NHC-MOF, developed by Verpoort et al., achieved a yield of 97% at rt after 1h for the A3-coupling reaction between paraformaldehyde, phenylacetylene and diisopropylamine in CH2Cl2.
302 The catalyst was recycled 4 times and further applied in the A3-coupling with other substrates. Core−shell AgNP@IRMOF-3 with average Ag NP size of 5.2 nm and IRMOF-3 of 91.5 nm was synthesized in only 5 min and was shown to be highly active for A3-coupling of amine, aldehyde, and acetylene; the catalyst was recycled 8 times without decrease of activity.303
Zhang et al. synthesized a series of Au/MOF-199 by microwave irradiation in 2 min, and high TOFs value over 700 h−1 were achieved for the A3-coupling of formaldehyde, phenylacetylene, and piperidine in 1,4-dioxane at 120 °C after 5 min.304 This catalyst was reused five times without significant loss of activity. Yang and Jiang reported the comparison between the catalytic performance of Auδ+ and Au0NP in A3coupling stabilized by MIL-101-NH2 via postsynthetic modification,305 and they found that the activity of the Auδ+ catalyst was 11-fold higher than that of AuNP. Liu and Tai’s group reported a postsynthetic modification method in the synthesis of salicylaldehyde-functionalized MOF via nucleophilic addition of salicylaldehyde to the amino group of NH2-MIL-53(Al). Encapsulation of Au
III into this MOF and then reduction of AuIII to encapsulated AuNP allowed catalysis of A3-coupling of various aromatic or aliphatic aldehydes, aromatic alkynes, and piperidine, and the catalyst was recycled four times.306 Au@MIL-101-ED-SA and Au@MIL-101 were synthesized by the same group for A3-coupling catalysis, and Au@MIL-101-ED-SA that contained Au3+/Au0 = 0.9 showed higher catalytic performance than Au@MIL-101 that was synthesized using the impregnation method.307
2.4.4. Knoevenagel Condensation. The Knoevenagel condensation, a powerful reaction in organic synthesis, is a nucleophilic addition of an active methylene compound (with electron withdrawing functional groups Z) with a carbonyl derivative in the presence of a base (eq 10).308
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
T
The use or alkali metal hydroxides and organic bases pose separation and waste problems, however. Therefore, heterogeneous catalysts would, as for other reactions, present ecological advantages to avoid these drawbacks. In particular, MOFs are ideal candidates thanks to their structural flexibility adaptable to specific problems of the reaction. For instance, ZIF MOFs are excellent catalysts because the framework Lewis acid Zn sites activate the carbonyl oxygen atom of the aldehyde or ketone while the active methylene group is deprotonated by the frame imidazole ligand, as shown by Verpoort’s group.309 Thus, the MOF alone can be the catalyst even in the absence of other NPs, but in many MOF catalysts magnetic iron oxide or Pd or other transition metal NPs are introduced in order to facilitate the reaction and/or to allow cascade reactions. Han’s group synthesized a bifunctional MOF, Yb-BDC-NH2, for tandem deacetalization of benzaldehyde dimethyl acetal to benzaldehyde and then Knoevenagel condensation of the generated benzaldehyde with malononitrile at 50 °C for 24 h.310 The yield of the final product, benzylidenemalononitrile, reached 97% thanks to the strong Lewis acidity of the Yb MOF site and small ionic radius. However, the activity of Yb-BDCNH2 decreased in the recycle experiment. Ho and Wang reported the synthesis of magnetic hierarchically porous MOF composites through an interfacial nanoassembly/emulsion polymerization method with ZIF-8, UiO-66, Cr-MIL-101, HKUST-1, and Fe3O4 NPs.
311 Excellent mechanical stability and higher conversion rate for the Knoevenagel reaction were obtained compared to the MOF itself in the case of ZIF-8. In order to develop supports for flow-based applications, Maya’s group designed NP-directed MOF/porous organic polymer monolithic materials. In two steps, these authors prepared macroporous polymer monoliths in which the surface of the pores is protected by a ZIF-8 coating.312 This ZIF-8-coated polymer monolithic was implemented as a microreactor for the catalysis of the Knoevenagel reaction. Zhang and Zhao synthesized 3.1% RuNP/UiO-66 that catalyzed the Knoevenagen reaction. This was attributed to the ZnO2 Lewis acid− base pair of the MOF frame. RuNP/UiO-66 also catalyzed the reduction of nitroarene to amines.313 The Yao and Dong groups grafted poly[2-(diethylamino)ethyl methacrylate] (PDEAEMA) chains onto UiO-66 via a postsynthetic approach forming PDEAEMA-g-UiO-66 NMOF (termed as MOF-3, Figure 26).314 Pd NP-loaded Pd@MOF-3 fabricated via solution impregnation showed high activity in interfacial catalysis of a Knoevenagel condensation-hydrogenation cascade. Huang’s group reported that PdNPs supported on a N-doped porous carbon Cz-MOF-253 resulting from pyrolysis of bipyridyl MOF-253 showed catalyst activity for the Knoevenagel reaction that outperformed other N-containing derived carbons.315 Pd/Cz−MOF-253−800 was also an excellent catalyst of the Knoevenagel condensation-hydrogenation cascade. 2.4.5. Cyanosilylation. The cyanosilylation reaction is an addition reaction between an unsaturated compound and a compound that possesses cyano and silyl groups. Cyanosilylation of carbonyl derivatives allows a practical synthesis of cyanohydrins that are important intermediates in organic synthesis.316 The Mirkhani group treated MIL-101 with Fe3O4, and this composite magnetically recoverable catalyst was
shown to be active via its CrIII nodes in both oxidation and cyanosilylation reactions.317

sections.heading: 2.5. Cycloaddition of CO2
sections.text:
Reactions of CO2 forming valuable chemicals are actively researched because C1 source is cheap and inexhaustible. Cyclisation of propargyl alcohol with CO2 has attracted attention, especially since the alkylidene carbonate heterocycles produced find important applications in pharmaceutical industry and polymers.318 Zhao’s group synthesized a small Cu nanocluster-based MOF {(NH2C2H6)0.75[Cu4I4·L3·In0.75]· DMF·H2O} with L = 5-aminonicotinic acid that catalyzed the cyclization of various propargyl alcohols with CO2 in the absence of solvent (TON = 14400). Synergistic effect between CuI and InIII were responsible for this catalytic CO2 conversion.319
The cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides yields cyclic carbonates that are useful for fine chemicals and plastics.320 Jiang’s group reported N-doped porous carbon-encapsulated ZnO NPs (Figure 27), ZnO@NPC-Ox-700, that catalyzed
CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides at 60 °C for 2 d, under 0.1 MPa CO2 in the presence of TBAB, with 100% selectivity and 98% conversion.321 This catalyst was recycled 10 times. In order to prepare this catalyst, the authors pyrolized ZIF-8 at 700 °C (optimized temperature for catalysis), and the resulting material was oxidized with sodium hypochlorite, which resulted in the formation of ZnO@NPC-Ox-700. This material contained phenol, carboxylic acid, and lactone groups on the porous carbon surface providing synergy for the catalytic activation. Comparatively, ZIF-8 and TBAB only led to 16% conversion. Since TBAB itself gave 14% conversion,
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
U
this shows the lack of activity of ZIF-8, which is taken into account by the lack of active sites, the small ZIF-8 aperture (3.4 A), and low diffusion rates. ZnO in this catalyst is more active than conventional ZnO encapsulated in porous carbon due to the synergies with the functional groups. In comparison, reactions catalyzed by other materials including porous carbons, ZIFs, and MOFs need higher temperature and CO2 pressure than ZnO@NPC-Ox-700. Zhang’s group showed that SnS2 nanosheets were essential as UiO-66 support to inhibit the blockage of the active metal centers by organic linkers for cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide under solvent-free conditions.322 Indeed this catalyst was 11 times more active than the pure UiO-66 catalyst. The group of Sheng and Zhu et al. synthesized the atomically precise nanocluster [Au12Ag32(SR)30] 4−, [Zn2+]2, and then reaction of this nanocluster with the ZIF-8 precursor 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIM) in methanol yielded Au12Ag32(SR)30@ZIF-8 after 1 day at rt.
323 This nanomaterial catalyzed the reaction of CO2 addition with phenylacetylene yielding phenylpropiolate. In the presence of a base (Cs2CO3 or K2CO3), a TON value of 18 000 was obtained after 1 d at 50 °C in DMSO, which exceeded the performance of most reported catalysts, and this catalyst was reused 5 times.

sections.heading: 2.6. Biomass and Biodiesel
sections.text:
Biomass is an important source of primary energy, and its most abundant form is lignocellulose. Lignin, a natural amorphous polymer and one of the main lignocellulosic constituents, is the only large renewable feedstock containing aromatics, but it has not yet been exploited toward fine chemicals.324 Its depolymerization was conducted through cleavage of the βO-4 linkages that comprised nearly half of the lignin linkages. Such cleavages were best conducted by transfer hydrogenation from the numerous alcohol moieties in lignin.325
Biodiesel is a green fuel that involves long-chain fatty acid methyl esters from the transesterification with methanol of triglycerides, and its development is highly desirable in the context of the energy crisis.326 Xie and Wan synthesized a magnetic core−shell catalyst Fe3O4@HKUST-1-ABILs using the layer-by-layer assembly method followed by encapsulation of basic ionic liquids. This green catalyst was efficient for the transesterification of soybean oil in methanol to biodiesel.327 This conversion to biodiesel reached 92.3% within 3 h, and the catalyst that was easily separated using an external magnetic field was recycled 5 times. Given the drawback of standard catalysts including Pd/C and the excellent synergistic properties of bimetallic NPs and porous MOF, Cai’s group synthesized a bimetallic NP-MOF catalyst Pd1Ni4/MIL-100(Fe), prepared by the impregnationreduction method, for β-O-4 cleavage of lignin.328 Upon using H2O as a solvent, high conversion (100%) and good yield (95%) were obtained under argon after 6 h at 130 °C for the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenethanol to acetophenone and phenol through intramolecular hydrogen transfer and C−O bond cleavage, and the catalyst was stable during 5-time recycling. The good catalytic performance was ascribed to the synergistic effect between the bimetallic NPs and the MOF with Lewis-acid activity.

sections.heading: 3. ELECTROCATALYSIS
sections.text:
Recently MOFs have been extensively studied as components of electrode materials for electrocatalysis of the oxygen
reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2), and for Li−air batteries.329,330 The field of MOF-based nanomaterials for electrocatalysis has been reviewed by Zou’s group in 2016 and Zhang’s group in 2018, and designed strategies for energy conversion have been reviewed by Qiao’s group in 2017.331−333 Traditionally Pt has proven to be the ideal electrocatalytic metal, but its high price and scarcity on Earth has promoted research of other nanomaterials. The challenges are to overcome kinetic problems related to multielectron transfer and mass transport. Earth-abundant catalysts are limited by high overpotentials, but new strategies involve the design of bi- or trimetallic core− shell or alloy nanostructures eventually incorporating B, N, or P atoms in these structures or in carbon frameworks. MOFderived nanocomposites have limited electron transport capability because of poor graphitic degree upon pyrolysis, but metal-based NPs encapsulated in porous carbon are promising high-stability materials.334 The pyrolysis of MOFs containing atomically dispersed metal nanoclusters between organic linkers is thus a major method to produce nanostructured M−N−C catalysts of suitable size with uniformly distributed active sites and excellent porosity. During the pyrolysis, the high annealing temperature provides enough Gibb’s free energy for diffusion of ions of different metals to form alloys. At the same time, these metal species catalyze the formation of carbon material from the organic MOF ligands. The metal NPs made in this way are used as efficient electrocatalysts only when they are supported on carbon materials with good conductivity.335
Besides, optimization of the MOF porosity by “iso-reticular expansion” improves mass transport. Metal open sites of MOF such as Fe, Co, and Ni have the useful function of Lewis-acid catalysts often operating in synergy with the guest metal NPs. Several other strategies are therefore developed, such as calcination of MOF-MNP at controlled temperatures yielding MOF-derived carbon-based nanocatalysts and nanocatalyst supports optimizing synergies between inter alia C, N, P, metals, and metal oxides. In this method, the MNP@MOF structure is a sacrified precursor of nanoporous heteroatomdoped carbon-based nanomaterials with high BET surface area and large pore volumes most often performing very efficiently as heterogeneous catalysts, in particular for these electrocatalyzed reactions. In addition, there is increasing evidence that MOFs modified with guest materials show better electrocatalytic performance than without organic guest due to modified electronic structure.32,336,337
In sum, the qualities that are researched for new electrocatalysts obtained by pyrolysis of mono- or polymetallic NPMOF generally include high surface area, porous carbon with retained morphology, a high graphitization degree, hierarchical porosity, and N and/or P dopant moieties. Another promising strategy is that of using single-site catalysts, a quite new, very active, and promising field.23,338 In order to describe the performances of electrocatalysts, several parameters are normally used including the onset potential (Eonset), overpotential at a current density (ηj), Tafel slope (TS), and turnover frequency (TOF).

The production of hydrogen from nonfossil-fuel sources is the key to environmentally safe energy of the close future.

Therefore, hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) with MOFbased and MOF-derived catalysts include chemical hydrogen sources such as inorganic hydrides that are the subject of section 3.1, electrocatalytic water splitting described in this section, and photocatalytic water splitting treated in section 4. A year ago Zhu, Zou, and Xu reported a review of MOF-based catalysts for HER with special emphasis on postsynthetic MOF modifications for highly efficient HER.339 In this section, after briefly recalling the fundamental principles, focus will be oriented toward the very new HER electrocatalysts (Table 1). The electrochemical HER from water is the reduction of protons or water by two electrons:
2H 2e H2+ → + −
This proton reduction reaction involves two steps: the proton reduction by one electron to the adsorbed hydrogen atom, the Volmer step, followed by the second step that can proceed according to two distinct mechanisms. The reduction of the adsorbed hydrogen atom by an electron and a proton is the Heyrovski mechanism, whereas the reductive elimination of two adsorbed hydrogen atoms is the Tafel mechanism.
H e H Volmer step+ → *+ −
H H e H Heyrovski mechanism2* + + → + −
2H H Tafel mechanism2* →
The activation energy strongly depends on the adsorption energy of the adsorbed hydrogen atom that should be neither too weak nor too strong. The optimized catalyst corresponds to a nil adsorption free energy (volcano-type) and minimal overpotential in both acidic and basic conditions. DFT calculations are useful to optimize this H adsorption energy on catalyst surfaces.340−343 Catalysts possessing oxo atoms should be favorable because oxo atoms facilitate the mobility of protons. Therefore MOFs have been combined with polyoxometallates (POMs) in POMOF catalysts or precursors leading to Mo oxide nanomaterials.344 In POMOFs, the optimized countercation is a hydrated Li cation that transports the largest amount of water molecules.345 Other materials presenting good electrocatalytic properties were cobalt and bimetallic Fe−Co Prussian Blue and MOFs phosphides eventually containing other atoms (B, C, N, and S) for synergistic catalysis.346−349 Altogether a large number of Earthabundant metal-based catalysts (in particular with Mo and W) such as chalcogenides, phosphides, carbides, and nitrides, metal-free carbon-based materials, and their hybrids with a variety of structures morphologies have been reported for HER electrocatalysis, but considerable efforts are needed to obtain nanomaterials able to compete with Pt-based electrocatalysts. Some bimetallic and trimetallic catalysts combining a first-raw transition metal and a noble metal have also been introduced, such as IrCo-, NiRu-, NiMo-, CoW-, and PtCoFe-catalysts with excellent performances.339
3.1.1. Monometallic Catalysts for HER. In spite of the outstanding activity of Pt and other noble-metal electrocatalysts, emphasis is now on the design of catalysts based on Earth-abundant metals. In the design of HER electrocatalysts, it is essential to take into account doping to bring about activation synergy, combination with graphene, or CNTs in order to improve the conductivity, and the optimization of the specific surface area by decreasing the catalyst size to increase its proportion of active sites. Therefore decreasing the catalyst
size down to the single atom should be extremely efficient and now appear most promising in the overall catalyst field. Several Mo- and W-based HER electrocatalysts have been reported taking into account the need of these properties with an Earthabundant metal. Indeed the electronic structures of Mo2C, WC, W2C, MoP, WN, MoS2, and WSe2 inter alia have indicated that these catalysts are excellent substitutes of Pt. Mo-based nanomaterials have been much investigated as HER electrocatalysts with low overpotentials, including MoS2, MoSe2, Mo2C, MoB, MoP, and Mo-containing bimetallic NPs. MoO2, a semiconductor, has received a lot of attention as a promising stable anode material due high electrochemical activity. The seemingly metallic MoO2 behavior is essentially due to the delocalization of metal electrons in its conduction band, and the multiple oxygen vacancies in transition metal oxides narrow the band gaps and create additional active sites boosting the electrocatalytic activity.350 Although MoS2 has received most attention as a standard HER electrocatalyst in the beginning of the 20th century, it requires a relatively high overpotential and does not present a sufficient density of active edge sites, so that practical applications using this catalyst cannot be envisaged. Mo-based MOF-derived nanomaterials represent a new generation of cheap, Earth-abundant recently emphasized HER electrocatalysts.351−359 Shao and Liu’s group fabricated MoN-NC from Cu-MOF NENU-5. The HER activity of MoN is much enhanced by the presence of porous MoN@N-doped carbon octahedrons derived from MOFs. MoN-NC achieved an overpotential of 62 mV at current density of 10 mA cm−2, and the Tafel slope was 54 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4. 351 MoN presents corrosion resistance, and the catalytic property of MoN-NC was also attributed to the unique MoN structure and the synergy between MoN and the N-doped carbon substrate. Li’s group synthesized MoP@PC (Figure 28), also starting from NENU-5 further functionalized
with phosphorus-containing groups aiming at further formation of P-doped carbon after pyrolysis.353 Therefore the authors synthesized a POMOF to fabricate MoP encapsulated in P-doped porous carbon, i.e., MoP@PC, by carbonization and phosphidation. This catalyst showed an onset overpotential of 97 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2 current density, with a Tafel slope of 59.3 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4. Thomas’ group reported a hierarchically mesoporous Mo-based carbon electrocatalyst synthesized from MOF precursors. This Mo-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
X
based mesoporous electrocatalyst exhibited HER activity and stability with an overpotential of 222 mV at 100 mA cm−2 (compare Pt/C: 263 mV).354
Zhang and Li’s groups designed ultrasmall WC NPs using as precursor zeolitic metal-azolate framework (MAF)-6 to confine [W(CO)6] before pyrolysis.
355 MAF-6 is nitrogen-rich, which favors the production of N-doped carbon for the stabilization of nanoclusters. Pyrolysis yieded WC nanoclusters/NP of 2 nm size. This electrocatalyst showed an overpotential of 51 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and Tafel slope of 49 mV per decade, as well as exchange current density of 2.4 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2 SO4. A single-W-atom MOF-derived N-doped carbon catalyst,W-SAC with W1N1C3 local structure, has been designed by Wang’s group (Figure 29).356 In order to synthesize this catalyst, WCl5 was encapsulated in UiO-66-NH2 in which the NH2 group prevented W species aggregation, followed by pyrolysis at 950 °C. W-SAC exhibited an overpotential (85 mV) at a current
density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 53 mV dec−1 in 0.1 M KOH. The HER activity is comparable to that of commercial Pt/C and benefits from the structure of the W1N1C3 species as revealed by DFT calculations. 163
Electrocatalysts based on the late first-raw transition metals have recently been the subject of special attention in view of the low cost and abundance of these metals. Thus such catalysts have been made with Fe,360,361 Co,362−370 Ni,371−373 and Cu,376 although NPs of these metal NPs must be handled carefully in the absence of air to avoid oxidation, at least on their surface. Xiang’s group synthesized in a single step FexP@ NPC (Figure 30) an iron phosphide hybrid encapsulated in hollow N−P codoped carbon derived from MIL-101-NH2-FeP (P from glyphosine via postsynthetic modification). This electrocatalyst showed a nearly constant voltage with only less than 0.1% increase at 10 mA cm−2 after 90 h in a full water
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
Y
splitting cell. The Faradaic efficiency was nearly quantitative with a similar level after 10 days.360
Most monometallic HER electrocatalysts are based on Co NPs.362−370 Co@N-CNTs@rGO reported by Fang et al. was derived from core−shell ZIF-67@ZIF-8 (Figure 31).366 In order to fabricate ultrafine Co NPs N-doped carbon, NTs were grafted onto both sides of graphene oxide (GO) by annealing GO-wrapped bimetallic (Co−Zn) ZIF-67@ZIF-8. Therefore Zn2+ was electrostatically bonded to the oxygen atoms of GO, and then 2-MeIm was coordinated to Zn2+ allowing ZIF growth on both GO sides. The so-formed sandwich-shape ZIF8@GO template then served as an epitaxial seed for the growth of ZIF-67 in the presence of Co2+ and 2-MeIm in a solvothermal reaction for 6 h at 90 °C. Co@N-CNTs@rGO was finally fabricated by pyrolysis at 900 °C liberating the GO and Co2+ that were reduced to rGO and Co NPs, respectively, whereas reduced Zn evaporated, leaving mesopores and micropores. Co@N-CNTs@rGO showed in HER, for a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η10), catalytic activity in both 1 M KOH (overpotential: 108 mV) and 0.5 M H2SO4 solution (overpotential: 87 mV). Durability in both acidic and alkaline conditions was observed. Employing the same strategy, some binary and ternary alloy@N-CNTs@rGO were fabricated and showed good performances. Li’s group fabricated ZIF-67-derived CoPS/NC and CoPCNTs upon introducing phosphorus atoms into the nanomaterials. For the former catalyst, ternary pyrite Co phosphosulfide NPs on a N-doped carbon matrix were fabricated by carbonization and phosphosulfurization of Co-ZIF-67.367 This electrocatalyst showed a catalytic current density of 10 mA cm−2 at overpotentials of 80 and 148 mV versus RHE and Tafel slope of 68 and 78 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH, respectively, which was among the best results obtained for transition-metal phosphosulfide HER catalysts. Synergistic catalytic effects between CoP polyhedron NPs and CNTs were disclosed for CoP-CNTs that exhibited HER activity, with an overpotential of 139 mV yielding a current density of 10 mA cm−2, a Tafel slope of 52 mV dec−1, and a stability over 20 h in 0.5 M H2SO4.
368 Liu’s group used a cobalt-based MOF as the starting material to fabricate a hybrid of CoP nanocrystals (∼10 nm) confined in N-doped bundled carbon nanowires (CoP/NCNWs).369 The Co-MOF precursor of bundle-like nanowire morphology was prepared via a solvothermal reaction. Co cations were linked by trimesic anions (Hbtc2) forming a planar structure. Pyrolysis was conducted at 700 °C,
far above the MOF decomposition temperature of 300 °C. The CoP/NCNWs hybrid displayed a Tafel slope of ∼50 mV dec−1; the Tafel slope for CoP/NC-D, CoP/C, and CoP NPs were 65, 70, and 69 mV dec−1, respectively, which demonstrated the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. The Hu and Bu group reported a MOF containing Co and S as a precursor of Co sulfide with a variety of Co/S stoichiometries. Co9S8/CoS1.097/rGO showed HER with an overpotential of 50 mV at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and 188 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2.370
Single-phase Ni phosphide materials fabricated from a MOF precursor with a hierarchically porous and regular morphology are highly desired as active HER electrocatalysts. Zhao’s group synthesized a regular three-dimensional hierarchically porous single-phase Ni2P polyhedron from a MOF-74-Ni precursor using one-step calcination at only 275 °C with sodium hypophosphite.371 In this way, Ni2P inherited the morphology and porosity of its precursor MOF-74-Ni. Ni2P presented an overpotential of 158 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 73 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4, showing the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism for HER. The Ni2P electrocatalyst was durable for over 20 h. Ni NPs synthesized by optimizing the annealing temperature of NiMOF performed HER with an overpotential of 41 mV at 10 mA cm−2.372 The introduction of Ni3+ lowered the Gibbs free energy of H-atom absorption on the Ni/NiO surface, due to the presence of additional active sites, which was confirmed by DFT calculation. The Chen group designed a core−shell structure of NiSe2 NPs@N-doped graphene derived from a Ni-based MOF in both acidic and alkaline media.373 In acidic (or alkaline) media, the hybrid had an onset potential of −163 (or −171) mV versus RHE, an overpotential of 201 (or 248) mV versus RHE at 10 mA cm−2, and a Tafel slope of 36.1 (or 74.2) mV dec−1. Copper, as a low-cost material that has recently emerged as
an abundant source of numerous catalytic processes, was an obvious candidate for the fabrication of MOF-derived green catalysts for energy conversion.374,375 Zang’s group synthesized Cu3P@NPPC-650.
376 The authors chose a Cu-based MOF (Cu-NPMOF), connecting the Cu2+ nodes with two linkers, 1- hydroxyethylidene-1,1-diphosphonic acid, and N-atom-containing pyrazine as a template, to fabricate, after pyrolysis at 650 °C, Cu3P NPs covered with a N,P-co-doped carbon shell, Cu3P@NPPC-650. This electrocatalyst exhibited an over-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
Z
potential of 89 mV for η10 in 0.5 M H2SO4 with a Tafel slope of 76 mV dec−1, suggesting the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. Platinum-based materials remaining the best performing HER electrocatalysts, smarter strategies for the design of sophisticated Pt-based nanomaterials fabricated from MOFbased precursors are highly desired, and some recent reports have indeed appeared.377−380 For example, Chen’s group synthesized Pt@NHPCP from ZIF-8.379 In 0.1 M HClO4, to obtain a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the overpotential value of Pt@NHPCP (−57.0 mV) was lower than that of commercial Pt/C (−69.6 mV), and the Tafel slope (27 mV dec−1) was also lower than for Pt/C (32 mV dec−1), suggesting a Volmer−Tafel mechanism for HER. The catalyst Pt@ NHPCP was demonstrated to have better HER durability than Pt/C by durability tests after 5000 potential cycles. Sun’s group reported N-doped hollow carbon nanospheres fabricated from a MOF for in situ Pt dispersion.380 Therefore Pt NPs were anchored on the surface of electrode modified with the carbon nanospheres. In H2SO4, the Tafel slope was 33 mV dec
−1, the overpotential was 40 mV to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2, and the catalyst was stable for 4000 CV cycles with a total 30 h of high current density (10, 50, and 100 mA cm−2 chronoamperometric electrolysis). 3.1.2. Bimetallic Catalysts for HER. Numerous bimetallic HER electrocatalysts have been reported with Fe, Co, Ni, Mo, W, or a noble metal.381−393 Fu and Sun’s group designed a MOF-templated approach with MIL-88B to synthesize Co incorporating FeP nanotubes.381 First CoFe MIL-88B nanorods were assembled by a solvothermal process using two metal salts and 1,4-BDC, next these nanorods were converted to semihollow CoFeOx by calcination in air, and then after phosphidation, the hollow Co−Fe−P nanotubes were obtained. They presented abundant catalytic sites, fast mass and charge transport pathways, and optimized electronic configuration. The Co−Fe−P nanotubes performed in a wide pH range, achieving overpotentials of 86, 108, and 66 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, 1 M phosphate buffer solution, and 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively. DFT calculations attributed the efficiency to the increased density of states near the Fermi level created by Co substitution. Hou’s group reported a hierarchical porous Co9S8−N-doped carbon@MoS2 polyhedral nanomaterial named Co9S8/NC@ MoS2 in which the morphology of the ZIF-67 precursor was preserved (Figure 32).384 The Co/NC polyhedrons, precursors of the Co9S8 NPs, were synthesized by carbonization at 800 °C of Co-based ZIF-67, and these authors improved the conductivity of the hybrid to allow charge transfer at the electrode/electrolyte interface. Co9S8/NC@MoS2 served as a
pH-universal HER electrocatalyst exhibiting activity for HER with overpotentials at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH (67 mV), 0.5 M H2SO4 (117 mV), and 1.0 M phosphate buffer solution (261 mV). The Tafel slopes were 60.3, 68.8, and 126.1 mV dec−1, respectively. Among Earth-abundant metal-based HER electrocatalysts, the Ni−Mo alloys were those that exhibited the lowest overpotentials. Zheng and Li et al. synthesized NiMo−C from a well-known Ni-MOF, Ni3(BTC)2.
388 This nanomaterial consisted of Ni NPs incorporated in a molybdate by addition of MoCl5 during the preparation of the Ni-MOF, which did not modify the Ni−MOF structure, and the Mo oxide was encapsulated in N-doped carbon layers. NiMo−C was obtained upon heating MoOx@Ni-MOF (Mo: Ni molar ratio of 6:94) at 450 °C under an atmosphere of NH3: Ar = 1:5 (v/v). A current density of 20 mA cm−2 (η20) was obtained with an overpotential of 58 mV, and this potential remained stable at 20 mA cm−2 for 12 h. The Tafel slope was 57 mV dec−1. The d-band center of the CoIr alloy is located in the vicinity of the Fermi level and close to that of the Pt benchmark. This suggested that the electronic state of the CoIr alloy would be similar to that of Pt. Therefore on this basis, Chen’s group fabricated Ir−Co alloys encapsulated in N-doped carbon, IrCo@NC, for HER catalysis.391 The fabrication of the MOF-derived IrCo@NC catalyst involved incorporation of Ir into the Prussian-blue analog Co3[Co(CN)6]2, which provided Ir as a single-atom precursor to form the desired nanomaterial composed of an alloy core with highly N-doped carbon layers. The obtained precursor was carbonized at temperatures between 500 and 800 °C under inert atmosphere, provoking the merging of Ir and Co into the Ir−Co alloy, while the CN− groups were carbonized to form an N-rich graphene as layers at the alloy surface. The Tafel slope was 23 mV dec−1, indicating a Volmer-Heyrovsky reaction mechanism. The catalytic performance was superior to most reported catalysts, owing to electron transfer from the IrCo core to the graphene shell as demonstrated by DFT calculations. The trend of η in 0.5 M H2SO4 at the current density of 10 mA cm
−2 ranked according to IrCo@NC-500 (24 mV) < 20% Pt/C (35 mV) < 20% Ir/C (51 mV) < 5% Pt/C (59 mV) < Co@NC-600 (276 mV). It is remarkable that the alloy effect was clear compared to the individual metals and that the HER performance of optimal IrCo@NC-500 even exceeded that of 20 wt % Pt/C. Wang et al. prepared bimetallic NiRu@N−C from Ni-based MOF [Ni2-(bdc)2ted] for HER. First the Ni-based MOF [Ni2(bdc)2ted] was synthesized by reacting Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, bdc (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid), and ted (triethylenediamine) in DMF solution at 130 °C for 24 h.392 Ni-MOF reacted with a RuCl3 solution, and the sheet-like morphology of the original Ni-based MOF was essentially maintained. Then the Ru-doped Ni-based MOF precursors were pyrolyzed at 800 °C under nitrogen, which provoked the reduction of NiII and RuIII to bimetallic RuNi alloy nanocrystals and the formation of nitrogen-doped graphitized carbon layers from the organic components of the precursor. For a current density of 10 mA cm−2, 50 mV was needed from this catalyst in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 32 mV was needed in 1.0 M KOH corresponding to Tafel slopes of 36 mV dec−1 in 0.5 H2SO4 and 64 mV dec −1 in KOH, respectively. Among the noble metals, Ru ($42 per oz) is the cheapest compared to Pt ($992 per oz), Ir ($500 per oz), and Pd ($551) per oz. Chen’s group also believed that the strong electronic interactions via the interface of the Ru/MoO2
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AA
nanomaterial would enhance electrical conductivity and lower the energy barriers of intermediates, and therefore, on this basis these authors fabricated Ru-MoO2 prepared from MoMOF (Mo3(btc)2) annealing.
393 The nanostructure involved Ru NPs dispersed on the MoO2 surface. For the synthesis of Ru-MoO2, an aqueous RuCl3 solution was first added to an oxygen-free ethanol solution of Mo-btc NPs, and after separation, this precursor was pyrolyzed at 700 °C. At a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the electrocatalyst showed a good activity under both acidic 0.5 M H2SO4 (55 mV) and 1 M KOH (29 mV), better than that of 20% Pt/C. The Tafel slopes were 44 and 31 mV dec−1, respectively. DFT calculations suggested that the catalytic performances benefited from the electronic interactions between Ru NPs and MoO2.

sections.heading: 3.2. Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER)
sections.text:
The OER is the oxidation of water at the anode producing O2:
2H O O 4H 4e2 2→ + + + −
The reaction proceeds with sluggish kinetics and large overpotential, however, and a variety of mechanisms have been proposed, as well as the four following overall steps:394
H O HO H e2 site → * + + + −
HO O H e* → * + ++ −
O H O HOO H e2* + → * + + − +
HOO O H e2* → + + + −
Understanding the actual OER mechanism is thus essential because the sluggish OER is the current bottleneck of efficient water electrolysis and also is key to the rechargeable metal-air batteries. The optimization of the OER kinetics is crucial for the applications of the water-splitting process, including the efficient generation of hydrogen. A high surface area is expected to optimize the electrocatalyst as well as hydrophilicity to take the evolved bubbles into account. It must overtake the high free energies of HO*, O*, HOO* and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AB
anionic species binding on the surface causing large overpotentials. The best catalysts are so far noble metals (Pt) and noble metal oxides (RuO2 and IrO2). The best and so far most popular catalyst is RuO2, but it is corroded (as IrO2) under operating conditions. Research with MOFs is at the forefront of new catalyst optimization.395,396 For instance MOF functional groups such as −NH2, organic ligands, and coordinated metals significantly decrease or influence these surface binding energies.397 In order to compensate for the poor MOF conductivity and enhance electrode/electrolyte interface, highly porous composite nanomaterials must be elaborated for instance by growing MOF films on highly conductive compounds such as GO and MWCNTs.398 Cobalt is an Earth-abundant metal of choice for OER electrocatalysis with MOFs because pyrolysis forms Co3O4 that provide O−H interactions favoring proton mobility. Doping MOF-Co catalysts with P, C, or Ni upon calcination also proved efficient in lowering overpotentials, and therefore, the calcination temperature is very influencial.340−342 Recently, various transition metal catalysts, especially non-noble metals, such as Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu, and their oxides, especially hybridized with N-doped carbons, have been fabricated and successfully applied for OER, and the area has specifically been reviewed by Zhao’s group in 2017.399 The transition metals favor the crystallinity and electrical conductivity of carbon matrix by catalytic graphitization at high temperature, which protect the metals from corrosion and aggregation during the electrochemical reactions. The synergy of metal species, the doped N species, and carbon lattice introduce localized reactive sites upon modification of the charge distribution on the carbon surface by promoting electron transfer, thereby modifying O2 adsorption and facilitating the ORR and OER. 400 Recent results on OER are discussed in the following sections (Table 2). 3.2.1. Monometallic Catalysts for OER. Numerous Co-
based MOF electrocatalysts for OER have recently emerged.337,365,401−419 NC@Co−NGC DSNCs with NC as
inner shell and Co-NGC as outer shell (Figure 33) was fabricated by Zhao and Qiu’s group.337 The hybrid nanocages involve closely packed double shells comprising a ZIF-8derived inner shell of N-doped microporous carbon (NC) and a ZIF-67-derived outer shell of codecorated N-doped mesoporous graphitic carbon (Co-NGC), noted NC@Co− NGC DSNCs. Polyhedral nanocrystals of ZIF-8 were first fabricated by the coordination of Zn2+ by 2-MeIm in methanol and function as crystal seeds for subsequent epitaxial growth of ZIF-67 with similar structure ([M(MeIm)2] (M = Zn for ZIF8 or Co for ZIF-67). The resulting ZIF-8@ZIF-67 nanomaterial presenting structural similarities with ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 crystals is then thermally annealed under N2 at 800 °C followed by etching away the unstable Co NPs with H2SO4, which forms short carbon NTs on the surface. The catalytic activities for OER (η10: 1.64 V, Tafel slope: 91 mV dec
−1) were superior to those of Pt and RuO2, due to the synergistic effect between the CoNPs and two carbon shells. Fan’s group synthesized CoSe2-450 from Co-MOF (using cobalt nitrate hexahydrate and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid as precursors).404 The hollow MOF precursor Co-MOF was converted into a catalyst by single-step selenization annealing at 450 °C under Ar. The catalyst exhibits a η10 of 330 mV with a Tafel slope of 79 mV dec−1, which is superior to that of IrO2. The catalytic activity was attributed to the hollow CoSe2 shape and the well-distributed active sites. CoSe2-450 shows a durability of 1000 CV cycles. N, P, and S are widely used to dope MOF materials in order
to enhance the catalytic performances, and thus Li and Su et al. fabricated Co@NC-3/1 from CoZn-BMZIF (Figure 34).405
Co@NC-3/1 presented OER activity (η10: 1.57 V, Tafel slope: 85 mV dec−1) in 1 M KOH, which exceeded the OER performance of RuO2 and IrO2, and it exhibited stability for 2000-circle scanning. These authors also addressed the difficult challenge of designing a bifunctional electrocatalyst able to perform both ORR and OER. Indeed Ru- and Ir-based composites that present the best OER activity are also poor
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AC
ORR catalysts. Pt Ir alloys and their oxides perform well as ORR catalysts but are not stable, and their scarcity also precludes commercial applications. Transition-metal chalcogenides and oxides are potentially able to serve as catalysts for both ORR and OER, but they suffer from easy NP aggregation, large NP size, low specific surface areas, and lack of active sites. On the other hand, transition-metal carbonitriles are good candidates, and therefore, ZIFs are excellent precursors with plenty of N atoms that can form N-doped carbons upon pyrolysis. Therefore, these authors synthesized N-doped graphitic carbon frameworks cross-linked with Co NPs and crystalline CNTs derived from CoxZny-BMZIF for both ORR and OER. Porous carbons derived from CoxZny-BMZIF indeed combine the advantages of carbons derived from both ZIF-8 and ZIF-67, and they benefit from high large surface area, graphitic carbon, highly dispersed N, and active Co−Nx groups. Co9S8 NP-embedded N/S-co-doped carbon nanofibers derived from ZIF-wrapped CdS nanowires Co9S8/NSCNFs was reported by the Song and Zhang group as OER electrocatalysts.410 Therefore CdS nanowires were synthesized by solvothermal reaction, and then CdS@ZIF was prepared by mixing Zn(NO3)2, 2-MeIm, and PVP in methanol with CdS followed by pyrolysis under N2 leading to Co9S8/NSCNFs. The overpotential with this electrocatalyst to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 was of 302 mV, the Tafel slope was 54 mV dec−1, and stability of Co9S8/NSCNFs for 1000 CV cycles was observed. Another S,N-co-doped carbon-fiber nanomaterial, Co/CoxSy@SNCF-800, was fabricated by Zhang’s group.411 These authors synthesized [Co(Tdc)(bpy)]n as a MOF using water and methanol as solvents with NaOH. The presence of doubly pillared layer structures brought a high thermal stability to the Co-MOFs. Pyrolysis at 800 °C provided uniformly encapsulated 50−100 nm Co/CoxSy NPs into the carbon structure. The η10 potential of this nanomaterial was of 1.542 V and the Tafel slope of 68 mV dec−1 for OER, close to those of RuO2 (1.536 V, 59 mV dec
−1). Besides these two reports, several other OER catalysts were fabricated based on Co oxides.412−419 For example, Jiang et al. fabricated UTSA-16 with a Co4O4 core.
419 Benefiting from the synergistic effects of the porous structure, high-valent Co and cubane-shaped Co4O4, UTSA-16 exhibited activity toward OER in 1.0 M KOH with η10 of 408 mV and Tafel slope of 77 mV dec−1, which is much smaller than Co3O4 but still larger than RuO2. Ni-based OER electrocatalysts are less numerous than those based on Co, but examples have recently appeared. Chao et al. fabricated Ni NPs@N-CNTs for OER electrocatalysis.420 The Ni-MOF precursor, prepared from Ni(NO3)2·H2O, Na2CO3, 4,40-bipyridine, and D-(+)-camphoric acid in water at 120 °C, was pyrolyzed at 600 °C for 3h yielding Ni NPs@N-CNTs. The Tafel slope value of this electrocatalyst was 106 mV dec−1, larger than that of RuO2, and the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 (0.46 V) was smaller than that of RuO2 (0.62 V). Overall, the OER catalytic performances of Ni NPs@N-CNTs were comparable to those of RuO2. Acharya et al. reported a hybrid electrocatalyst, AgNPs@ rGO/MIL-88B(Fe), that was based on a MOF, MIL-88B (Fe), and chemically grown in situ on flexible GO sheets and then doped with Ag NPs.421 AgNPs@rGO/MIL-88B(Fe) provided an overpotential of 395 mV at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 with a Tafel slope of 60 mV dec−1 in a neutral buffer solution. The catalyst also exhibited stability for over 30 days.
The catalytic performances may be due to the stability of AgNPs, high porosity, and conductivity of the hybrid MOF structure.
3.2.2. Bimetallic Catalysts for OER. Co oxide-based electrocatalysts have shown promising performances for the OER, but they are not commercially viable because of their low conductivity and aggregation in alkaline media. The use of MOFs as template precursors should allow overcoming these problems, however. In particular, MOF-derived bimetallic electrocatalysts appear especially suitable due to their tunability toward microstructures, compatibility with many metal ions, and ability to achieve uniform dispersion of derived carbon.422−435
Co and Fe being two most Earth-abundant and benign metals, their combination in catalysts is attractive in spite of their low intrinsic conductivity and trend to agglomerate leading to high overpotentials. The ability of charge transfer is a missing quality of these metal NPs in terms of overpotential. Bimetallic synergy in the effect of additives such as oxyphosphides appears suitable for catalyst improvements, in particular, with MOF-derived materials that bring about sufficient porosity. With porous structure the diffusion of oxygen gas bubbles is expedited as well as the stability and rigidity of the structure for optimized electron transfer.422,423 On the basis of these concepts Wang et al. synthesized the bimetallic CoFe nanomaterial Co3FePxO.
423 Therefore, a mixed Co3Fe MOF with nanodiamond morphology was fabricated from a solution of Co2+, Fe3+, and p-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) followed by phosphorylation with NaH2PO2 and annealing in air at 550 °C to give the CoFe oxyphosphide Co3FePxO. The Co/Fe ratio was optimized to Co3Fe, and this nanocatalyst exhibited an activity of η10 = 291 mV, Tafel slope = 85 mV dec−1, and durability over 18 h for OER because of the highly active sites in the porous structure and the efficient electron transfer from metal to P. Likewise, Ni is another first-raw late transition metal of choice to combine with Co or Fe for synergy with the advantages and qualities indicated above, and several reports have appeared with such bimetallic OER catalysts. Thus combining Ni and Fe,424−427 Jiang’s group synthesized the bimetallic catalyst Fe−Ni−P/rGO-400, prepared from a NiMOF template.426 Benefiting from the synergistic effect between Fe and Ni, the good conductivity of rGO and the highly porous structure, an overpotential of 240 mV was found to reach 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 63 mV dec−1 was obtained, better than IrO2 and most non-noble metal electrocatalysts. After 5 h of continuous CV scanning, the catalyst was slightly inactivated. In order to optimize synergy, trimetallic nanomaterials have also been tested as OER catalysts combining three first-raw late transition metals. Zhang’s group reported Ni3FeN/Co,N-CNF, prepared from a ZIF-type MOF with 2-MeIm linkers after carbonization of the precursor at 900 °C for 2 h under N2. 427 This nanomaterial afforded a η10 of 0.27 V that was superior to that of IrO2 (0.34 V), and the Tafel slope (51 mV dec
−1) was lower than that of IrO2 (70 mV dec
−1). The remarkable OER activity was attributable to the size effect of Ni3FeN NPs and the Co,N−CNF support that inhibited the aggregation of Ni3FeN. Dong’s group transformed bimetallic MOF polyhedra (CoNi-ZIF PHs) with a hollow structure for the fabrication of NiCoP/NC PHCs using etching with tannic acid, calcination at 700 °C for 3 h, and finally phosphidation with
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AD
NaH2PO4 at 300 °C for 2 h (Figure 35). 428 The electrocatalytic properties of this nanocomposite were characterized
by an overpotential of 297 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 51 mV dec−1, better than commercial RuO2 (η10: 358 mV, Tafel slope: 81 mV dec
−1). The catalyst retained stability over 10 h. Cui’s group encapsulated a Ni−Cu alloy into MOF-74 without additional precursors, and the catalyst showed multiple synergistic effects for the OER.429 Lee’s group fabricated a 3D bimetallic CoMo-based electrocatalyst CoOx-MoC/NC for OER.431 This catalyst showed an overpotential of 330 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (smaller than IrO2/C, 400 mV) with a Tafel slope of 89 mV dec−1, benefiting from the synergistic effect between Co and MoC. Several catalysts were assembled with a noble metal and a non-noble metal.214,432 For instance, viewing also the good efficiency and stability properties of Pt−Mo2C thin films demonstrated by Chen’s group,432 Pd@PdO-Co3O4 fabricated by Liu and Chen et al. from ZIF-67 (Figure 36), provided an overpotential of 1.54 V (η10) with a Tafel slope of 70 mV dec−1, comparable to the values of RuO2.
433,434 DFT calculations suggested that the CoOOH layer formatted on the catalyst surface protected the metal core and provided more active sites for OER.

sections.heading: 3.3. Water Splitting (HER + OER)
sections.text:
Electrocatalytic water splitting, the reverse process of fuel cell reactions, consists in the catalysis of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at the cathode and oxygen evolution reaction
(OER) at the anode. The energy input under standard conditions is 237 kJ mol−1 (1.23 V), but in practice, the required energy is much higher due to the sluggish kinetics related to multiple electron transfers with bond rearrangements. See the HER and OER sections for mechanistic details. Thus both reactions require efficient catalysts, and therefore, traditionally Pt was by far the best element for HER and RuO2 and IrO2 the best electrocatalysts for OER. Earth-abundant metal components are presently actively searched in particular based on or derived from MOFs. Among the electrocatalysts discussed and cited in the HER and OER sections, some are good catalysts for only one of these two reactions, whereas some others are good catalysts for both reactions. There are many common features for electrocatalysts of these two reactions, however. The electrocatalysts are evaluated for their activity determined by the potential in the polarization curve for which the current density reaches 10 mA cm−2 and the Tafel slope, and for their stability.435,436 To date, non-noble metals and their carbides, nitrides, phosphides, sulfides, and selenides have been explored as effective water-splitting electrocatalysts.437,438 Pristine MOFs are being more and more rarely used as heterogeneous functional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, but they can be productively engineered to integrate both catalytic sites of HER and OER in the same MOF structure. Actually there is an impressive increase of the number of reports on HER, OER, and overall water splitting using bifunctional MOF derivatives because they can avoid the drawbacks of low conductivity, aggregation, and limited stability that are currently encountered with pristine MOFs. Typical examples include POM, ZIF-type MOFs, and other hollow structural motifs. In particular, the calcination strategy under well-determined temperature and gas atmosphere conditions allows using MOFs for the fabrication of highly porous composites containing N- and other element-doped carbon-supported transition-metal NPs. Doping elements of conducting carbon materials are classified according to their charge populations as electron donors (F, S, P, and B) and electron acceptors (N, O). Specifically for HER, N/P codoping provided the lowest overpotential results, whereas they were obtained for OER in alkaline media with
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AE
N-doped mesoprous carbon.438 The superiority of MOFdependent strategies in producing porous N- and elementdoped carbons encapsulating, thus stabilizing active metal sites, ensuring their dispersity and the material conductivity has been demonstrated. It is manifested by cage confinement, and using
adequate engineering, single-site catalysts avoiding metal site aggregation have been designed for efficient electrocatalysis activity and stability for overall water splitting.439−441
Publications in the recent years on MOFs in water splitting are discussed in the following sections (Table 3).
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AF
3.3.1. Monometallic Catalysts for Water Splitting. Many transition metal phosphide-based electrocatalyst for overall water splitting have been designed. Recently, non-noble metal based, especially Co (the most used non-noble metal)442−449 and Ni catalysts,450−454 have drawn much attention for their capabilities in electrocatalytic water splitting. For a number of applications, there is a need of multiple reactions proceeding in tandem or a concerted way. Rather than using several catalysts at the same electrode, it would be desirable to design a single material able to catalyze several reactions. For instance, gas electrodes in fuel cells and metal− air batteries require both OER and ORR catalysts. Mechanistic information would also benefit from such devices. Such an area remains in its infancy, and innovative concepts and materials are awaited toward this goal. Along this line, the Chen and Li group constructed a hybrid nanostructure CoP/NCNHP with CoP NPs embedded in Ndoped CNT hollow polyhedron (NCNHP) using a strategy successively involving pyrolysis at 900 °C, oxidation and phosphidation from a ZIF-8@ZIF-67 (Figure 37).442 The seed ZIF-8-derived N-doped carbon, from which Zn evaporated with the temperature reaching above 900 °C (under Ar flow), functioned as a nanostructured hollow frame promoting the diffusion kinetics. The CNTs formed on the surface of hollow polyhedrons upon pyrolysis played a major catalytic role. This catalyst CoP/NCNHP was used as both anode and cathode for overall water splitting, and a potential of 1.64 V was needed to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2 with durability of 36 h without significant potential decrease. Liu and Sun et al. designed a trifunctional catalyst Co/CoPHNC prepared from Co-based ZIF-67, this MOF type being chosen for its uniform pore size and large number of C, Co, and N atoms in the framework.446 Pyrolysis of Co-ZIF-67 with dicyandiamide resulted in the formation of carbon polyhedrons penetrated with CNTs. ORR activity is provided by the Co NPs embedded in the N-CNTs. HER and OER activities come from the Co NPs on the side wall of hierarchical N-doped carbon polyhedrons as a result of the phophorization of uncovered Co NPs. For a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the
overpotential was 0.18 V for HER. For OER and overall water splitting in 1.0 M KOH, 1.53 and 1.68 V were needed, respectively. In another report of multiple electrocatalysis, Zhang and Liu’s group fabricated a Co NP-embedded Ndoped carbon/CNT framework by pyrolysis of a Cocontaining MOF with adenine as a ligand without any other precursor.406 This Co@N-CNTF catalyst showed performances toward the ORR, OER, and HER, with a high half-wave potential of 0.81 V versus RHE for the ORR, and overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 for the OER of 0.35 V and HER of 0.22 V, and for overall water splitting an alkaline electrolyzer with 10 mA cm−2 under a stable voltage of 1.71 V. These performances were attributed to the abundant, homogeneously distributed Co NP active sites within the N-doped graphitic layer. The Jin and Ma group synthesized CoPS@NPS-C with CoPS NPs and tridoped (N, P, S) porous carbon fabricated from a Co-ZIF-67 MOF and commercial carbon black (XC-72) precursors.447 The catalyst benefited from the interaction between CoPS NPs and NPS-C. Overpotentials of 93 mV and 191 mV were needed to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH, respectively, for HER; 320 mV was needed under these latter conditions for OER. Toward overall water splitting, the observed value under the same alkaline conditions for η10 was 1.62 V. After Co, Ni is the second-most used Earth-abundant metal on which electrocatalysts are based for water splitting.450−454 Theoretical calculations have indicated that Ni2P possesses a superior activity compared to the noble metal catalysts for HER, and catalytic results also showed high activity in OER, making the synthesis of Ni2P a privileged choice for overall water splitting electrocatalysis.450,451 Xing and Zhao et al. fabricated Ni2P/rGO from MOF-74-Ni-GO upon heating with NaH2PO2·H2O at 275 °C for 3 h.
452 The exposed defects of the rGO sheets on Ni2P/rGO showed that Ni2P NPs have grown ultrasmall nickel phosphide nanocrystals on both sides of rGO, so that a sandwich structure was obtained for Ni2P/ rGO (Figure 38). TEM images indicated that Ni2P/rGO remained in the same shape as MOF-74-Ni/GO without aggregation of homogeneous carbon formed during the
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AG
phosphorization, which was a source of electron highway for enhanced electron-transfer efficiency. A large active surface area and a perfect dispersity of active sites were provided with a NP size of 2.6 nm. In 1.0 M KOH, Ni2P/rGO exhibited η10 of 142 mV, 260 mV, and 1.61 V, for HER, OER, and overall water splitting, respectively. 3.3.2. Bi- and Trimetallic Catalysts for Water Splitting. Several noble-metal-free bi- or trimetallic electrocatalysts for water splitting were recently reported by combining Co with Ti, Mo, W, Fe, Ni, or Zn, increasing the possibilities of activation synergies compared to monometallic electrocatalysts.431,455−470 Several catalysts have been designed with Ni,456−458 and Zhao’s group reported Co4Ni1P, synthesized from MOF-74.458 This catalyst exhibited η10 values of 129 mV, 245 mV, and 1.59 V for HER, OER, and overall water splitting, respectively, thanks to the highly dispersed active sites and the synergistic effect between NiCoP and Co2P. The catalyst was also stable with a durability test over 50 h. Liu’s group fabricated Co9S8-NSC@Mo2C composed of Co9S8 and Mo2C NPs starting from the ZIF-67 precursor. 459 The electrocatalyst showed HER performances over a broad pH range. To achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the overpotentials were 74, 89, and 121 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4, 1.0 M KOH, and 1.0 M phosphate-buffered solution, with Tafel slopes of 69.3, 86.7, and 106.4 mV dec−1, respectively. η10 of 293 mV with a Tafel slope of 59.7 mV dec−1 was observed for OER, with a η10 value of 1.6 V in 1.0 M KOH. The catalytic activities of Co9S8-NSC@Mo2C were assigned to electron transfer between Co and Mo2C. Also prepared from the precursor ZIF-67, the catalyst Fe−CoP HTPAs was synthesized by Yu’s group, with a needed overpotential of 98 and 230 mV to achieve a 10 mA cm−2 current density for HER and OER.460 Toward overall water splitting, the η10 was only 1.59 V because of the abundant active sites and efficient electron-transfer properties of the catalyst. Bai and Sun’s group reported several catalysts combining Co and Zn.461,462 For instance, these authors synthesized a catalyst containing Co3ZnC and Co NPs embedded in a N-doped CNT-grafted carbon polyhedron framework, Zn0.975Co0.025S/ CoS2 NPs. This nanomaterial was obtained by pyrolysis of CoZn-ZIF in a reducing atmosphere of H2/Ar (Figure 39). 462 The electrical conductivity and structure stability were improved by the interconnected CNTs in the polyhedra. Because of the mesoporous structure and the synergetic effect of Zn and Co, the catalyst ZnCoS-NSCNT/NP exhibited the following catalytic performance for HER (η10: 152 mV), OER (η10: 270 mV), and overall water splitting (η10: 1.59 V) in 1 M KOH and showed stability during 40 h for water splitting. A number of catalysts have been reported upon combining Ni and Fe.464−468 Manthiram and Ahn designed Cincorporated porous Fe−Ni phosphide nanorods grown on
commercial Ni foam, Ni−Fe−P@C NRs.467 This catalyst displayed activity for both HER (η10, 79 mV; Tafel slope, 92.6 mV dec−1) and OER (η10, 217 mV; Tafel slope, 40 mV dec
−1) in 1.0 KOH. It needed only 1.52 V to afford a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with over 24 h stability for water splitting. The Xu and Zhu groups designed a MIL-53(NiFe)-based electrode composed of thin Ni−Fe MOF foam nanosheets containing small Fe−Ni clusters that they used as OER electrocatalyst with performance of required overpotentials 227 and 253 mV for current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively, which outperformed the benchmark of RuO. Upon coupling with a Pt electrode in overall water splitting, only 1.537 V was needed to obtain a current density of 10 mA cm−2.468
Co has also been combined with noble metals.469−471 For instance Tang and Wang’s group fabricated core−shell Co@Ir NPs encapsulated in porous carbon, Co@Ir/NC-10%.470 This catalyst was derived from ZIF-67 by pyrolysis at 900 °C for 3 h and then the powder dispersed under ambient conditions in water was impregnated with aqueous IrCl3·3H2O. Co@Ir/NC10% exhibited an overpotential of 121 mV for HER and 280 mV for OER at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. It may be practical for water splitting with a potential of 1.7 V.

sections.heading: 3.4. Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR)
sections.text:
In fuel cells, O2 is reduced at the cathodic half-cell according to
O 4H 4e 2H O2 2+ + → + −
O2 is adsorbed then reduced by an associative, dissociative, or peroxo mechanism that proceeds either unfavorably according to a 2e− pathway via the intermediate H2O2 or through the hoped-for 4e− pathway. ORR is of great importance in electrochemical energy conversion area including proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and metal-air batteries. Pt/C has been widely used in ORR for several decades, but Pt is rare and expensive, easy to corrode carbon, and aggregate. Therefore efforts have been dedicated to design and synthesize inexpensive substitutes such as Ptmetal alloys and non-noble metal electrocatalysts to replace Pt/C.472−475 The later strategy was pioneered by Mao et al. with Cu-based MOFs.476 The poor MOF conductivity needs to be overtaken by combining the MOF with conducting graphene oxide (GO)477 or by using ionic MOF species478 or a mediator.479 Calcination of MOFs together with N ligands for the formation of M−N−C carbonaceous composite nanocatalysts (M = Fe or Co) proved especially efficient.32,480−484 A similar approach was used with metal sulfides to form M− S−C composite catalysts or oxides to generate M−O−C catalysts.482−484 Boron and phosphorus are other helpful doping atoms. High surface areas and macropores are necessary in these composites for efficient mass transfer, but micropores are also needed for active sites.397,398 Publications

in recent years on NPs in MOFs for ORR are discussed in the following sections (Table 4). 3.4.1. Monometallic Catalysis for ORR. Recent research
on MOF-derived ORR electrocatalysts has focused on Ti, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu-containing mono- and bimetallic nanomaterials, in particular when these nanomaterials contained N-doped carbon. Actually, a number of electrocatalysts introduced in the HER361,376,406 and OER337,402,403,405−408,411−414,416 section also display good catalytic performance for ORR, some of them being even trifunctional.365,447
Qin and Huang’s group reported Ti-MOF/N-doped graphene nanomaterials as ORR electrocatalysts in both alkaline and acidic media. The onset potential and the Tafel slope value of the Ti-MOFs/NG nanocomposite are 1.14 V and 17.84 mV dec−1 in 0.1 M HClO4, respectively.
485 The catalysts performances have been attributed to the existences of the Ti3N2−x, C2O7Ti2.3, H2Ti5O11, Ti, and TiO active ORR segments. Electrocatalysts based on Fe, the most abundant on Earth,
are attractive, and Fe is an active component of electrocatalysts.486−491 It has been suggested that Fe−N/C nanomaterials present a better ORR activity than other M-N/C materials with the other first-raw late transition metals as a result of the optimized synergy between the Fe−N fragment and the conductive carbon layers. Therefore Liu and Xia et al. fabricated Fe3O4/N-HCSC by encapsulating Fe3O4 with a hollow core−shell N-doped carbon sphere with uniformly dispersed Fe−N species in both carbon core and shell.490 The carbon architecture favors both mass transfer and electron transfer during the catalytic process. Because of these factors
related to the porous hollow structure and the synergistic effect between Fe3O4 and NC, the Fe3O4/N-HCSC shows an Eonset of 1.024 V, E1/2 of 0.846 V, and JL of 5.69 mA cm
−2, prior to that of Pt/C. Most recently reported ORR electrocatalysts fabricated from MOFs are based on cobalt.406−408,492−512 Varela and Dai’s group prepared PANI/ZIF-67 by in situ synthesis of the complex of polyaniline and Co-ZIF-67 followed by simple pyrolysis at 500 °C for 2 h then 800 °C for 3 h.365 This catalyst consisted of Co/Co3O4/NC and exhibited good catalytic multifunctional activities toward HER, OER, and ORR. Benefiting from the synergy between Co and Co3O4 NPs, PANI/ZIF-67 displayed for ORR Eonset of 0.85 V, E1/2 of 0.75 V, and a diffusion-limited current density of 4.6 mA cm−2. The Zhang group tuned the dimensions and structures of N-
doped carbon nanomaterials upon regulating the Co/Zn ratio in ZIF-8 or ZIF-67 arrays grown in situ on γ-C3N4 nanosheets, forming the 1D, 2D, and 3D nitrogen-doped Co nanomaterials Co/N-BCNTs, N-CNS, and Co/N-CNTFs from Zn/CoZIF@g-C3N4, ZIF-8@g-C3N4 (Co free), and ZIF-67@g-C3N4 (Zn free), respectively. After pyrolysis at 900 °C for 1 h, Zn/ Co-ZIF@g-C3N4 yielded Co/N-BCNTs that showed a halfwave potential of 0.83 V with a limiting current density of 6 mA cm−2, which is larger than that of Pt/C (E1/2: 0.82 V, JL: 5.37 mA cm−2) in 0.1 M KOH. Its stability was also demonstrated to be better than Pt/C after a 12 h test.503
Kim and Lee’s group reported a one-pot synthesis of Co@NC derived from Co-MOFs, ZnxCo1−x(C3H4N2) via a mechanochemical coordination self-assembly synthesis.504 Pyrolysis of ZnxCo1−x(C3H4N2) yielded the uniform Co@NC nanostruc-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AJ
ture by simple evaporation of Zn. This Co@NC-MOF catalyst (Figure 40) exhibited an Eonset of 0.97 V, an E1/2 of 0.88 V, and a Tafel slope of 55 mV dec−1. The catalytic activity may be ascribed to the efficient electron transfer from NC shell to Co NPs. The Zou and Xu groups have designed N- and S-doped nonnoble metal honeycomb-like open porous carbon structures containing Co9S8 NPs derived from MIL-101-NH2. Because of multiple synergies this nanomaterial disclosed excellent electrocatalytic activity for the ORR with long-term stability and methanol tolerance comparable with commercial 20 wt % Pt/C catalyst under alkaline conditions. Therefore, the authors have achieved double encapsulation to uniformly and quantitatively introduce thiourea (TU) and CoCl2 forming [(TU)4Co]Cl2 as the secondary precursors into the MOF pores without their aggregation on the MOF external surface (Figure 41).512
Cu3P@NPPC-650 synthesized by Zang’s group is applied to both HER and ORR.376 This catalyst shows a half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.78 V with a limiting current density (JL) of 5.57 mA cm−2 in 0.1 M KOH, ascribed to the synergistic effect between the heteroatom-doped carbon and the Cu3P. On the basis of Cu, Wang and Tang et al. fabricated CuNC/KB-400 with Cu/Cu2O NPs and CuNxCy species from a Cu-MOF. 513 CuNC/KB-400 exhibited better catalytic activity for ORR (E1/2, 0.82 V; JL, 6.05 mA cm
−2; and Tafel slope, 69.7 mA cm−2) than commercial Pt/C. 3.4.2. Bimetallic Catalysis for ORR. Numerous nonnoble bimetallic catalysts have recently been reported using a
combination of Co with Mo, Fe, Ni, or Zn.382,405,427,514−519 Ni3FeN/Co,N-CNF developed by Zhang’s group exhibited good catalytic activity toward both OER and ORR. For ORR, it afforded a half-wave potential of 0.81 V and a Tafel slope of 52 mV dec−1, which is comparable to Pt/C.427 Li and Su’s group synthesized Co@NC-3/1 for both OER and ORR.405 The bimetallic Co/Zn catalysts synthesized from CoxZnyBMZIF-derived porous carbon with various Co/Zn ratios combine the advantages of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67, possess highly graphitic carbon, large surface area, highly dispersed N and active C−Nx groups. Upon carbonization of CoxZnyBMZIF at 900 °C under Ar, Zn evaporated. The best catalyst, Co@NC-3/1, presented a high onset potential (Eonset) of 1.15 V and E1/2 of 0.93 V, i.e., superior performance and durability than commercial Pt/C (Eonset, 0.93 V; E1/2, 0.87 V), because of the active Co−Nx species, evenly dispersed Co NPs and heteroatoms, and hierarchical pores. Li’s group fabricated ZnO/ZnCo2O4/C@rGO from ZIF-67 (Figure 42). The E1/2 of ZnO/ZnCo2O4/C@rGO was −0.15 V (V vs Ag/AgCl), less negative than Pt/C (−0.18 V), the Tafel slope of 46.70 mV dec−1 also outperforming Pt/C (74.79 mV dec−1).516 The good catalytic performance was attributed to the porous hollow structure and the synergistic effect between ZnO/ZnCo2O4/C and GO. Noble metals are no longer widely used in monometallic catalysts, but some reports still appeared using noble metals cooperating with Co, Fe, and Ce to improve the catalytic activities.435,520−523 Chen’s group synthesized np-PtFe/NPCS supported on N-doped carbon sheets via thermolysis of a Ptmodified Fe-MOF.520 Meanwhile the porous PtFe NPs are converted to a hollow structure. np-PtFe/NPCS exhibited a more positive E1/2 (0.92 V) than Pt/C catalyst (0.883 V) and a smaller Tafel slope (40 mV dec−1) than Pt/C (48 mV dec−1) in 0.1 M HClO4, benefiting from the synergistic effect between PtFe NPs and the porous NC. Su and Wu’s group reported the preparation of Pt/40Co-NC synthesized from ordered Pt3Co NPs through thermal treatment of Pt NPs supported on Codoped MOF-derived carbon. The dispersed Co sites originally embedded in MOF-derived carbon diffused into Pt NPs to form the final structure.522 Pt/40Co-NC showed a high Eonset of 1.05 V and E1/2 of 0.92 V, both higher than Pt/C (Eonset, 1.02 V; E1/2, 0.86 V), and the stability was also demonstrated by only a 12 mV decrease of E1/2 after 30 000 cycles.

sections.heading: 3.5. CO2 Reduction Reaction (CO2RR)
sections.text:
CO2, the main fuel combustion product, is very largely available, but it is a very low-energy molecule. Thus its reduction (Scheme 4) requires high reduction potentials. Therefore the finding of clean, selective, and low-overpotential electrocatalytic reduction is a considerable challenge due to its complexity with multielectron step processes involved and the variety of reduction products including mainly CO and HCOOH but also some hydrogen, carbonate, oxalic acid, methane, and ethane.524−526
Yet in nature, photosynthesis efficiently converts it together with water into oxygen and energy-storing carbohydrates in most plants, algae, and cyanobacteria using green chlorophyll pigments of reaction centers. Although soluble synthetic porphyrin electrocatalysts suffer from limited density of reaction centers and side reactions, Co porphyrins proved to be very useful catalyst components in combination with MOF thin films and showed selectivity in the Fischer−Tropsch products CO and H2. These electrocatalysts also showed
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AK
greater catalytic currents than homogeneous metalloporphyrin catalysts.527,528 Besides metalloporphyrin-MOF-based electro-
catalysts, various metals have been probed in combination with MOF heterogeneous electrocatalysts, and interestingly, in early studies only Cu was found to efficiently lead to the formation of hydrocarbons.529 In nonaqueous media, oxalic acid530 or formic acid are produced.531 MOF-Cu electrocatalysts are indeed promising as also suggested by DFT calculation.532
Most recently, however, more and more non-noble metal catalysts based on Co, Ni, Mo, and Cu are being developed and applied for CO2RR, producing CO, HCOOH, CH4, and ethylene.533−538
The Wu and Li group synthesized a series of atomically dispersed Co catalysts with various N coordination numbers from a bimetallic precursor Co/Zn-ZIF (Figure 43). Among them, Co with two-coordinate N atoms, Co−N2, was the best catalyst in terms of both selectivity with the formation of 94% CO Faradaic efficiency and a current of 18.1 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 520 mV and activity with TOF = 18200 h−1 in 0.5 M KHCO3 (pH = 7.2).
533 Upon comparing Co−N2 and Co−N4, DFT calculations demonstrated that less coordinated
Scheme 4. Cathodic Reduction of CO2 in the Absence and Electrocatalyst
