N to Co favors the CO2 activation and enhances the CO2RR activity. The same Wu and Li group developed single-Ni-site catalysts for CO2RR based on ionic exchange between Zn II nodes and NiII in the ZIF-8 cavity.534,535 ZIF-8 was dispersed in hexane, and Ni(NO3)2 was injected in aqueous solution. The double-solvent approach allowed confining NiII in the
ZIF-8 pores. This was followed by pyrolysis at 1000 °C under an Ar flow providing N-doped carbon skeleton while Zn (Eb:
907 °C) evaporated, providing N-rich defects. At an overpotential of 0.89 V, Ni SAs/N−C exhibited a high CO selectivity (Faradaic efficiency: 71.9%), a current density of
10.48 mA cm−2, and a TOF value of 5273 h−1.535
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AM
Han et al. synthesized MoP NPs supported on In-doped carbon using In-MIL-68 as a precursor. MoP@In-PC was fabricated by reaction between MoO2 with PH3 and H2. 536 This catalyst MoP@In-PC provided a high Faradaic efficiency for formic acid (96.5%) and a current density of 43.8 mA cm−2 with [Bmim]PF6 as the supporting electrolyte in MeCN/H2O. The catalytic performance was ascribed to the efficient adsorption of CO2 and the synergistic effect between MoP NPs and In−C supports. Sargent et al. designed a Cu catalyst for CO2RR toward high selectivity for C2 hydrocarbon. The Cu-MOF HKUST-1 was synthesized in which the SBU was a paddle-wheel Cu dimer stabilized by the four O atoms of the carboxylate groups.538 The authors optimized the surface topology and size of Cu clusters by promoting undercoordinated sites during the formation of Cu clusters upon control of the Cu dimer structure. Thus the symmetric Cu dimer of HKUST-1 was distorted to an asymmetric frame under selective thermal treatment at 250 °C detaching the carboxylate fragments, based on thermogravimetric studies. The modified, HKUST-1 catalyst exhibited in 1 M KOH a high Faradaic efficiency of 45% for C2H4, and a current density of 262 mA cm
−2 was achieved at −1.07 V (vs RHE).

sections.heading: 3.6. Concluding Remarks
sections.text: In summary, there are multiple synergistic ways and types of interactions involving MOFs in NP catalysis. The Lewis acidic or basic MOF sites may interact with the NPs as well as other components of the nanocatalyst such as functional groups introduced during the MOF synthesis or by PSM, inorganic oxide NPs, or POMs. The MOF pores induce size selectivity in organic synthesis, enhance gas concentrations, and modulate the electronic properties of the NP catalysts that most often also act in synergy among the two metals in bimetallic NPs (for instance a noble metal and an Earth-abundant metal or a transition metal and a main-group element such as B, N, O, P, or S). These multicomponent synergistic interactions are best designed and optimized using DFT theoretical calculations given the high crystallinity of MOFs. Great progress and understanding are awaited from the area of pyrolysis of MNP@MOF compounds.32 This strategy is employed for the valorization of biomass.539 Therefore single-atom-based nanocatalysts are attracting increased attention.540−544

sections.heading: 4. PHOTOCATALYSIS
sections.text: Photocatalysis is an environmentally friendly and convenient approach to convert solar energy into chemical energy. Almost 50 years ago, early studies led to the discovery of H2 production from water splitting from photocatalytic TiO2 materials.545 Since then semiconductor-promoted photocatalysis has remained an active research area. Presently the search of eco-friendly, cheap nanomaterials using sunlight for water splitting remains a formidable challenge for which MOFbased and derived nanomaterials occupy a central place.546 These photocatalysts are also active for a range of other transformations, including CO2 reduction, degradation of dyes and pollutants, and other organic reactions.547−549

sections.heading: 4.1. Hydrogen Production Reaction
sections.text:
Paralleling electrocatalysis, photocatalysis is increasingly involving MOF tools for hydrogen evolution from H2O. Several MOF-based photocatalysts have also been probed for H2 release from hydrogen storage inorganic materials, such as
mostly ammonia borane and formic acid.550 Data obtained recently are summarized in Table 5.
4.1.1. Hydrogen Production from Water. When a semiconductor photocathode is irradiated by light with an energy superior to the semiconductor bandgap, an electron is injected from the semiconductor valence band to the conductive band, and this electron transfers to the catalyst surface via redox mediation to reduce a proton to adsorbed H atom and then H2. The highly competitive process is the recombination, with a strong driving force, of the generated electron with the electron hole that occurs if the mediation is not efficient enough and annihilates the reaction. Free holes and electrons are generated within picoseconds after light irradiation, but hydrogen generation only occurs on the order of microseconds.551
MOFs are essential in this context, because the MOF linker can be a semiconductor that transfers the light-generated electron to the nearby metal node by ligand-to-metal charge transfer (MLCT). The reduced metal node can then transfer the electron to the surface of the transition metal NP cocatalyst for proton reduction. The great structural versatility of the MOF allows exchanging the metal node, adapting the nature of the linker to the required semiconductor properties (verified by the MOF electrical conductivity), bearing ligands that can complex metal ions, and encapsulating the NP of choice. Water photosplitting using visible light is an immense challenge because most semiconductors absorb in the UV region. The use of photosensitizers such as organic dyes in combination with an inorganic semiconductor represents a solution to extend the light absorption from the UV region into the visible region. Thus, dye fixation on the semiconductor surface improves the electron transfer process because the dye absorbs visible light and then transfers the excited electron into the semiconductor conduction band. For instance, the organic dye Eosin Y has been much used for hydrogen generation, providing quantum yields between 9 and 19%. A well-known example of semiconductor is CdS due to its favorable band gap of ca. 2.4 eV that provokes excitation of charge carriers via effective absorption of solar light. A cocatalyst such as a transition-metal sulfide (instead of rare and expensive Pt) is employed to inhibit the fast electron−hole recombination and achieve good performances, including high hydrogen generation and quantum yield. Recent research has involved MOF nanomaterial engineering with a heterojunction, the junction between two distinct semiconductors that considerably enhances the photocatalytic activity. Bimetallic heterojunction photocatalysts are obtained upon pyrolyzing a metal-MOFsemiconductor precursor. Finally in phocatalytic H2 generation, a sacrificial agent is required stoichiometrically as an electron donor to scavenge the photogenerated holes. This is a great difficulty because the oxidation of water to O2 is sluggish, and otherwise, if in an electron donor such a sacrificial amine is stoichiometrically used, the benefit of H2 production is annihilated. Hydrogen evolution photocatalysts based on non-noble metals including Ti,552−558 Fe,559 Co,560−563 Ni,564−568 Cu,569−571 Zn,572,573 Mo,574−576 Cd,577−580 and In581 are being increasingly investigated. In order to decrease the overpotential, the cocatalyst needs active exposed facet and large dispersion, providing fast charge transfer and low surface hydrogen adsorption energy. The adsorption of H atom on the catalyst surface is the essential step of HER, determining its kinetics, and it is reflected by the adsorption energy.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AN
A number of reports have recently appeared combining the semiconductor TiO2 with a MOF to design a photocatalyst in which the visible light becomes efficient and the hole−electron pair recombination is inhibited.555−557 The Cheng group reported titanium dioxide hollow nanospheres (HNP) TiO2HNPs externally decorated with ZIF-8 using sonochemistry. The resulting composite showed dispersion of ZIF-8 on the TiO2 HNP surface. An apparent quantum efficiency of 50.89% was obtained, and the photocatalyst exhibited 3.5 times higher HER than bare TiO2 HNPs due to synergistic activation in the hybrid double shell HNP.555
Lu et al. found that the hydrogen adsorption energy on various bimetallic sulfide cocatalysts CoxNi4−xS4 could be adjusted by variation of the Co/Ni ratio. Using a DFT calculation, these authors proposed that Co2Ni2S4 possess the lowest hydrogen adsorption energy in the CoxNi4−xS4 series; and then they synthesized Co2Ni2S4@MIL-101 to photocatalyze H2 generation.
561 A rate of 441.4 μmol h−1 g−1 was obtained because of the low hydrogen adsorption energy of Co2Ni2S4 and the stability of intermediates during the reaction. Kim’s group designed an onion slice-type Co4S3 nanomaterial Co4S3/CdS from Co-MOF (Figure 44). 563 The Co4S3 NPs effectively accelerated charge separation and transfer because of the low density, hollow interior, and shell permeability of the onion-morphology. A H2 production rate of 12360 μmol h−1 g−1 in cobalt sulfide-based composites was obtained. The photocatalyst Co4S3/CdS was stable for 65 h of H2 generation reaction and could be reused for five runs. Stylianou et al. mixed MIL-125-NH2 as the photocatalyst with Ni2P NPs as the cocatalyst in a solvent mixture composed of CH3CN, NEt3 (sacrificial electron donor), and water and used visible light irradiation (300 W Xe lamp). The synthesized Ni2P/MIL-125-NH2 catalyst benefitted from the high intrinsic activity of Ni2P and the efficient electron transfer from MOF to Ni2P. 565 A H2 generation rate of 894 μmol h −1 g−1 H2 was achieved with quantum yields of 27.0 and 6.6% at 400 and 450 nm, respectively, and the photocatalyst was recycled for 7 catalytic runs of 12 h each. Neppolian et al. designed a Cu2O-encapsulating NH2-MIL-125(Ti) MOF by postsynthetic encapsulation of the Cu2O NP cocatalyst (Figure 45).570 In Cu2O/NH2-MIL-125(Ti), Cu2O NPs located in the MOF pores facilitated electron transfer and the Ti3+ sites favored charge separation, drastically reducing electron−hole pair recombination. A H2 production activity of 11055.5 μmol h−1 g−1 was achieved under solar light, 28 times superior to that of the pristine MOF, and the catalytic activity remained for 5 runs of recycling.
Cheng et al. fabricated ZnO/ZnS nanomaterials (average size: 20 nm) through calcination of MOF-5 (Zn) as a host and thioacetamide as a sulfur source guest.572 The nanoscale heterojunction formed ZnO/ZnS was tuned to enhance photocatalytic HER activity with visible light (λ > 420 nm) with high stability and recyclability without cocatalyst. The best catalyst ZnOS-30 (calcination time in air, 30 min) exhibited a photocatalytic HER activity at a rate of 415 μmol h−1 g−1 because of the shorter path of charge carriers and the efficient charge separation by the ZnO/ZnS structure. Jin et al. showed the enhanced synergistic effects of MoS2 quantum dots and graphene as cocatalysts for the photocatalytic activity of UiO-66-NH2 combined with the dye sensitizer Eosin Y. Graphene is an efficient cocatalyst due to its exceptional electron mobility and large surface.574 Thus, these authors fabricated MoS2QDs/UiO-66-NH2/G, and they employed this photocatalyst for a H2 production rate of 62.12 μmol h −1 g−1 with apparent quantum efficiency of 40.5% under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm).575 The proposed mechanism involved light absorption by Eosin Y on the MOF surface forming singlet excited state Eosin Y*1, decaying to triplet Eosin Y*3 quenched by triethanolamine (TEOA) to give Y− that transfers the electron to the MOF, graphene, and finally MoS2 that reduces H2O to H2. Sun and Zhang’s group incorporated CdS quantum dots and carbon nanodots (CDs) into the cages of the MIL-101 nanoreactor using the one-step double-solvent method followed by heating. With the optimum CD content of 5.2 wt %, the photocatalyst CD/CdS@MIL101(50) exhibited an H2 evolution activity at a rate of 14.66 μmol h−1 under visible light irradiation.578 This rate was 8.5
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AO
and 18.6 times higher than that of CdS@MIL-101 and bare CdS, respectively, and this enhancement was assigned to the effect of CDs serving as electron collector increasing the photogenerated charge lifetime. Han et al. assembled hollow hexagonal porous microrods In2O3@C from core−shell In2O3@carbon nanoparticles (PHIC).
581 Therefore, these authors achieved thermal decomposition upon calcination of the In-MIL-68 precursor in one-step. PHIC afforded a H2 production of 2700 mmol h−1 g−1, higher than that of commercial In2O3 (543 mmol h
−1 g−1). The H2 yield rate was comparable to that of Pt/PHI, hollow hexagonal microrods assembled from In2O3 NPs without carbon layer, which showed that the carbon layer coating of In2O3 NPs has an effect comparable to that of Pt. There was no apparent deactivation of the photocatalyst after 5 reaction cycles. There is continuous interest in Pt and other noble-metal catalysts given the initial impressive performances of Pt photocatalysts for H2 evolution from water.
582−592 Liu and Su’s group synthesized a dye-sensitized photocatalyst Calix-3/ Pt@UiO-66-NH2-1.
583 This catalyst achieved a high hydrogen production activity (1528 μmol h−1 g−1). Liu et al. elaborated a strategy to inhibit hole−electron pair recombination by introducing PtNPs into UiO-66-NH2 followed by using graphene oxide wrapping around the external surface of the MOF in order to facilitate electron transfer on the MOF surface, and they therefore fabricated the catalyst GOWPt@ U6N-8 mL.
584 Because of efficient electron transfer, high molar absorptivity, and low aggregation tendency this catalyst provided a H2 generation rate of 18.15 mmol h
−1 g−1, 21 times higher than the PtNP inside-only decorated sample and 32 times than the outside-only decorated one (GOWU6N). A decrease of the H2 generation activity was observed after the first cycle, however. Pt/PCN-777 synthesized by Jiang’s group produced a H2 production rate of 586 μmol g
−1 h−1 in the presence of TEOA (triethyl orthoacetate).585 Upon replacing TEOA by benzylamine, the H2 production rate decreased to 332 μmol g−1 h−1, while the benzylamine was oxidized to Nbenzylbenzaldimine. The same group also confined the single Pt atoms into the catalyst Al-TCPP MOF (Figure 46), and AlTCPP-0.1Pt exhibited a H2 production rate of 129 μmol g −1 h−1, higher that that of Al-TCPP-PtNPs (50 μmol g−1 h−1).586 DFT calculations suggested that the hydrogen binding energy improved the H2 production activity with the single Pt atoms introduction. Jiang et al. further introduced a plasmonic metal
Au in order to inject hot electrons to the LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) of semiconductor-like MOF (MIL-125). The catalyst Pt@MIL-125/Au then showed a H2 production rate of 1743 μmol g−1 h−1.587
Wan and Guo et al. introduced a methylthio terephtalate group into MIL-125 by solvent-assisted ligand-exchange and then doped this methylthio-functionalized MOF with Pt to obtain Pt/20%-MIL-125-(SCH3)2.
590 The methylthio group helps the absorption band extension to the visible-light region by donating the sp3 electrons. A H2 production with quantum yield of 8.90% at 420 nm was obtained, and the rate of 3814.0 μmol g−1 h−1 was much higher than that of Pt/MIL-125-NH2 (366.7 μmol g−1 h−1). Liu and Wang reported that postsynthetic modification of a triazine-based MOF [PCN9(Co)] by PtII complexation of the N atom of triazine enhanced photocatalytic HER under UV−vis light irradiation by about 6.8 times compared to that of PCN-9(Co) because Pt improved the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers.591 Wang and Su reported the photocatalytic HER activity of an amine-functionalized polyhedral Zr MOF (510.42 μmol g−1 h−1) and its further enhancement upon introduction of Pt, which was assigned to efficient electron− hole separation, targeted electron transfer, and recombination suppression.592
Besides Pt, other noble metals have also been used to catalyze H2 evolution.
378,593−596 In particular, the Au plasmon has been utilized by several research groups.378,593 Tilgner and Kempe reported the combination of plasmonic Au irradiation with the semiconducting properties of TiO2. Therefore, these authors utilized MIL-101 (Cr) as core material to stabilize and direct the size of the core−shell photocatalyst composite.593 The Zhang group demonstrated that Au plasmon excitation by visible light boosted the HER reaction in N-doped carbon-Au NP resulting from pyrolysis at 900 °C under N2 of Au-ZIF-8 together with furfuryl alcohol that retained the porous framework while expanding the active surface area by evaporating Zn. Upon visible light irradiation, the overpotential of HER at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 decreased from 196 mV to 99 mV and an ∼4-fold enhancement was obtained, which was attributed to efficient charge transfer of N-doped carbon that fastened the injection of hot electrons from the plasmonic Au NPs.378 MIL-101core-Au/anatase-shell was synthesized toward photocatalysis of HER from water. The anastase shell was formed stepwise using [Ti(O-i-Pr)4] as a precursor, and a hydrogen evolution rate of 903 μmol g−1 h−1 was obtained. Visible light plasmonic Au NP irradiation on TiO2 shell produced higher activity than Au−P25 (Degussa).593 The intrinsic photoactivity of ZIF-67 was enhanced by energy transfer from a photosensitizer RuN3 on the surface of ZIF-67 by Huang’s group. RuN3/ZIF-67 sensitized by the photosensitizer RuN3 on the surface of ZIF-67 allowed for reaching a hydrogen evolution rate of 4.85 μmol g−1 h−1 without a cocatalyst.594 The photocatalyst NH2-MIL-125(Ti)/ 0.75CN/Ni15.8Pd2.1 was synthesized by Wang’s group. It showed a hydrogen production rate of 8.7 mmol g−1 h−1, attributed to efficient charge transfer by the NiPd NPs cocatalyst and the intimate interfacial contact between the MOF and CN.596
4.1.2. From Hydrogen Storage Compounds. Only a few publications recently appeared on photocatalytic hydrogen generation using MOF-based or MOF-derived nanomaterials from some inorganic hydrides, i.e., ammonia borane and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AP
formic acid. Gu and Su et al. synthesized and compared a series of Co/Ni-MOF-NH2 and Co/Ni-MOF catalysts for AB hydrolysis. The results indicated that the catalysts with NH2functionalized photoactive MOFs performed better than nonfunctionalized MOFs. The visible light irradiation enriched the electron density of Co and Ni NPs, and the highest TOF value (117.7 min−1) was achieved with Co/MIL-101(Cr)NH2.
597 This catalyst preserved its activities after 25 runs of reaction. Kim et al. doped Pd NPs to a core−shell MOFs@ COFs (covalent organic frameworks) to form Pd/TiATA@ LZU1 and then applied this photocatalyst for a tandem AB dehydrogenation and styrene hydrogenation reaction in a dualchamber microreactor. Under visible light irradiation, a TOF value of 147 molH2 molPd
−1 min−1 was achieved for dehydrogenation of AB, due to the synergistic effect among the MOF electron donor, the COF shell mediator, and the Pd NP active sites.598 Xu et al. reported Pt@Rh/p-TiO2 with subnanometer core−shell Pt@Rh NPs using MIL-125-derived TiO2 as both photoreductant and catalyst support. The TOF value of AB hydrolysis with Pt@Rh/p-TiO2 was high, 2441 min−1 (within 1.17 min; nmetal/nAB = 0.0011) at 30 °C due to the synergistic effect between the two metals, the subnanometer and uniform particle size.599
For photocatalytic hydrogen generation from formic acid decomposition, Mori and Yamashita’s group fabricated Au@ Pd/UiO-66(Zr85Ti15) upon assembling Au@Pd NPs on NH2functionalized MOFs {UiO-66(Zr100−xTix)}.
600 The photoactive MOFs and the localized surface plasmon resonance effect of Au promoted the electron-rich Pd sites (Figure 47) and then boosted the TOF value to 200 h−1 for FA dehydrogenation. Kinetic isotope effect (KIE) measurements suggested that the C−H cleavage of FA was the ratedetermining step.

sections.heading: 4.2. CO2 Photoreduction
sections.text:
Besides the production of hydrogen, the photoreduction of anthropogenic CO2 (CO2RR) also is of high interest in order to contribute to compensate excessive CO2 emission due to fossil fuel consumption.601 This process was first discovered by Inoue et al. in 1979 using Xe lamp irradiation and a suspended semiconductor photocatalyst.602 Photoreduction benefits from the sunlight energy to reduce this cheap and abundant lowenergy C1 molecule to valuable products. Indeed such photoreduction is difficult because single-electron reduction of CO2 requires about 1.9 eV, which is above the conduction band of the semiconductors. Whereas homogeneously photocatalyzed CO2 photoreduction is marred by catalyst separation,
the heterogeneously catalyzed reaction by semiconductor suspension most often produces CO, although it might be coupled with water splitting and water−gas-shift reaction to produce methanol.601 For instance,
2CO 4H O CH OH O2 2 3 2+ → +
This reaction remains a real challenge, however, and research in this area is still in its infancy. Heterogeneous photocatalysts for CO2 reduction include semiconductors, transition metal NPs, and alloys and carbon materials, and besides CO, a variety of other reaction products have been obtained including methane, ethane, ethylene, propylene, methanol, ethanol, and formic, acetic, and malonic acids. Reactions are most often conducted in water (although CO2 is a little soluble), which mimics photosynthesis in nature. In this case, water is oxidized to O2 by the electron hole upon photoexcitation, thus both CO2 reduction potentials and water oxidation potential must be taken into account for the electronic potentials of the photocatalysts. The surface of the catalyst (porosity, defects, etc.) is most important for its interaction with and activation of CO2. 603
The major difficulties to overcome in CO2 photocatalytic reduction are (i) photolysis must occur with light of sufficient energy to reach the conducting band of the semiconductor bandgap that usually is in the UV region (only 4% of sunlight) and (ii) the fast electron−hole recombination competes after photoirradiation. Thus, although easily available TiO2 has long been the most studied photocatalyst nanomaterial engineering during the last four decades, researchers have attempted to design new photocatalysts that are efficient with visible light and increase the quantum efficiency by decreasing the electron−hole recombination. In this context, the catalyst improvements brought about by the contribution of MOFbased and MOF-derived nanomaterials has attracted much attention given their rich and tunable photocatalytic properties.604
If MOF metal nodes act as semiconductor QDs, the organic linkers are antenna sensitizing the QDs, and fast charge transfer to metal cluster is efficient. In addition a photoactive metalloligand may also be added by a postsynthetic method. The large structural diversity of these MOF elements makes them tunable photocatalysts.605,606 Table 6 summarizes the recent data obtained with MOF NP photocatalysts. The MOFs used for photocatalytic CO2 reduction have recently been ZIF-8,607,608,627 ZIF-9,625 ZIF-67,613,631 UiO66,618−621,632 HKUST-1,611,616,629 MOL,615 MIL-125,609,610 NENU-10,629 MOF-74,617,630 and PMOF.622,623 Besides classic homogeneous Re-based catalysts that have been introduced into MOF pores, CO2 photoreduction has been initiated by MOF metal nodes and hybrid systems as nanomaterial composites. The photocatalysts have been MOF-based, with the exception of a HKUST-derived catalyst.617 In many cases, a MOF structure has been associated with a semiconductor NP such as TiO2, 607−612 Co3O4, 613 Zn2GeO4, 617 Cd0.2Zn0.8S, 618 ZnO,619,621 CdS,620,621 or CsPbBr3 631,632 loaded in the MOF pores for synergistic reduction of the semiconductor band gap from the UV to the visible light energy region. Carbon materials such as aminefunctionalized graphene624 or graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets625 are sometimes integrated in the photocatalysts in order to improve electronic conductivity inhibiting electron− hole recombination.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AQ
Using the high CO2 adsorption capacity of MOFs, Maina et al. developed Cu-TiO2-ZIF-8 by depositing ZIF-8 on graphene oxide then adding semiconductor Cu-TiO2 nanoparticles. 608 2170 ppm g−1 for CO and 2238 ppm g−1 for methanol were produced with 7 μg of Cu-TiO2 NPs loading under UV light
irradiation. The catalytic performances are due to the synergistic effect between the semiconductor NPs and MOFs and the use of dimethylacetamide as the solvent that possesses a higher CO2 solubility than H2O. DFT studies conducted by the Zhang group on the ligand effects of NH2, OH, and NO2
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AR
on the photocatalytic properties of Ti-based MIL-125 MOF showed that new energy bands appeared in the MOF band gap after introducing this group in the BDC linker and that the NH2 group decreased the band gap of MIL-125 that became significantly shifted toward the visible region.609 Uribe-Romo’s group also studied the effect of substituents of the MIL-125 terephthalate linkers on the bandgap and photocatalytic properties of these MOFs under blue illumination over 120 h.610 These authors showed that the secondary N-alkyl groups (isopropyl, cyclopentyl, and cyclohexyl) involve larger apparent quantum yields than the primary N-alkyl analogs directly related to their longer-lived excited-state lifetime, and that, in particular, the cyclopentyl group induces a small bandgap (Eg = 2.30 eV), a long-lived excited-state (τ = 68.8 ns), and a larger apparent quantum yield (Φapp = 1.80%) compared to the parent MIL-125-NH2 (Eg = 2.56 eV, Φ app = 0.31%, τ = 12.8 ns). These fine and conclusive substituent studies bring about precious information on the molecular engineering of photocatalysts. Wang’s group synthesized HKUST-1/TiO2 nanocomposites in microdroplets through an aerosol route. A CO yield of 256.35 μmol/(g-TiO2 h) was obtained by HKUST-1/TiO2 (ratio: 3.33), much higher than that of TiO2 [11.48 μmol/(g-TiO2 h)] because of the reactant adsorption promoted by MOF.611 Heterojunctions (vide supra) between the TiO2 and Cu2O semiconductors have been introduced by He and Wang via microdroplet approach followed in the in situ growth of the [Cu3(BTC)2] MOF. 612 This is a rare case for which CO2 photoreduction preferentially produces CH4. The enhanced performances were assigned to the semiconductor heterojunction and unsaturated copper coordination sites. The Li group synthesized simple Ni, Co, and Cu isostructural MOFs and found that the Ni-MOF was the best photocatalyst for CO2 reduction to CO with 97.7% selectivity (Figure 48).614 Model studies allowed proposing a mechanism involving CO2 coordination to a Ni node followed by protonation then proton-induced loss of hydroxide to form
water followed by CO decoordination. Using HKUST-1 as a precursor and further loading on graphitic carbon nitride, Sun and Wang’s group synthesized C−Cu2−xS@g-C3N4 and used this nanomaterial to catalyze CO2 photoreduction.
616 This is a rare example of MOF-derived photocatalyst for CO2 reduction. As an electron reservoir, the carbon coat in the catalyst facilitated the electron−hole pair separation. When the C− Cu2−xS content was 0.71 wt %, the selectivity of 97% and yield of 1062.6 μmol g−1 for CO were obtained upon CO2 photoreduction by H2O after 12 h. As a catalyst component, NH2-UiO-66 was combined with Cd0.2Zn0.8S solid solution by Wang’s group for enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction to produce CH3OH. 618
The Sun group introduced the sensitizer [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2· 6H2O] into the new pillared-layer porous high-nuclear Ag@ Co-ZIF-9.625 With the use of this nanomaterial, photocatalysis of CO2 reduction to CO with visible-light irradiation provided, after 0.5 h, 28.4 μmol CO and 22.9 μmol H2. Upon attaching [ReI(CO)3(BPYDC)Cl] to Zr-UiO-67, the Yaghi group fabricated a CO2 photoreduction catalyst that was coated onto Ag nanocubes (Figure 49). The Re centers were confined to the intensified near-surface electric field at the Ag nanocube surface resulting in a 7-fold enhancement of CO2 conversion to CO under visible light, and the catalyst stability was maintained for 48 h.626 The Xu group reported the use of Au nanorods (NRs) serving as cores for the epitaxial growth of Ag shells, followed by oxidative etching, which led to the trinuclear Au@PtAg nanorattles with an aqueous K2PtCl4 solution.627 These trinuclear NPs were encapsulated in ZIF8, and this nanocomposite photocatalyzed the selective gasphase CO2 reduction by H2O to CO. Ryu et al. reported UiO67 modification with a Re photocatalyst and a primary amine to produce a photocatalyst for CO2 reduction to CO under visible light in the presence of TEA. The activity was 3-fold superior to that of the same catalyst without the primary amine.628 Au@NENU-10, consisting of Au NPs, Ti-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AS
substituted Keggin-type polyoxometalate [PTi2W10O40] 7− (PTiW), and HKUST-1 in which the PTiW was used as an electron and proton reservoir was synthesized by Liu’s group.629 This nanocomposite served as a visible-light photocatalyst for CO2 reduction to CO that was 85.3 times more efficient than the analogue containing [PW12O40]
3−, which was ascribed to the higher net charges on the terminal oxygen atoms. Zhong’s group fabricated CsPbBr3QDs/UiO-66(NH2) from perovskite CsPbBr3 QDs and UiO-66(NH2). High CO2 conversion was reached at 98.57 μmol g−1 upon modifying the CsPbBr3 QDs content as 15 wt % under Xe lamp.
632 This catalytic performance resulted from efficient charge separation and transfer between the MOF and the semiconductor CsPbBr3. In conclusion, the use of various MOF as photocatalyst
components is very promising toward future prospects. Precious information has been obtained on the roles and synergies of the linkers, their substituents, nodes, additives,
various semiconductor NPs, carbon materials, heterojunction, and in particular, their influence on the UV to visible region shift of the semiconductor band gaps. The results are still modest in terms of TOFs despite recent progress. The stability of the MOF has been increased with the appearance of very stable MOFs such as the ZIP types but remains a point of care. Recent mechanistic studies bring some light on reaction mechanisms, but progress still remains to be conducted for clarification, for instance using transient absorption techniques. If photocatalytic CO2 reduction is desired, it must be accompanied by oxidation of water to O2 by the electron hole. Many if not most studies are not conducted in water and need a sacrificial reagent such as amine, H2, etc., which remains ecologically and economically problematic. MOFs are extraordinarily rich and powerful nanomaterials, and therefore, there is no doubt that the future will open immense progress.

sections.heading: 4.3. Degradation of Organic Contaminants
sections.text:
Water contamination by organic pollutants, in particular dyes and antibiotics, is a crucial and vital environmental problem of
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AT
human health. Many of these pollutants contain aromatic fragments that are very resistant to biological and other classic treatments. Using sunlight to degrade the pollutants by means of highly active oxygen radicals such as hydroxide radical (OH•) or superoxide radicals (O2•−) for ultimate oxidation to CO2 and H2O is highly desirable. Direct bond cleavage by light being rarely possible, the intermediacy of semiconductors facilitates this process by photoinjection of an electron from the semiconductor valence band with creation of a hole (h+) to its valence band if the light energy is superior to the semiconductor band gap. Further mechanisms are not obvious and depend on the system and substrate, but anyway, the electron hole is strongly oxidizing (for instance oxidizing H2O to OH•) if recombination of the hole−electron pair can be avoided. If the high-energy electron in the conducting band can be quenched by oxygen producing O2
•−, the latter can be aggressive toward groups of the pollutant by nucleophilic reaction and even more so in nonaqueous media. TiO2 is the most popular semiconductor and has been used for pollutant degradation, but its band gap (3.2 eV) necessitates UV light, restricting applications. Metal sulfides including CdS, In2S3, Sb2S3, and CoS2 are often considered because their lower band gaps allow their effective function with visible light, but their use is ecologically very problematic, when they contain a toxic heavy metal. Therefore, the search of new semiconductor systems is very challenging, and the role of MOFs in this context is highly promising, as for other photocatalyzed reactions. MOFs themselves are semiconductors with tunable band gaps due to their extraordinary designable structural variety, and they have been extensively probed in the early investigation for this purpose. Several well-documented reviews are available on this topic, in particular, the later one by the Wang group.633 Pristine MOFs have been the subject of a large number of studies, but their photoactivity remains modest. Consequently, there have been only a few studies of such MOF electrocatalysts during the last two years. Investigations of pristine MOFs in photo-oxidation of pollutants are nowadays published along with the syntheses of new MOF such as in Kumar’s publication on Co and Zn coordination polymers.634 Recent articles on MOF semiconductors for depollution focus on composite photocatalysts that are hybrid nanomaterials composed at least of a semiconductor and a MOF. Again the most frequent combination is that of TiO2 with a MOF. Nanomaterials including TiO2 semiconductor as multifunction photocatalysts have been reviewed by Zou’s group who has also appropriately emphasized the specificity and interest of the construction of robust Ti(IV)-based MOFs for these applications.635 TiO2 has recently been associated with MIL-88B, MIL-101, and MIL-
125.635,655−657 Other associated semiconductors mostly include metal oxides such as α-Fe2O3 with UiO-66,
649 Fe3O4 with MIL-100(Fe),652 ZnO with ZIF-8,650 ZrO2 with HKUST1,658 Ag2WO4 with UiO-66,
642 and rare cases of metal phosphates such as Ag3PO4 with MIL-53 (Fe)
651 and UMOFN,659 CdS with MIL-53(Fe).643 Magnetic catalysts among the semiconductors, i.e., α-Fe2O3 are especially useful for recycling.646,649 Coupled to NH2-MIL-125, QDs served as both electron acceptors promoting photoinduced charge separation and spectrum converter to convert NIR light into visible light.637 Heterojunctions juxtaposing two distinct semiconductors are often used to boost performances.642
The recent data are summarized in Table 7. The most frequently studied dyes are Rhodamine B (RhB)636−645 and methylene blue (MB),646−649 the degradation of some other dyes (MO: methylene orange) have been less frequently examined.650 TiO2 is still widely used in the photocataltytic degradation field. TP-222(Zn) containing a porph-Zr-MOF and linked TiO2 NPs (Figure 50) was synthesized by Zhang and Feng et al. and showed efficiency for photocatalytic degradation of RhB.636 Complete RhB degradation along with a rate constant of 0.01239 min−1 was achieved under visible light irradiation due to the promoted charge separation and transfer from MOF to TiO2 NPs. The TON only changed a little (725 to 719 mg g−1) from the first degradation cycle to the fourth cycle, demonstrating the high stability of TP-222(Zn). Remarkably, there are very few reports using MOF-derived
catalysts even recently, presumably due to the success of MOFbased catalysts.26 Zhang and Liu’s group fabricated and phosphatized a bimetallic Co/Fe-MOF material producing Cp/Fe metal-phosphide embedded in mesoporous carbon, CoP/Fe2P@mC, that was active to degrade RhB in visible light.638 The efficiency of this photocatalyst was assigned to the high electron−hole separation rate of Fe2P@mC, fast electron transfer from CoP@mC, and strong absorption of mesoporous carbon based on radical trapping and ESR data. Feng’s group reported a ternary photocatalyst UiO-66/g-
C3N4/Ag for which the catalytic efficiency in decomposition of RhB and 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-d) increased compared to that of the MOF alone due to synergies among the catalyst components.641 Sofi and Majid reported plasmoninduced charge transfer across Zr-UiO-66 coupled Ag2WO4 heterojunction combined with AgNPs for the photodegradation of azo and nonazo dyes (RhB), under visible light.642
Synergistic effects of the heterojunction and the Ag NP plasmon were found responsible for the favorable photocatalytic properties.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AU
Li’s group has investigated RhB degradation use a core−shell photocatalyst UCNP@NH2-MIL-53(Fe) through NaYF4:Yb,Tm and a NH2-functionalized MOF.
644 Lanthanide ion-doped UCNPs (UpConversion NPs) are a special antiStokes emission material that absorbs near-infrared (NIR) photons then emits a photon with higher energy (UV and visible regions). Considering that MOF photocatalysts can be activated by UV and visible photons, integration of UCNPs into MOFs is a potential way to develop NIR-responsive photocatalysts (Figure 51). A degradation rate over 80% was achieved for photocatalytic RhB degradation by UCNP@NH2MIL-53(Fe).
The ternary 2D photocatalyst BiOBr/GO/MOF-5 was synthesized by the Chen group by ultrasonic-assisted solvothermal method and exhibited degradation of RhB because of excellent electron mobility of GO enhancing charge separation of electron−hole pairs and to the large MOF-5 surface area.645
Wheatley et al. degraded MB using the photocatalyst SnO2@monoZIF-8 integrated with SnO2-NPs to a monolithic MOF (ZIF-8).647 41.5% of MB was degraded in 3 h with 53 μmol of SnO2@monoZIF-8, and the degradation rate increased to 93.6% with a larger amount of catalyst (225 μmol). The MB degradation rate was sustained with 39.4 after the 10th cycle of reaction, revealing the recyclability of catalyst. Shen and Li studied the photocatalytic degradation of methyl orange (MO) through calcination of a Zn/Co-ZIF. The MOF-derived material ZnO@C−N−Co contained ZnO NPs in the core and Co NPs with graphitized carbon in the shell.650 This catalyst displayed the good degradation percentage of 99.5% for MO after 2.5 h (apparent rate constant: 0.0283 min−1) because of the synergistic effect between the ZnO and C−N−Co shell. The degradation of antibiotics is particularly important due to the antibiotic resistance, a rapidly developing phenomenon due to the resistance of bacteria resulting from the wide use of antibiotics in animal food and human drugs for decades. Zhang and Xie’s groups have addressed the problem of antibiotics photodegradation with a combination of MIL-53(Fe) and Ag3PO4 using the examples of tetracycline derivatives. 651,652 Thus, tetracycline hydrochloride, oxytetracycline, and chlortetracycline were the subject of these studies. Upon exposition for 1 h to visible light, destruction was achieved on the order of 90%. Yang et al. studied the photodegradation of a typical fluoroquinolone antibiotic, norfloxacin (NOR), with the BiOrUiO-66-NH2 composite under simulated sunlight.
653 UiO-66NH2 content of 20 wt % (BUN-20) showed the best
performance for the removal of NOR. The removal efficiency of NOR (10 mg/L) over BUN-20 (0.3 g/L) was 93.60% within 180 min irradiation. Efficiency was ascribed to photoadsorption capacity and weaker recombination probability of electron−hole pair. Pan’s group reported the pyrolysis of MIL-125 in NH3 atmosphere at 500 °C producing N-doped anatase/rutile mixed-phase TiO2 (A/R N-TiO2) that was efficient for the photodegradation and mineralization (77% in 100 min) of nitrobenzene under UV irradiation.655
The photodegradation of cyhalothrine, an insecticide of the pyrethrinoid family, is urgent because its wide use has caused high toxicity to the aquatic organism and danger for the bioenvironment. Cao’s group has examined cyalothrin photodegradation using a combination of HKUST-1 and CuCl2. With ZrO2, a junction formed with HKUST-1, narrowing the band gap and reducing the recombination of photoinduced carriers.658 The composite photocatalysts used are efficient not only for the degradation of organic contaminants but also for the inorganic ones. For instance, MIL-88B(Fe)Ag-TiO2NT/ Ti plates were active for the removal of Pb2+.657 Yao’s group reported that the photocatalyzed reduction of Cr(VI) was promoted by the nanocomposites Au/UiO-66-NH2 and Au/ UiO-66 in which the activity was synergistically boosted by combination between Au NPs and the MOF.659
Cui’s group synthesized core−shell Ag3PO4@UMOFNs by coating ultrathin two-dimensional Ni−Co MOF nanosheets on Ag3PO4 NPs.
660 For degradation of phenol and biphenyl A, the degradation rate was 100% within 16 min and 98.9% within 20 min, respectively. The enhanced photocatalytic performance was ascribed to the promoted charge transfer by the MOF π−π bonds and the weak interactions between Ag3PO4 and MOFs. Zheng and Jiao fabricated the catalyst Bi2WO6/MIL100(Fe) for the degradation of salicylic acid.661 The degradation rate for salicylic acid was improved to 95.1% by Bi2WO6/MIL-100(Fe) compared to 65% by Bi2WO6 after 50 min irradiation because of the facilitated electron−hole pairs separation by the p−n junctions between MOFs and Bi2WO6. In addition, no obvious loss of degradation rate was observed after five cycles of the reaction, showing the stability of the catalyst. In conclusion, research on photodegradation of organic and inorganic pollutants is bursting obviously for ecological reasons and the development of nanomaterials. MOFs play an important role in the design of photocatalysts due to their extremely flexible design possibilities and semiconductor behavior. Irradiation of a photosensitive linker is facilitated by subsequent fast LMCT to the neighboring metal node. Combination of the MOF with NP guests and specific groups on the linker facilitate charge separation and catalytic photoactivity. Mixing MOFs in binary or ternary composites including heterojunction semiconductors, metal NP, plasmonic metals, and carbon materials (GO and C3N4) was found essential to create synergies boosting the photocatalytic activities. Several dyes, phenols, and antibiotics have been targeted, and the spectrum of targets will necessarily need extension in the close future. It is likely that further research will include more catalysts not only based on MOFs but also derived from MOFs.

sections.heading: 4.4. Miscellaneous Photocatalyzed Reactions
sections.text:
Besides HER, CO2 photoreduction, and decontamination from organic pollutants, there are a few distinct photocatalytic
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AV
reactions. Cohen’s group reported a representative review of organic transformation photocatalyzed by MOFs until the end of 2016.662 These earlier works included photooxidation of alcohols, olefins, and cyclohexane by MOF SBUs behaving as semiconductors, activities of metalloligands of MOFs for photooxidation of amines, phenol, and sulfides and oxidative C−N bond formation, enhanced catalysis by encapsulating catalysts in MOFs, and photocatalysis by MOF-containing composites using benzylic alcohol oxidation as a model reaction. Composite photocatalysts are rapidly developing, and their remarkable properties together with recent examples have been emphasized in the previous sections. Some additional cases of various reactions including tandem reactions catalyzed by MOF-based or MOF-derived composite photocatalysts have appeared since 2017, often interfacing with the other sections of this review.662
Oxidative coupling of amines to imines using O2 in air as oxidant was reported by Han and Chen et al., who synthesized therefore a butterfly-like TiO2@N-doped porous carbon (TNPC) by calcination of NH2-MIL-125 (Ti) (Figure 52).663 This photocatalyst led to a yield of 99% (rate constant, 0.14 h−1) after 17 h for the oxidative coupling of benzylamine due to the efficient charge separation. DFT calculations together with transient absorption spectroscopy were utilized to show the charge carrier dynamics in N-doped catalyst, assigning the photocatalytic performance to long-lived holes. Chen and Lu et al. reported oxidation of H2S photocatalyzed by a double-shell urchin-inspired nanomaterial, TiO2@MIL101, by coating MIL-101 (Cr) MOF onto hollow TiO2. In the presence of oxygen, TiO2@MIL-101 exhibited a H2S conversion rate of 90.1% after 60 min, almost two-times faster
than with hollow TiO2 because of the excellent H2S adsorption capability of MIL-101.664 In this process, H2S was oxidized by the high-energy photogenerated OH• radicals formed upon H2O oxidation by the electron holes. Chen and Han et al. reported C−C bond forming reactions photocatalyzed by Cu2O@N−C (MCNC).665 This nanomaterial was synthesized by calcination of a Cu MOFs (NTU105) (Figure 53) and catalyzed coupling reactions between various indole derivatives with N-aryl-tetrahydroisoquinoline in 89−99% yields. The composite offers favorable photocatalysis advantages: the porous C matrix substrate stabilizes small Cu2O NPs, inhibiting aggregation, Cu2O N-doping, enhances conductivity, and uniform distribution of N-doped Cu2O NPs produces many active sites. The stability of the catalyst MCNC was established by 5 runs of recycling experiments without loss of catalytic activity.665,666
Su’s group reported ZnCo2O4 mesocrystal on rGO synthesized by annealing ZnCo ZIF on rGO. The ZnCo2O4 photocatalyst was active in NO photo-oxidation (83.8% under visible light and 92.6% under simulated solar light) and was more stable than N-doped TiO2. 667
Kim et al. reported hydrogenation of styrene photocatalyzed by a Pd-doped MOFs@COF nanomaterial, Pd/TiATA@ LZU1, that displayed good catalytic performance for the tandem reaction of AB dehydrogenation and styrene hydrogenation.598 Complete conversion of styrene with a high selectivity for ethylbenzene (>99%) was obtained after 15 min under visible-light irradiation (TOF: 589 h−1) because of the synergistic effect between the Pt active center, the MOF electron donor, and electron transfer by COF.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AW
The N-alkylation of amines with alcohols was reported by Li’s group who synthesized bimetallic nanomaterial PdAu@ MIL-100(Fe) by encapsulating 1.7 nm PdAu alloy NPs into MIL-100(Fe).668 A conversion of 99% and yield of 93% were obtained for the N-alkylation of aniline by benzyl alcohol photocatalyzed by Pd1Au1@MIL-100(Fe) after 24 h under visible-light irradiation. The reaction rates of the two consecutive steps in the N-alkylation reaction, photocatalytic alcohol dehydrogenation and imine hydrogenation, were synchronized in order to optimize the whole process. Photoreduction of Cr(VI) was reported by Jiang and Ai et
al., who synthesized the catalyst Ag/AgCl@MIL-53-Fe by combining plasmonic Ag/AgCl and photoactive MIL-53-Fe. Ag/AgCl@MIL-53-Fe was both efficient for photodegradation of RhB and photoreduction of Cr(VI). For Cr(VI) reduction, high reduction efficiency (99.4%) and rate constant (1.002 h−1) were achieved under visible light irradiation after 4 h.640
After five-run recycling, 93% of Cr(VI) reduction by Ag/ AgCl@MIL-53-Fe was still maintained. Sun et al. reported photocatalytic oxygen evolution using the
catalyst In2O3-450 containing the n-type semiconductor In2O3. In2O3-450 was synthesized by calcination of an In-based sodZMOF at 450 °C, and the In2O3 band gap narrowed to 2.9 from 3.7 eV of the pure In2O3 because of N-doping and formation of oxygen vacancies.669 In 0.1 M KOH, an overpotential for a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (0.60 V) and small Tafel slope (60 mV dec−1) were reached for oxygen evolution under Xe lamp irradiation with long-term durability. In photocatalytic water splitting, the OER being sluggish,
Jiang’s group astutely coupled HER with the value-added benzylamine oxidation in the absence of a sacrificial agent. Charge separation was enhanced by the use of an elongated conjugated ligand in PCN-777. Upon catalyst Pt/PCN-777 photoexcitation, the excited electron produced H2 (vide inf ra) while the electron holes were used for amine oxidation (rate, 1512 μmol g−1 h−1; selectivity, 99% reached in the presence of 200 mg AgNO3). 585
Dai and Fu et al. reported CO oxidation using a composite photocatalyst, Au/ZIF-8-TiO2, prepared by distributing ZIF-8 onto the surface of TiO2 to prevent the aggregation and migration of Au NPs and promote electron transfer between TiO2 and Au NPs.
670 Benefiting from ZIF-8, the catalytic activity of Au/ZIF-8-TiO2 was remarkably enhanced compared to Au/TiO2. The many delocalized π electrons of ZIF-8 could transfer electron density to TiO2 and mediate electron transfer between Au and TiO2 induced by the Au NP plasmon under visible light irradiation. The catalytic performance did not improve too much from dark to visible light conditions, however.

sections.heading: 4.5. Concluding Remarks
sections.text: In summary, composite photocatalysts present possibilities of multiple activation potentially for a large variety of substrates and reactions because of the synergy between MOFs with metal and semiconductor NP components. The goal of these synergies is to favor charge separation by decreasing band gaps and increasing catalyst stabilities. There is now room for considerable selectivity and efficiency improvements. Further mechanistic studies and DFT calculations are still also necessary toward optimized catalyst design.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS AND PROSPECTS
sections.text:
Catalysis is of prime importance in the transformation of chemicals in industry as well as in the laboratory, and MOFs are taking a fast-growing part in catalytic processes. With more than 20 000 MOFs fabricated so far, the selection of catalytically useful MOFs is becoming more demanding in order to satisfy the requirement of stability, selectivity, and efficiency of MOF-based and MOF-derived nanocatalysts. This review has presented first an introduction and general background on MOF nanocatalysis including mentions of seminal and representative examples of catalysts reported in the first 20 years of the field and then a comprehensive view of the last years of research in the field of MOF-based and MOFderived nanocatalysis. MOF thermal stability and in particular stability toward water is a primary consideration in catalysis with durability for recycling, harsh catalytic conditions, and resistance to an environment that has been verified, in particular, for MOF74,40 ZIF-8,42,43 CPO-27,44 UiO-66,45 Cu-BDC (HKUST1),46 MIL-53,47 and MIL-101.48 Recent emphases on highoxidation-state metal nodes (TiIV and ZrIV)635 still improve stability trends. MOFs present the advantage over traditional heterogeneous catalysts to possess a perfectly defined architecture with specific pores allowing selective introduction of substrates. MOFs can be engineered and tailored on demand for a given purpose with considerable flexibility in the design of the nature of the metal nodes and linkers. The influential factors concerning the metal nodes include the oxidation state, redox activity, possibilities of metal-cation exchange and solvent removal for unsaturation, whereas those of the linkers are the acidity, redox properties, and possibilities of functionalization. The choice of the MOF cavity is also dictated by the size of the metal, metal cluster, metal derivative, or semiconductor nanoparticle or any substrate that needs to be introduced inside the MOF or around which the MOF is constructed. A drawback for the characterization of MOFencapsulated nanoparticles is the difficulty of imaging by TEM or HRTEM due to MOF framework shielding. Digestion of the MOF and extraction of the nanoparticle with a polymer is not fully satisfactory. Likewise alloys are difficult to analyze inside MOFs by EDS line scanning or elemental mapping. Therefore, new techniques must be developed. For catalysis, metal nanoparticles must be very small, ideally of subnanometer size, although the efficiency sometimes decreases when the nanoparticle size decreases below a certain atom number. For instance in dendrimers,671 that can be considered as the equivalents of MOFs in homogeneous catalysis, the Yamamoto group demonstrated that the golden number for Pt nanocluster catalysis was 19 for both ORR672 and aerobic toluene oxidation,673 i.e., the catalytic efficiency was lower below 19 Pt atoms. This also raises the question concerning the optimized catalysis by single atom catalysts for which the first MOF examples have recently started to appear234,541,543,544 and how single-atom catalysts compare with subnanoclusters in terms of catalytic efficiency. Singleatom catalysts are the equivalents of the numerous monometallic complexes in homogeneous catalysis whose efficiency is extremely variable depending on the nature of the metals and ligands. As recently pointed out by Corma,543 the difference in heterogeneous catalysts is that the ligands of the single atoms are rigidly held in solid matrices, whereas they are
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AX
more flexible when the complexes are soluble. Also note that single atom catalysis has been frequently encountered for several decades in Basset’s catalytic organometallic surfaces.674,675 The merit of single-site catalysis, however, is that it emphasizes the need to intimately characterize the catalytic event and its precise steps at the atomic and molecular levels. Therefore, the ongoing contribution of MOF catalyst to singlesite catalysis is a major one because it involves a rather clearly defined framework environment around the catalytic sites. The relationship between the MOF framework and the catalytically important nanoparticle shape also remains to be determined. In this sense, organometallic chemistry helps one to understand MOF catalysis, and in turn, MOF catalysis helps one to understand heterogeneous catalysis. Nevertheless, progress is awaited concerning the characterization techniques to define the single-site catalyst and its detailed behavior during the catalytic act. The precise definition of the MOF template should also p r omo t e i n c r e a s e d effo r t s f o r t a n d em r e a c - tions16,25,94,103,122,244,313,315,668 and for enantioselective catalysis using homochiral MOFs for the design of asymmetric induction pathways for which a proof of concept was provided a decade ago.23,676 Sophistication of the MOF architecture by recently designed combined MOFs or MOF@MOF may allow the performance of multistep reactions with improved catalyst separation. There also is a potential for the use of MOFs as enzyme supports for which attempts have already been reported.677−682 In particular, the Yaghi and Sommorjai groups have very recently fabricated MOF-808 with appropriate topology and functionality to postsynthetically install imidazole-containing fragments that were coordinated to CuI in the presence of oxygen for selective oxidation of methane to methanol under isothermal conditions at 150 °C. A methanemonooxygenase-like bis (μ-oxo) dicopper species was proposed as the active catalytic site. It is likely that this MOF-enzyme/biomimetic area will burst shortly.682
Beyond the advantage of precision, MOF nanocatalysis has provided the possibility of involving several components to obtain synergistic catalytic effects between the MOF itself and encapsulated metal nanoparticle or other metal species (cluster, POM, nanoparticle, and semiconductor), encapsulated alloys involving additional synergies. Postsynthetic modifications bring about more synergies by mixing metal nodes and linker functional groups and ligands. Many strategies involving chemical, electrochemical, and photochemical aspects of MOF nanocatalysis focus on avoiding the use of noble metals and their replacement by Earthabundant elements acting in synergy. This is the case for hydrogen generation for which Co and Ni nanoparticles, in particular P-doped ones, should replace the best performing Pt nanoparticles, although performances are still far inferior. In C−C coupling reactions, Ni catalysts are also on their way to compete with the classic Pd catalysts but with great progress still in front of us. A fast-increasing proportion of Earth-abundant metal MOFs are used to produce MOF-derived catalysts for which the MOF together with encapsulated materials are pyrolyzed at variable temperatures. The goal is to fabricate highly porous graphitized carbons with large surface areas, controllable hierarchical structures, and optimized porosities for mass transport and exposition of a large number of active sites, preferably N- or Pdoped provided by the presence of precursors containing these elements. The templating MOF framework is preserved for
maintaining a good porosity and stability of the catalyst. These nanomaterials including metal and metal oxide nanoparticles are fabricated with the aim of substituting noble metals in catalysis. They should be used more often in the future for the catalysis of organic reactions, but they already have been abundantly used with success for energy conversion and electrocatalysis of HER, OER, ORR, overall water splitting, and the highly energetic electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Improved conductivity for adequate electron transfer683,684 is ensured by addition of graphene materials and/or CNTs. Obvious advantages are the simplicity of the synthesis and handling and the low cost. Limitations are the impossibility to control the fine structure in the absence of mechanistic information, disordered structures with lack of interconnection of the pores, and the absence of understanding of the possibilities to optimize electrocatalytic properties. These features are especially crucial for improvement of the central OER and its reverse ORR process marred by their sluggish kinetics. Here again molecular inorganic chemistry should bring precious information on the precise chemistry of the metal-oxo species involved on the oxide surfaces in electrocatalysis.685−687 An extended number of MOFs should be probed in order to improve our understanding, and operando in situ monitoring would bring considerable knowledge on these processes. As in general in heterogeneous catalysis, in situ surface techniques including XAS, XPS, XRD, and TEM allowing to follow catalyst evolution along the reaction should be of great help. The engineering strategies for pore surfaces and their functionalization play a crucial role in heterogeneous catalysis and have been discussed in particular for MOF.688
Photocatalysis with MOF catalysts have been used to improve the well-known photocatalyzed water splitting induced by TiO2 with UV light. In particular, combining a semiconductor and a MOF in a composite photocatalyst with visible light brings about remarkable improvement. MOF structures allowed for a decrease in the semiconductor band gap to the visible region and for a decrease in the charge recombination by separating charges. However, the sluggish water oxidation by electron hole largely limits the efficiency of the HER process in absence of a more efficient sacrificial electron donor. Besides HER, two increasingly active areas of MOF-based photocatalysis using sunlight are photoreduction of anthropogenic CO2 to valuable C1 chemicals and photodegradation of organic contaminants, in particular, in view of water depollution. Photoreduction of CO2 with sunlight is a formidable challenge mimicking photosynthesis in water, and a variety of C1 products have been obtained, although CO is the most common one. CO2 is not very soluble in water, however, and quantum yields and turnover numbers remain low. Yet, the abundant recent research has allowed great improvement in the efficiency of MOF-semiconductor photocatalysts by functionalizing the MOF linker, optimizing the surface porosity and defects for active sites, using heterojunctions, and enriching the photocomposite catalyst by adding carbon materials in order to improve the electronic conductivity.547,603,606,662 The use of the plasmonic Ag or Au nanoparticles689 also allows injecting hot electron into the semiconductor photocatalyst to decrease the semiconductor bandgap. Another limit is the stability of MOFs to UV light in water, although recent MOFs are becoming more resistant. Many studies are not conducted in water but rather in CO2solubilizing solvents with a sacrificial agent as electron donor
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00223 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AY
reducing the electron hole. If this sacrificial agent could be an organic compound whose oxidation would add value, such solution would be beneficial but has rarely been used.662 Finally increased mechanistic and theoretical research with DFT calculations on this process should be very helpful. Photodegradation of organic contaminants is a bursting area using MOF-semiconductor nanocomposite photocatalysts because it is one of the most powerful decontamination methods, and the problem is increasingly becoming crucial for the environment.690−692 Presently, however, most studies concentrate on the degradation of a few dyes using UV light, whereas a much larger spectrum of organic and biomedical contaminants should be examined in the next future. Photolytic processes have rarely also involved polymerization. Yaghi’s group used MOF-901 and MOF-902 for the photocatalytic polymerization of methyl acrylate, benzyl methacrylate, and styrene under visible light in the presence of the co-initiator ethyl α-bromophenylacetate.693 Finally MOF have been shown to also generate radicals for Fentonlike catalysis.694 Nonmetallic cavities such as doped cellular carbon nanocapsules also are efficient electrode materials for energy storage.695 Covalent organic frameworks (COFs)696 are the cousins of MOFs and have not been considered in this review. COFs are deeply investigated for their physical properties and materials applications but less so in catalysis in spite of their capacity to encapsulate catalysts.676 COFs are sometimes associated in complex MOF structures for designed MOF applications.693
In this review, pristine MOFs and their Lewis-acid properties have been mentioned in the introductory background section and had been previously reviewed.15−17 Thus, they have not been further emphasized, especially because synergies with inter alia metal NPs and functionalization have been treated here and have brought about considerable catalytic improvements. Besides, although MOFs have been discussed as perfect materials, it has appeared that many catalytic properties were in fact due to defects in their structures, and this aspect has recently been emphasized.697 Moreover, as noted in the introduction, the stability of MOFs and their resistance in water is of prime importance for applications and, in particular, for their use in industry. Along this line, careful studies of the water stabilities of the various MOFs have delineated this important feature, and a number of early MOF catalysts have been discarded based on this criterion, whereas some MOFs have been found to be remarkably water resistant.43,49−51 Water-stable MOFs are key materials not only in catalysis but also, for instance, for removal of heavy metal and radionuclides.698 MOF-derived nanomaterials have been developed in recent years with great significance for energy-related problems including, in particular, as electrocatalysts and photocatalysts, and here again, the synergies between the nanomaterial components as well as the high porosity of doped graphitized carbon obtained upon pyrolysis of MOFs with other components have been shown to result in remarkable enhancement of electronic and catalytic properties. Another essential criterion for the use of MOF-based and MOF-derived catalysts in industry is their cost that usually remains rather high given their sophistication. This latter aspect is especially crucial and should be taken care of because by comparison the costs of zeolite catalysts18 are only of a few euros or dollars per kilograms and thus will remain difficult to challenge. In conclusion, MOFs will certainly continue to trigger much increasing research in the future with catalysis using Earth-
abundant elements to efficiently address the most challenging chemical, energy, and environmental problems of our time. The greatest goals are fossil-free hydrogen production, selective methane oxidation, water splitting, CO2 reduction to methanol, nitrogen fixation, and water depollution.

Biographies
Qi Wang was born in Luan, Anhui Province, China, and did undergraduate studies at the Anhui University in Hefei where she obtained her Master’s degree under the supervision of Dr. Yan Feng and then carried out Ph.D. studies in France as a Chinese Research Council awardee under the supervision of Professor Didier Astruc at the University of Bordeaux on hydrogen evolution reactions. She is presently completing her Ph.D. thesis with Professor Jean-Yves Saillard in Rennes with DFT calculations. Her interests are in the synthesis, properties, and applications of nanomaterials.
Didier Astruc was born in Versailles and received his Ph.D. from the University of Rennes under the supervision of Professor Rene ́Dabard. He was then a NATO postdoctoral fellow at MIT with Prof. Richard R. Schrock and later spent a sabbatical year in Berkeley with Prof. K. Peter C. Vollhardt. He is a professor of chemistry at the University of Bordeaux and a Member of the Institut Universitaire de France and several Academies. He is the author of more than 500 research publications and several books including “Electron Transfer and Radical Processes in Transition Metal Chemistry” (VCH, 1995, foreword by Henry Taube) and “Organometallic Chemistry and Catalysis” (Springer, 2007). His present interests are in nanomaterials and, particularly, their applications in nanocatalysis.

metadata.abstractText: Metal−organic framework (MOF) nanoparticles, also called porous coordination polymers, are a major part of nanomaterials science, and their role in catalysis is becoming central. The extraordinary variability and richness of their structures afford engineering synergies between the metal nodes, functional linkers, encapsulated substrates, or nanoparticles for multiple and selective heterogeneous interactions and activations in these MOF-based nanocatalysts. Pyrolysis of MOFnanoparticle composites forms highly porous Nor P-doped graphitized MOF-derived nanomaterials that are increasingly used as efficient catalysts especially in electroand photocatalysis. This review first briefly summarizes this background of MOF nanoparticle catalysis and then comprehensively reviews the fast-growing literature reported during the last years. The major parts are catalysis of organic and molecular reactions, electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and views of prospects. Major challenges of our society are addressed using these welldefined heterogeneous catalysts in the fields of synthesis, energy, and environment. In spite of the many achievements, enormous progress is still necessary to improve our understanding of the processes involved beyond the proof-of-concept, particularly for selective methane oxidation, hydrogen production, water splitting, CO2 reduction to methanol, nitrogen fixation, and water depollution.
